en: Two new laws have already been approved by the Saudi Cabinet. One governs the admissibility of evidence, previously at the judges' discretion.
kin: Amategeko abiri mashya yamaze kwemezwa na Guverinoma ya Arabiya Sawudite. Umuntu agenga iyakirwa ryibimenyetso, mbere kubushake bwabacamanza.
mt0: <pad> Two new laws have been ratified by the Saudi Arabian government. No one can prevent the confiscation of evidence, even by the will of the judiciary.</s>

en: The second, a family law, is to take effect in June. In a traditionally male-dominated system, it expands the rights of divorced women to alimony and custody of their children.
kin: Iya kabiri, amategeko yumuryango, agomba gukurikizwa muri kamena. Muri gahunda gakondo yiganjemo abagabo, yagura uburenganzira bwabagore bahukanye kubatunga no kurera abana babo.
mt0: <pad> Second, the family law, must be observed in a marriage. In a traditional system that was dominated by men, it acquired the right of women to support and raise their children.</s>

en: Announcing the new law in March, Prince Mohammed said it represented "a major qualitative leap" for women's rights and "family stability."
kin: Mu kwezi kwa Werurwe, igikomangoma Mohammed yatangaje iryo tegeko rishya, yavuze ko rihagarariye "gusimbuka ubuziranenge" ku burenganzira bw'umugore no "gutekana mu muryango."
mt0: <pad> In March, the sultan Mohammed announced the new law, saying it represented a "breakthrough standard" in women's rights and a "disgrace to the family."</s>

en: The reforms seem partly to cater to foreign firms whose investment the kingdom is courting, said Adel al-Saeed, vice president of the European Saudi Organization for Human Rights.
kin: Adel al-Saeed, visi perezida w’umuryango w’ubumwe bw’ibihugu by’Uburayi ushinzwe uburenganzira bwa muntu, Adel al-Saeed yavuze ko iryo vugurura risa nkaho ryita ku masosiyete y’amahanga ashora imari mu bwami.
mt0: <pad> Adel al-Saeed, the European Union's vice president for human rights, said that the amendment seems to be aimed at foreign companies investing in the kingdom.</s>

en: "The owners of capital are afraid of investing in this country, which is notorious in the legal aspect, so these laws are intended to change the image," he said.
kin: Ati: "Ba nyir'imari bafite ubwoba bwo gushora imari muri iki gihugu, kizwiho amategeko, bityo aya mategeko agamije guhindura isura".
mt0: <pad> He said: "The investors are afraid to invest in this country, which is known for its laws, so this law is meant to change the face of the country."</s>

en: The new penal code, yet to be unveiled, could bring further dramatic changes.

mt0: <pad> The new Criminal Code, before it is published, could bring about further important changes.</s>

en: Under sharia, only apostasy, theft, revolt, armed robbery, adultery, drinking alcohol and slander carry prescribed sentences. Judges are left to determine punishment in other cases.
kin: Muri shariya, ubuhakanyi, ubujura, kwigomeka, ubujura bwitwaje intwaro, gusambana, kunywa inzoga no gusebanya bitwara ibihano byateganijwe. Abacamanza basigaye bagena ibihano mu zindi manza.
mt0: <pad> In the Sharia, lying, stealing, rebellion, armed robbery, prostitution, drinking and smoking are punishable. The judiciary now defines the penalties in other courts.</s>

en: With a penal code in place, "the state will expect judges to rely not on their own training in sharia but instead on the legal rules (based on sharia) approved by the state," said Nathan Brown, an academic at George Washington University.
kin: Hamwe n’amategeko ahana, "leta izateganya ko abacamanza batashingira ku mahugurwa yabo bwite muri shariya ahubwo bakurikiza amategeko (ashingiye kuri shariya) yemejwe na leta", ibi bikaba byavuzwe na Nathan Brown, umunyeshuri muri kaminuza ya George Washington.
mt0: <pad> With the laws, "the state requires that judges do not base their decisions on their own personal training in Sharia but rather on the law (based on Sharia) approved by the state," said Nathan Brown, a student at George Washington University.</s>

en: "As a result, Saudi Arabia will look much more like a civil law system, much like most states in the region," said Brown, who has studied the Saudi reforms.
kin: Brown wize ku ivugurura rya Arabiya Sawudite yagize ati: "Kubera iyo mpamvu, Arabiya Sawudite izasa cyane na gahunda y’amategeko mbonezamubano, kimwe na Leta nyinshi zo mu karere."
mt0: <pad> Brown, who studied Saudi Arabia's reforms, said: "For that reason, Saudi Arabia will look very much like a system of civil law, like many other countries in the region."</s>

en: The result should be more "predictability," said Abdullah Alaoudh, a U.S.-based legal expert and government critic, as new rules "take away from the leeway ... that the judges used to have."
kin: Ibisubizo bigomba kurushaho kuba "guhanura", nk'uko byavuzwe na Abdullah Alaoudh, impuguke mu by'amategeko ukomoka muri Amerika akaba anenga guverinoma, kubera ko amategeko mashya "akuraho inzira ... abacamanza bari bafite."
mt0: <pad> The response should be more "predictive," according to Abdullah Alaoudh, an American-born legal expert and a government critic, because the new law "removes the... powers... judges had."</s>

en: But tighter regulation by the monarchy also "creates a larger problem: lack of independence," he added.
kin: Yongeyeho ko ariko gukurikiza amategeko agenga ubwami nabyo "bitera ikibazo kinini: kubura ubwigenge".
mt0: <pad> He added that however, following the monarchy's laws "causes a major problem: it means losing independence."</s>

en: The king is the head of the Saudi judiciary and acts as the final court of appeal.
kin: Umwami ni umuyobozi wubutabera bwa Arabiya Sawudite kandi akora nkurukiko rwa nyuma rwubujurire.
mt0: <pad> The King is the head of justice in Saudi Arabia and he serves as the last appeals court.</s>

en: Alaoudh's own father, prominent cleric Salman al-Awdah, has been held since 2017, seemingly in retaliation for a Twitter post that clashed with Saudi Arabia's policy at the time of isolating Qatar.

mt0: <pad> The father of Alaoudh, the prominent Islamic preacher Salman al-Awdah, has been imprisoned since 2017, seemingly as punishment for his Twitter posts that were critical of Saudi Arabia's policy during the Saudi Arabian boycott of Qatar.</s>

mt0: <pad> He is one of many people taken prisoner in order to crush the opponents of the government and any potential challenger to the government of President Mohammed.</s>

mt0: <pad> One of the most significant examples is the former prince of the palace, Mohammed bin Nayef, a CIA ally who was respected in the West for his fight against extremism, but King Salman removed him from the line of succession.</s>

en: Graduating from the program doesn't make inmates automatically eligible for early release, but does increase their chances of getting a royal pardon or a reduced sentence. mt0: <pad> The report on Monday reported that Hossein Bahrein said a "large Russian car company" had requested parts from Iran. He did not specify who it was. He said it was seeking parts for ferries, airliners, condensers and other equipment.</s>

en: Diversity, New Perspectives Are Applied to Middle East Coverage
kin: Dutandukanye, Ibitekerezo bishya bikoreshwa muburasirazuba bwo hagati
mt0: <pad> We are different, new ideas are used in the middle east.</s>

en: Natalia Sancha has always adopted a collaborative approach to journalism. When out on assignment, she speaks to others covering the same story about their perspectives.
kin: Nataliya Sancha yamye afata inzira yo gufatanya mubanyamakuru. Iyo asohotse mukoro, avugana nabandi bavuga inkuru imwe kubitekerezo byabo.
mt0: <pad> Nataliya Sancha has always followed the path of co-operation in journalists. After work, she meets with other people who share the same story about their experiences.</s>

en: This partly stems from an interest in telling underreported stories, but as a female journalist in a male-dominated region, she says collaboration and supporting the women she works with have always been important.
kin: Ibi bimwe bituruka ku gushimishwa no kuvuga inkuru zidasobanutse, ariko nkumunyamakuru wumugore mukarere kariganjemo abagabo, avuga ko ubufatanye no gutera inkunga abagore bakorana byahoze ari ngombwa.
mt0: <pad> This sometimes depends on compliments and misleading stories, but as a woman journalist in a male-dominated area, she says that cooperation and support for women colleagues has always been important.</s>

en: "I would talk to male and female journalists, and I always realized that women had a similar perspective, because we had similar experiences while covering the story," the 42-year-old journalist said.
kin: Umunyamakuru w'imyaka 42 yagize ati: "Naganiriye n'abanyamakuru b'abagabo n'abagore, kandi buri gihe nabonaga ko abagore bafite imyumvire imwe, kuko natwe twagize ibyabaye mugihe twatangaga inkuru".
mt0: <pad> The 42-year-old journalist said: "I've talked to men and women, and I always found that they had the same mindset, because we've also had our own experiences when we were reporting."</s>

en: That collaborative approach came into play in 2020 when a publisher asked Sancha if she was interested in writing a book about Syria.
kin: Ubwo buryo bwo gufatanya bwatangiye gukurikizwa mu 2020 ubwo umubwiriza yabazaga Sancha niba ashishikajwe no kwandika igitabo kivuga kuri Siriya.
mt0: <pad> The collaboration began in 2020 when the pastor asked Sancha if he was interested in writing a book about Syria.</s>

en: She countered with a better offer.
kin: Yarwanyije icyifuzo cyiza.
mt0: <pad> He rejected the good wish.</s>

en: "I told him that a collective narrative by women journalists about the broader region would have a different effect," she said. "I could have written the book myself, but it would not have the same sense."
kin: Ati: "Namubwiye ko inkuru rusange y'abanyamakuru b'abagore ivuga ku karere kanini byagira ingaruka zitandukanye." "Nanjye ubwanjye nashoboraga kwandika igitabo, ariko ntabwo cyari kumva kimwe."
mt0: <pad> She said: "I told her that a general story by women journalists about a large area would have different effects." "I could write a book, but it wouldn't have the same sense."</s>

en: Originally from Andalusia in southern Spain, Sancha spent the past 14 years in the Middle East covering conflicts in Iraq, Syria and Yemen, and reporting from Egypt, Lebanon and Tunisia.
kin: Sancha ukomoka muri Andalusiya mu majyepfo ya Espagne, Sancha yamaze imyaka 14 ishize mu burasirazuba bwo hagati yerekana amakimbirane yo muri Iraki, Siriya na Yemeni, kandi atanga raporo avuye muri Egiputa, Libani na Tuniziya.
mt0: <pad> Sancha, from Andalusia in southern Spain, has spent the last 14 years in the Middle East documenting conflicts in Iraq, Syria and Yemen, and reporting from Egypt, Lebanon and Tunisia.</s>

en: She has been working more recently with the European Union communications department, after leaving Beirut for health reasons following a mass explosion that rocked the city in 2020.
kin: Aherutse gukorana n’ishami ry’itumanaho ry’umuryango w’ubumwe bw’ibihugu by’Uburayi, nyuma yo kuva i Beirut kubera impamvu z’ubuzima nyuma y’igiturika kinini cyibasiye umujyi muri 2020.
mt0: <pad> He recently worked for the European Union's communication department, after leaving Beirut for health reasons after the large earthquake that hit the city in 2020</s>

en: Women "have a different experience because we would go to places that our male colleagues were not used to. Not because we're smarter, but just because the majority of the region is still Arab, Muslim and gender-segregated," Sancha told VOA.
kin: Sancha yabwiye VOA ati: "Abagore" bafite uburambe butandukanye kuko twajya ahantu bagenzi bacu b'igitsina gabo batamenyereye. Ntabwo ari ukubera ko turi abanyabwenge, ahubwo ni ukubera ko igice kinini cy'akarere kikiri abarabu, abayisilamu ndetse n'abagabo."
mt0: <pad> Sancha told VOA: "We have different experiences because we go places where our male friends don't know. It's not because we are smarter, but because the large part of the region is still Arab, Muslim and men."</s>

en: Having women reporters has an impact, she noted.
kin: Yavuze ko kugira abanyamakuru b'abagore bigira ingaruka.
mt0: <pad> He said that having women journalists had an impact.</s>

en: "If I put myself in the position of the reader, I would prefer to have a woman telling me the story because it is going to be about 100 percent of the population, which means you are going to have a more inclusive narrative on the conflict."
kin: "Niba nishyize mu mwanya w'abasomyi, nahitamo kugira umugore umbwira inkuru kuko igiye kuba hafi 100 ku ijana by'abaturage, bivuze ko uzaba ufite inkuru zuzuye zirimo amakimbirane."
mt0: <pad> "If I were the reader, I would have chosen to have a woman tell me the story because it will be nearly 100 percent of the population, meaning you will have a full story of conflict."</s>

en: For her book, Sancha reached out to other women who cover the Middle East, to ensure diverse perspectives from foreign and local reporters.
kin: Ku gitabo cye, Sancha yageze ku bandi bagore bavuga iburasirazuba bwo hagati, kugira ngo babone ibitekerezo bitandukanye n'abanyamakuru bo mu mahanga ndetse n'abenegihugu.
mt0: <pad> In her book, Sancha reached out to other Middle Eastern women, to get different views from international journalists and local people.</s>

en: The result of the nearly two-year collaboration is Bullets for All, released in Spanish in April.
kin: Ibisubizo byubufatanye bwimyaka hafi ibiri ni Bullets kuri Bose, yasohotse mu cyesipanyoli muri Mata.
mt0: <pad> The result of a two-year partnership is Bullets for All, which went into the Spanish league in May.</s>

en: In the book, "we tell one story with different voices that represent all the women" from the region, Sancha said.
kin: Muri iki gitabo, Sancha yagize ati: "Muri iki gitabo," tuvuga inkuru imwe n'amajwi atandukanye ahagarariye abagore bose ".
mt0: <pad> In this book, Sancha said: "In this book," we speak a story with different voices that represent all women."</s>

en: Each offers a personal perspective on covering historic moments, including the collapse of autocratic governments, popular protest movements and war. It also examines the discrimination and harassment women face in the newsroom and on assignment.
kin: Buri kimwe gitanga icyerekezo cyihariye cyo kwerekana ibihe byamateka, harimo gusenyuka kwa guverinoma yigenga, imyigaragambyo yamamaye nintambara. Irasuzuma kandi ivangura n'ihohoterwa abagore bahura nabyo mu cyumba cy'amakuru no ku mukoro.
mt0: <pad> Each one provides a unique perspective to illustrate historic events, including the fall of independent governments, widespread protests and wars. It also examines discrimination and abuse women face in the media room and on the workplace.</s>

en: Understanding language and culture goes a long way toward making progress in the region, says Maya Gebeily. The Reuters bureau chief for Lebanon, Syria and Jordan is one of the contributors to the book.

kin: Gebeily yavukiye muri Amerika ku babyeyi bo muri Libani, yatangiye umwuga we w'itangazamakuru mu 2013 akoresheje urubuga rw'amakuru i Beirut, muri Libani. Yakomeje yerekeza mu karere ka Agence France-Presse mbere yo kwinjira muri Reuters.

en: Gebeily said her American and Lebanese background helped her understand the region better, which in turn has shaped her reporting. Knowing the local language is an important part of that.
kin: Gebeily yavuze ko amateka ye y'Abanyamerika na Libani yamufashije kumva neza akarere, ari nako kagize uruhare mu gutanga raporo. Kumenya ururimi rwaho nigice cyingenzi cyibyo.
mt0: <pad> Gebeily said his American and Lebanon history helped him understand the region better, and played a role in writing the report. Knowing the language was also a key part of that.</s>

en: "When interviewing a minister or a displaced person or an activist, the most important element is getting their trust," she said. "If you're able to speak the language and make them feel comfortable from the beginning, it changes everything. It grants you a very beautiful kind of access."
kin: Ati: "Iyo ubajije minisitiri cyangwa umuntu wimuwe cyangwa umurwanashyaka, ikintu cy'ingenzi ni ukugirira icyizere." "Niba ushoboye kuvuga ururimi no gutuma bumva bamerewe neza kuva mu ntangiriro, bihindura byose. Iraguha uburyo bwiza cyane bwo kwinjira."

"If you can speak the language and make them feel good from the start, it changes everything. It gives you a very good way to get in. It gives you a very good way to get in."</s>

en: In addition to Iraq and Lebanon, Gebeily, 30, has also traveled to Syria to cover the war against the Islamic State (IS) militant group.
kin: Usibye Iraki na Libani, Gebeily w'imyaka 30 yanagiye muri Siriya kugira ngo akurikirane intambara yo kurwanya umutwe w'abarwanyi ba Leta ya Kisilamu (IS).
mt0: <pad> Beyond Iraq and Lebanon, Gebeily went to Syria to follow the fight against the so-called Islamic State (IS) group.</s>

en: "Ive been very privileged to access some communities directly without having to work with a translator or a fixer, which also shapes the way that the stories come out," she said.
kin: Ati: "Ive nagize amahirwe yo kugera ku baturage mu buryo butaziguye ntiriwe nkorana n'umusemuzi cyangwa uwakosoye, ibyo bikaba binerekana uburyo inkuru zisohoka".
mt0: <pad> He said: "I've had the opportunity to reach the public directly without having to work with a translator or editor, which shows how stories are produced."</s>

en: Syrian-Kurdish journalist Khabat Abbas, who has covered the war in Syria, attests to the importance of that.

mt0: <pad> The Syrian-Kurdish journalist Khabat Abbas, who has written about the conflict in Syria, attests to its importance.</s>

en: "Its knowing the language and the culture that gives people a sense of comfort to open up to you," she told VOA from Qamishli, Syria.

mt0: <pad> He told VOA from Qamishli, Syria: "Learning the language and culture gives people the courage to open up."</s>

en: That knowledge helped when Abbas, 34, was on assignment with Sancha in March 2021. They traveled to a Kurdish-run detention camp in northeast Syria and interviewed female jihadists affiliated with IS, for a story in El Pais.
kin: Ubwo bumenyi bwafashije igihe Abbas w'imyaka 34 yari mu butumwa na Sancha muri Werurwe 2021. Baragiye mu kigo cy’imfungwa cy’Abanyakorde mu majyaruguru y’amajyaruguru ya Siriya maze babaza abajihadiste b’abagore bafitanye isano na IS, kugira ngo babone inkuru muri El Pais.
mt0: <pad> That knowledge helped when Abbas, 34, was on a mission with Sancha in March 2021. They went to a Kurdish detainment center in north-eastern Syria and interviewed women jihadists affiliated with the Islamic State, to find an article in El Pais.</s>

en: "While in Qamishli [in northeast Syria], I ran into two British journalists, very good colleagues of mine, who were disappointed after Shamima Begum and other women at the camp refused to talk to them," Sancha said, referring to a young woman who left her home in Britain aged 15 to join IS.

en: "Their fixer was a man, so the jihadist women didnt talk to them because they are radical, and they dont talk to men. But then I was able to sit with Shamima and other women, who gave fantastic interviews from inside their tents," Sancha said.
kin: "Umukosora wabo yari umugabo, ku buryo abagore ba jihadiste batavuganye nabo kubera ko ari intagondwa, kandi ntibavugana n'abagabo. Ariko rero nashoboye kwicarana na Shamima n'abandi bagore, batanga ibiganiro bitangaje bivuye mu mahema yabo." Sancha ati.
mt0: <pad> "Their keeper was a man, so the jihadist women didn't talk to me because they were conservative, and didn't talk to men. But I could sit with Shamima and other women, who gave me fascinating conversations from their tents."</s>

"It took a lot of sacrificing for me to convince my family and society that Im as good, if not better, as my male colleagues."

en: Journalism appealed to her because the story of the Middle East has often been told by male journalists, both local and foreign.

en: "The narrative hasnt changed because of that, but if local and international women journalists get a real chance to tell the story of the Middle East, that narrative could change, which would affect the way others see this region," Abbas said.

en: It showed the Israeli flag being set on fire and groups of people around the country shouting choreographed "Death to America, Death to Israel" slogans.

en: Opposition to Israel is a touchstone of belief for Iran, which backs Palestinian and Lebanese Islamist militant groups opposed to peace with Israel, which Tehran does not recognize.
kin: Kurwanya Isiraheli ni ibuye rikomeye ku myizerere ya Irani, ishyigikiye imitwe yitwara gisirikare ya kisilamu ya Palesitine na Libani irwanya amahoro na Isiraheli, Tehran ikaba itemera.

en: "What has happened in Palestine in recent years annuls all plans for compromise with the Zionist enemy (Israel) because no plan for Palestine can be implemented in the absence or contrary to the opinions of its owners, the Palestinians," Khamenei said, speaking in Arabic and addressing Palestinians and other Arabs.

Icyarabu no kuvugana nabanyapalestine nabandi barabu.

en: Thus, Khamenei said, all previous peace agreements -- such as the 1993 Oslo Accords, the two-state solution to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and former U.S. President Donald Trump's plan dubbed the Deal of the Century "are null and void".
kin: Ni yo mpamvu, Khamenei yavuze ko amasezerano y’amahoro yabanjirije aya - nk’amasezerano ya Oslo yo mu 1993, igisubizo cy’ibihugu byombi kugira ngo gikemure amakimbirane hagati ya Isiraheli na Palesitine, ndetse n’umugambi wahoze ari Perezida wa Leta zunze ubumwe za Amerika, Donald Trump wise amasezerano y’ikinyejana "nta gaciro ufite."
mt0: <pad> For that reason, Khamenei said that the peace agreements that preceded this - such as the Oslo peace deal in 1993, the two-state solution to resolve the conflict between Israel and Palestine, and the plan by former U.S. President Donald Trump called the Century Deal "have no value."</s>

en: President Ebrahim Raisi, Irans military commanders and senior officials also attended the rallies in which people were allowed to march through the streets, the first time since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic two years ago.
kin: Perezida Ebrahim Raisi, abayobozi b'ingabo za Irans n'abayobozi bakuru na bo bitabiriye imyigaragambyo aho abantu bemerewe kugenda mu mihanda, ku nshuro ya mbere kuva icyorezo cya coronavirus gitangira mu myaka ibiri ishize.
mt0: <pad> President Ebrahim Raisi, commanders of the Iran army and senior officials also participated in the protests, which were the first time people were allowed to walk on the streets since the coronavirus pandemic began in the last two years.</s>

en: Iran's Jerusalem Day rallies are held annually in support of Palestinians, who want East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state in territories captured by Israel in a 1967 war, on the last Friday of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan.
kin: Igiterane cy’umunsi wa Yeruzalemu cya Irani kiba buri mwaka mu rwego rwo gushyigikira Abanyapalestine, bifuza ko Yeruzalemu y’iburasirazuba iba umurwa mukuru w’igihugu kizaza mu turere twafashwe na Isiraheli mu ntambara yo mu 1967, ku wa gatanu wanyuma w’ukwezi kwa Ramazani kwisonzesha kw’abayisilamu.
mt0: <pad> Iran's Jerusalem Day Conference is held every year to support the Palestinians, who want east Jerusalem to be the capital of the future state in the territories occupied by Israel in the 1967 war, on the fifth Friday of the last month of Ramazani, an Islamic holy month.</s>

en: "Stop your vicious deeds. You know well that we are people of action and reaction," Revolutionary Guards commander Hossein Salami, addressing Israel, told demonstrators in Tehran.
kin: Umuyobozi w'ingabo zishinzwe impinduramatwara, Hossein Salami, yabwiye Isiraheli, yabwiye abigaragambyaga i Tehran ati: "Hagarika ibikorwa byawe bibi. Uzi neza ko turi abantu bakora kandi bakitwara neza."
mt0: <pad> The commander of the Revolutionary Guards, Hossein Salami, said to Israeli protesters in Tehran: "Stop your bad deeds. You know well that we have people who work and act well."</s>

en: "Our responses are painful. You create conditions for your own destruction. We will not leave you alone ...You know better than me what will befall you if you take evil action."
kin: "Ibisubizo byacu birababaje. Ushiraho uburyo bwo kurimbuka kwawe. Ntabwo tuzagutererana wenyine ... Uzi kundusha ibizakubaho uramutse ufashe nabi."
mt0: <pad> "Our responses are harsh. You set the way for your destruction. We won't leave you alone...You know better than I do what will happen to you if you treat me badly."</s>

en: Iran's military has vowed to retaliate harshly against any attack by Israel, which has often voiced concern over the Iranian nuclear program. Tehran says the program is for peaceful purposes only.
kin: Igisirikare cya Irani cyiyemeje kwihorera bikabije igitero icyo ari cyo cyose cyagabwe na Isiraheli, cyakunze kugaragaza impungenge kuri gahunda ya kirimbuzi ya Irani. Tehran ivuga ko gahunda igamije amahoro gusa.
mt0: <pad> The Iranian military has promised to "retaliate harshly" to any attack by Israel, which has often expressed concerns about Iran's nuclear program. Tehran says its program is for peace only.</s>

en: Israel, whose existence the Islamic Republic does not recognize, has long threatened military action against Iran if talks between Tehran and world powers fail to curb Iranian nuclear activity. Iran says its nuclear ambitions are peaceful.
kin: Isiraheli, repubulika ya kisilamu itabaho, imaze igihe kinini itera ubwoba ibikorwa bya gisirikare byo kurwanya Irani niba ibiganiro hagati ya Tehran n’ibihugu by’ibihugu bidashoboye guhagarika ibikorwa bya kirimbuzi bya Irani. Irani ivuga ko intego zayo za kirimbuzi ari amahoro.
mt0: <pad> Israel, a virtual republic of Islam, has long been threatening military action against Iran if international talks between Tehran and the world community fail to stop Iran's nuclear activities. Iran says its nuclear goals are peaceful.</s>

en: In February, the Islamic Republic unveiled its "Kheibar Buster" missile with a range of 1,450 km (900 miles).
kin: Muri Gashyantare, Repubulika ya Kisilamu yashyize ahagaragara misile yayo "Kheibar Buster" ifite uburebure bwa kilometero 1,450.
mt0: <pad> In February, the Islamic Republic of Iran unveiled its "Kheibar Buster" missile with a range of 1,450 kilometers.</s>

en: Iran, which has one of the biggest missile programs in the Middle East, says its ballistic missiles have a range of up to 2,000 km (1,200 miles) and are capable of reaching its arch-foe Israel and U.S. bases in the region.
kin: Irani, ifite imwe muri gahunda zikomeye za misile mu burasirazuba bwo hagati, ivuga ko misile zayo zo mu bwoko bwa ballistique zifite uburebure bwa kilometero zigera ku 2.000 kandi ko zishobora kugera ku birindiro byazo bya Isiraheli ndetse n'ibirindiro by’Amerika muri ako karere.
mt0: <pad> Iran, which has one of the most powerful missile programs in the Middle East, says its ballistic missile ranges are up to 2,000 kilometers and can hit Israeli bases and American bases in the region.</s>

en: Kheibar refers to an ancient Jewish oasis in the Arabian Peninsula's Hijaz region that was overrun by Muslim warriors in the 7th century.
kin: Kheibar bivuga oasisi ya kera y'Abayahudi yo mu gace ka Hijaz ka Arabiya y’Abarabu yigaruriwe n'abarwanyi b'Abayisilamu mu kinyejana cya 7.
mt0: <pad> Kheibar is an ancient Jewish holy site in the Arab region of the Hijaz in Arabia. It was captured by Muslim soldiers in the 7th century.</s>

en: Tehran regards its ballistic missile program as an important deterrent against the United States, Israel and other adversaries, and has rejected Western demands to halt it.
kin: Tehran ibona gahunda yayo ya misile ballistique nk'ikintu gikomeye cyo gukumira Amerika, Isiraheli ndetse n'abanzi bayo, kandi yanze icyifuzo cy'iburengerazuba cyo kuyihagarika.
mt0: <pad> Tehran sees its ballistic missile program as a powerful tool to deter the United States, Israel and its enemies, and has refused western attempts to stop it.</s>

en: Over the past year, Iran and the United States have engaged in fitful, indirect talks in Vienna to revive a 2015 nuclear deal that then-President Donald Trump reneged on in 2018 and that Iran, in turn, began violating in 2019.
kin: Mu mwaka ushize, Irani na Amerika byaganiriye na Vienne mu biganiro bifatika kandi bitaziguye kugira ngo byongere kubyutsa amasezerano ya kirimbuzi yo muri 2015 icyo gihe Perezida Donald Trump yanze kuva muri 2018 kandi ko Irani nayo yatangiye kurenga muri 2019.
mt0: <pad> Last year, Iran and the United States negotiated in Vienne in serious and open talks to revive the 2015 nuclear deal that President Donald Trump refused to leave in 2018 and that Iran began to violate in 2019.</s>

en: Under the 2015 deal, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in return for relief from economic sanctions.
kin: Mu masezerano ya 2015, Irani yemeye kugabanya gahunda zayo za kirimbuzi mu rwego rwo gukuraho ibihano by’ubukungu.
mt0: <pad> In the 2015 agreement, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear programs in exchange for lifting economic sanctions.</s>

en: While they appeared close to resurrecting the deal in March, talks stalled over last-minute Russian demands and whether Washington might drop Iran's Revolutionary Guards from its Foreign Terrorist Organization list.
kin: Mu gihe basaga nkaho bari hafi kubyutsa ayo masezerano muri Werurwe, ibiganiro byahagaritse icyifuzo cy’Uburusiya ku munota wa nyuma ndetse n’uko Washington ishobora gukuraho abashinzwe umutekano w’impinduramatwara ya Irani ku rutonde rw’umuryango w’iterabwoba w’amahanga.
mt0: <pad> While they seemed to be nearing a resumption of the deal in March, talks were stalled by Russia's last-minute wish and that Washington might remove Iran's Revolutionary Guards from the list of international terror groups.</s>

en: As Fewer Americans Attend Church, Can Coffee Shops Fill the Void?
kin: Nk'uko Abanyamerika bake Bajya mu Itorero, Amaduka ya Kawa Yuzuza Icyuho?
mt0: <pad> As Americans Go to Church Less, Coffee Shops Fill the Gap.</s>

en: Churches and other houses of worship have historically played critical social and political functions in American society.
kin: Amatorero n'andi mazu asengeramo yagiye akora amateka akomeye mubikorwa bya politiki na politiki muri societe y'Abanyamerika.
mt0: <pad> Churches and other religious buildings have played a major role in the political and social activities of American Society.</s>

en: But fewer people are attending religious services, and the decline of churches and other houses of worship threatens to leave a void that could potentially be filled by coffee shops.
kin: Ariko abantu bake ni bo bitabira ibikorwa by’amadini, kandi kugabanuka kwamatorero nandi mazu yo gusengeramo bikangisha gusiga icyuho gishobora kuzuzwa n'amaduka ya kawa.
mt0: <pad> But few people participate in church activities, and the decline of churches and other places of worship threaten to leave a gap that can be filled by coffee shops.</s>

en: "For so much of American history, the church has really been — or their congregations have really been — essential, providing an unheralded role in providing cohesion and connectedness in communities … encouraging civic engagement and political participation," says Daniel Cox, director of the Survey Center on American Life and a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.
kin: Umuyobozi w'ikigo, Daniel Cox agira ati: "Mu mateka menshi y'Abanyamerika, itorero ryabaye - cyangwa amatorero yabo yabaye ngombwa - kugira uruhare rudasanzwe mu gutanga ubumwe no guhuza abaturage… gushishikariza uruhare rw'abaturage no kugira uruhare muri politiki." Ubushakashatsi ku Buzima bw'Abanyamerika na mugenzi wawe mukuru muri American Enterprise Institute.
mt0: <pad> Daniel Cox, the director of the American Enterprise Institute, said: "Throughout American history, churches have played an extraordinary role in uniting and connecting people... promoting civic participation and political involvement."</s>

en: "It was not happenstance or luck that the civil rights movement emerged out of the church," Cox says.
kin: Cox agira ati: "Ntabwo byari ibintu by'uruhurirane cyangwa amahirwe kuba umuryango uharanira uburenganzira bwa muntu wavuye mu itorero."
mt0: <pad> Cox said: "It was not a coincidence or a good thing that a human rights group had come out of the church."</s>

en: "And you see that cross-culturally … whether it's in predominantly white rural communities, in the suburbs, wherever, churches have historically been really, really important."
kin: "Kandi urabona ko imico itandukanye… haba mu baturage biganjemo abazungu bo mu cyaro, mu nkengero, ahantu hose, amatorero yabaye amateka mu by'ukuri, ni ngombwa."
mt0: <pad> "And you see that there are different cultures... among the people, mostly white, of the rural villages, on the beaches, everywhere, churches have become history in reality, it is necessary."</s>

en: Churches and other houses of worship have also played a role in helping immigrants assimilate once they arrive in America, Cox says.
kin: Cox avuga ko amatorero n'andi mazu asengeramo nabyo byagize uruhare mu gufasha abimukira kwimuka bamaze kugera muri Amerika.
mt0: <pad> Cox says that churches and other religious institutions also helped refugees get to know each other when they arrived in America.</s>

en: In 1999, 70% of Americans said they belonged to a church, mosque or synagogue.
kin: Mu 1999, 70% by'Abanyamerika bavuze ko bari mu rusengero, umusigiti cyangwa mu isinagogi.
mt0: <pad> In 1999, 70% of Americans said they were at a church, mosque or synagogue.</s>

en: By 2020, that number had dropped to 47%. A 2019 survey found that only about three in 10 Americans say they attend weekly religious services.
kin: Muri 2020, iyo mibare yari yagabanutse kugera kuri 47%. Ubushakashatsi bwakozwe mu mwaka wa 2019 bwerekanye ko Abanyamerika bagera kuri batatu gusa ari bo bavuga ko bitabira amadini ya buri cyumweru.
mt0: <pad> In 2020, the number had dropped to 47%. A survey conducted in 2019 showed that only about three percent of Americans said they attend a church every Sunday.</s>

en: Third places Lack of involvement and affiliation with churches, mosques and synagogues means people might be missing out on what urban sociologist Ray Oldenburg dubbed as "third places" — public gathering spots that offer something that home, the "first place," and work, the "second place," might not.
kin: Umwanya wa gatatu Kutagira uruhare no gufatanya n'amatorero, imisigiti n'amasinagogi bivuze ko abantu bashobora kubura icyo umuhanga mubya societologue wo mumijyi Ray Oldenburg yise "umwanya wa gatatu" - ahantu hateranira abantu benshi batanga ikintu murugo, "umwanya wa mbere," nakazi, "umwanya wa kabiri," ntabwo.
mt0: <pad> The Third Space The absence of involvement and participation in churches, mosques and synagogues means that people may miss what the urban sociologist Ray Oldenburg called the "third space" - a meeting place for many people who give something to their home, "first place," and work, "second place," not just.</s>

en: Oldenburg argued that third places are critical to a communitys social vitality.
kin: Oldenburg yavuze ko umwanya wa gatatu ari ingenzi ku mibereho y'abaturage.
mt0: <pad> Oldenburg said the third place was important for the well-being of the people.</s>

en: An October 2021 survey conducted by the American Survey Center found that commercial spaces like coffee houses foster trust and connection in American communities and could help fill the void left by churches.
kin: Ubushakashatsi bwakozwe mu Kwakira 2021 bwakozwe n’ikigo cy’Abanyamerika gishinzwe ubushakashatsi bwerekanye ko ahantu h’ubucuruzi nk’amazu ya kawa bitera kwizerana no guhuza imiryango y'Abanyamerika kandi bikaba byafasha kuziba icyuho cyasizwe n'amatorero.
mt0: <pad> A study published in October 2021 by the American Research Institute showed that commercial spaces like coffee shops increase trust and connect American families and help fill the gap left by churches.</s>

en: "If you're a regular at a cafe, the barista may know what you usually order, and they can make it for you, and that feels good," says clinical psychologist Dr. Maria Espinola, an assistant professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
kin: Inzobere mu by'imitekerereze ya muntu, Dr. Maria Espinola, umwarimu wungirije mu ishami ry’indwara zo mu mutwe, agira ati: "Niba usanzwe muri cafe, barista irashobora kumenya icyo usanzwe utumiza, kandi barashobora kukugukorera, kandi ibyo ni byiza." na Neuroscience Imyitwarire muri kaminuza ya Cincinnati College of Medicine.
mt0: <pad> Dr. Maria Espinola, a professor of neuroscience at the Cincinnati College of Medicine, said: "If you go to a cafe, barista can know what you're ordering, and they can make it for you, and that's good."</s>

en: "It feels good to be recognized, to know that people are expecting you, to know that people care about you, to know that you belong, because the need for belonging and human connection is a fundamental need that we all have, and it's important to have that fulfilled in different ways," Espinola says.
kin: "Ni byiza kumenyekana, kumenya ko abantu bagutegereje, kumenya ko abantu bakwitayeho, kumenya ko uri uwawe, kuko gukenera kuba hamwe no guhuza abantu nikintu cyibanze twese dufite, kandi ni ngombwa kugira ngo ibyo bisohozwe mu buryo butandukanye, "Espinola.
mt0: <pad> "It's good to know yourself, to know that people are waiting for you, to know that people care about you, to know that you are your own, because the need to be together and connect with others is something common to all of us, and it's important to do that in different ways," Espinola said.</s>

en: "So, places like third places can allow us to do that."
kin: "Rero, ahantu nka gatatu harashobora kutwemerera kubikora."
mt0: <pad> "So, a third party can still allow us to do that."</s>

en: In the past, churches and other houses of worship have been a third place for many Americans.
kin: Mu bihe byashize, amatorero n'andi mazu yo gusengeramo yabaye umwanya wa gatatu ku Banyamerika benshi.
mt0: <pad> In the past, churches and other places of worship were the third most important place for many Americans.</s>

en: In 2019, 67% of people surveyed said they have a third place — a coffee shop, bar, restaurant, park or other place in their community that they visit regularly.
kin: Muri 2019, 67% by'abantu babajijwe bavuze ko bafite umwanya wa gatatu - iduka rya kawa, akabari, resitora, parike cyangwa ahandi hantu basura buri gihe.
mt0: <pad> In 2019, 67% of people surveyed said they had a third space - a coffee shop, a bar, a restaurant, a park or other place they frequently go.</s>

en: That number dropped to 56% in 2021 — a number that could have been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.
kin: Umubare wagabanutse kugera kuri 56% muri 2021 - umubare washoboraga kwanduzwa nicyorezo cya COVID-19.
mt0: <pad> The number fell to 56% in 2021 - the number of people who were likely to be affected by the COVID-19 virus.</s>

en: "What we found was that people who had a third place were much more connected to their community," says Cox. "They're much more likely to engage in other activities there.
kin: Cox agira ati: "Icyo twabonye ni uko abantu bafite umwanya wa gatatu bari bahuze cyane n'abaturage babo". "Birashoboka cyane ko bakora ibikorwa bindi.
mt0: <pad> "What we found was that the third most senior people were very close to their citizens." "They may be doing other activities."</s>

en: They are much more trusting of their neighbors. There's a whole great array of positive social outcomes that were connected to having a third place … and for a lot of Americans, it's a coffee shop or a cafe."
kin: Barizera cyane abaturanyi babo. Hano hari byinshi byiza byagezweho mu mibereho bifitanye isano no kugira umwanya wa gatatu… kandi ku Banyamerika benshi, ni ikawa cyangwa ikawa. "
mt0: <pad> They trust their neighbors very much. There are many good things in life that have to do with having a third... and for many Americans, it is coffee or tea.</s>

en: What coffee shops have in their favor is that they can be found almost everywhere, all over the country, and anyone who wants to can stop by regularly.
kin: Icyo amaduka yikawa abifitemo inyungu nuko ashobora kuboneka hafi ya hose, mugihugu cyose, kandi umuntu wese ubishaka ashobora guhagarara buri gihe.
mt0: <pad> The advantage of coffee shops is that they can be found almost everywhere in the country, and anybody who wants to stop by can stop at any time.</s>

en: And many are open most days of the week.
kin: Kandi benshi barakinguye iminsi myinshi yicyumweru.
mt0: <pad> And many are closed for several days of the week.</s>

en: Cox says even brief coffee shop encounters can increase a sense of belonging.
kin: Cox avuga ko no guhura kwa kawa bigufi bishobora kongera imyumvire.
mt0: <pad> Cox says that even small interplays can add to the understanding.</s>

en: "I think there's a lot of potential here, and a lot of it is unrealized potential," Cox says.
kin: Cox agira ati: "Ntekereza ko hano hari byinshi bishoboka, kandi ibyinshi muri byo ntabwo bishoboka."
mt0: <pad> Cox said: "I think there are a lot of possibilities here, and a lot of them are not."</s>

en: "But in terms of what they could do, there's a lot there.
kin: "Ariko ukurikije ibyo bashoboraga gukora, hano hari byinshi.
mt0: <pad> "But according to what they could do, there are many things here.</s>

en: I've been in places where the same group of folks come in there to play chess.
kin: Nabaye ahantu itsinda rimwe ryabantu baza ngaho gukina chess.
mt0: <pad> I've been to a place where a group of people come to play chess.</s>

en: Or they have their informal bunch of retirees. … They just got together, and they talked and chatted and caught up with each other. … I don't know where else they would have gone — maybe a church, but maybe not — to share information, to encourage each other to maybe get involved in an activity.
kin: Cyangwa bafite udutsiko twabo twabasezeye. … Bahuye gusa, baraganira baraganira kandi bafatana. Sinzi aho bari kuba bagiye - ahari itorero, ariko birashoboka ko atari - gusangira amakuru, gushishikarizanya wenda kwishora mubikorwa.
mt0: <pad> Or they have their own groups that we've abandoned.... They just met, talked and worked together. I don't know where they were going - a church, but it's likely not - to share information, encourage each other, maybe get involved.</s>

en: And I think that is what is so powerful about coffee shops."
kin: Kandi ndatekereza ko ari cyo gikomeye cyane mu bubiko bwa kawa. "
mt0: <pad> And I think it's the biggest thing in the coffee cellar.</s>

en: What US Mayors Are Most Worried About After the Pandemic
kin: Ibyo abayobozi ba Amerika bahangayikishijwe cyane na byo nyuma y'icyorezo
mt0: <pad> The main concern of American officials after the disaster was the economic impact.</s>

en: Americas mayors are most concerned about the lingering mental health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a nationwide survey of 126 mayors conducted during the summer of 2021.
kin: Abayobozi ba Amerika bahangayikishijwe cyane n’ingaruka ziterwa n’ubuzima bwo mu mutwe bw’icyorezo cya COVID-19, nk’uko ubushakashatsi bwakozwe mu gihugu hose bwakorewe ku bayobozi 126 bwakozwe mu mpeshyi ya 2021.
mt0: <pad> The United States authorities are very concerned about the mental health effects of COVID-19, as a national survey of 126 officials conducted in the spring of 2021 showed.</s>

en: The respondents headed cities with at least 75,000 residents. The local leaders are still focused on traditional issues such as violent crime, the economy and infrastructure, but they are most concerned about the pandemics long-term impact on the mental health of their constituents.
kin: Ababajijwe bayoboye imijyi byibuze abaturage 75.000. Abayobozi b'inzego z'ibanze baracyibanda ku bibazo gakondo nk'ibyaha by'urugomo, ubukungu n'ibikorwa remezo, ariko bahangayikishijwe cyane n'ingaruka z'icyorezo ku buzima bwo mu mutwe bw'abatoye.
mt0: <pad> The respondents managed cities with at least 75,000 people. Local leaders are still focusing on traditional problems like crime, economy and infrastructure, but are very concerned about the impact of the pandemic on the mental health of voters.</s>

en: Mental health was top of mind for Michael Udine when he was sworn in as mayor of Broward County, Florida, in November 2021.
kin: Ubuzima bwo mu mutwe bwibanze kuri Michael Udine ubwo yarahiraga kuba umuyobozi w’intara ya Broward, muri Floride, mu Gushyingo 2021.
mt0: <pad> Mental health was a major concern for Michael Udine when he was sworn in as the Broward County Supervisor in November 2021.</s>

en: "Everything that was a potential issue pre-pandemic has pretty much been exacerbated by the pandemic," he says.
kin: Agira ati: "Ikintu cyose cyashoboraga kuba ikibazo mbere y’icyorezo cyarushijeho kwiyongera kubera icyorezo."
mt0: <pad> He said: "Anything that could have been a problem before the pandemic has become more of a problem after the pandemic."</s>

en: "There were issues going into the pandemic, and it was becoming more and more important on everyone's radar screen about the mental health of people of all ages. And I think the pandemic pretty much supercharged those issues."
kin: "Hariho ibibazo byagiye mu cyorezo, kandi byagendaga birushaho kuba ingenzi kuri ecran ya radar ya buri muntu ku bijyanye n'ubuzima bwo mu mutwe bw'abantu b'ingeri zose. Kandi ndatekereza ko icyorezo cyarenze ibyo bibazo."
mt0: <pad> "There were problems that went into the pandemic, and they became more important on everyone's radar screen regarding mental health of all kinds of people. And I think the pandemic went beyond those problems."</s>

en: It is not unusual for large outbreaks of disease to have a negative impact on mental health, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reports that rates of anxiety and depressive disorders among adults increased during the pandemic.
kin: Ntibisanzwe ko icyorezo kinini cy’indwara kigira ingaruka mbi ku buzima bwo mu mutwe, nk’uko ikigo gishinzwe kurwanya no gukumira indwara kibitangaza, ngo raporo y’uko abantu bahangayitse ndetse n’indwara yo kwiheba yiyongera mu gihe cy’icyorezo.
mt0: <pad> It is not uncommon for a major disease outbreak to have negative effects on mental health, as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report, the reports of people suffering from depression and depressive disorder are increased during the outbreak.</s>

en: The pandemic has also adversely influenced the emotional and mental health of about one-third of Americas youth.
kin: Icyorezo kandi cyagize ingaruka mbi ku buzima bw'amarangamutima no mu mutwe by'urubyiruko rwo muri Amerika.
mt0: <pad> The stigma also had a negative effect on the mental and emotional health of American young people.</s>

en: "What we've seen is just such anxiety, kids who wouldn't ordinarily have a meltdown, because it's so much change and difficulty adjusting to transitions," Maryland psychologist Mary Karapetian Alvord told VOA last month. "We've also seen a lot more sadness and depression."
kin: Mu kwezi gushize, umuhanga mu by'imitekerereze ya muntu witwa Maryland, Mary Karapetian, Alvord, yabwiye ibiro ntaramakuru by'Abanyamerika ati: "Ibyo twabonye ni impungenge nk'izo, abana badakunze kugira ikibazo cyo gushonga, kubera ko ari impinduka nyinshi kandi bigoye guhindura inzibacyuho." "Twabonye kandi umubabaro mwinshi no kwiheba."
mt0: <pad> "We found that these children are not often having problems with overeating, because it is a lot of changes and difficult to change the barriers." "We also saw a lot of pain and despair."</s>

en: Early on in the pandemic, mayors were more focused on city operations, budget shortfalls and the threat the pandemic posed to small businesses, according to David Glick, an associate professor of political science at Boston University and a co-author of the 2021 Menino Survey of Mayors.
kin: Nk’uko byatangajwe na David Glick, umwarimu wungirije wa siyanse ya politiki muri kaminuza ya Boston, akaba n'umwanditsi umwe w’ubushakashatsi bwakozwe na Menino 2021, nk'uko byatangajwe na David Glick, umwarimu wungirije ushinzwe ubushakashatsi mu bya politiki, nk'uko byatangajwe na David Glick.
mt0: <pad> David Glick, assistant professor of politics at Boston University and co-author of the Menino 2021 study, said:</s>

en: "Some of those concerns still remain, but what we saw more of in 2021 … is concern about some of the long-term impacts on individual residents," Glick says.
kin: Glick agira ati: "Zimwe muri izo mpungenge ziracyahari, ariko ibyo twabonye byinshi mu 2021… ni impungenge z'ingaruka z'igihe kirekire ku baturage ku giti cyabo."
mt0: <pad> Glick said: "Some of those concerns still exist, but what we saw in 2021... is the concern about long-term effects on individual citizens."</s>

en: "Concerns about polarization over vaccines and just people being pushed to their limits … and certainly less on their city budgets and revenues and having to cut programs and some of those types of things that were probably more top of mind earlier in the pandemic."
kin: "Guhangayikishwa no gukingira inkingo ndetse n'abantu basunikwa ku mipaka yabo… kandi rwose ni bike ku ngengo y’imari y’umujyi n’amafaranga yinjira ndetse no kugabanya gahunda ndetse na bimwe muri ibyo bintu byashobokaga kuba byaragaragaye mbere mu cyorezo."
mt0: <pad> "Anxious about quarantining and people being displaced from their borders... and really is little on the city budget and revenue and cuts to programs and some of those things might have been seen before the pandemic."</s>

en: Over half of mayors, 52%, are worried about "lingering mental health challenges and trauma," according to the survey.
kin: Ubushakashatsi buvuga ko kimwe cya kabiri cy’abayobozi, 52%, bahangayikishijwe n’ikibazo cy’ubuzima bwo mu mutwe n’ihungabana.
mt0: <pad> The study found that half of managers, 52%, were concerned about mental health and depression.</s>

en: Additionally, more than one-third of mayors, 37%, are worried about learning loss among young people.
kin: Byongeye kandi, kimwe cya gatatu cyabayobozi, 37%, bahangayikishijwe no gutakaza imyigire mu rubyiruko.
mt0: <pad> Also, one-third of officials, 37%, are worried about the dropout of young people from education.</s>

en: "Second only to mental health and trauma, and they're probably not totally independent concerns," Glick says.
kin: Glick agira ati: "Icya kabiri ku buzima bwo mu mutwe no guhahamuka, kandi birashoboka ko atari byo byigenga rwose."
mt0: <pad> Glick says: "Second is mental health and depression, and it's possible that it's not really independent.</s>

en: "It is part of that shift of mayors concerns from immediate threats to businesses closing and people getting sick, to some of these longer-term consequences that are going to persist in the future.
kin: "Ni bimwe mu byo guhindura abayobozi b'abayobozi biturutse ku iterabwoba ryihuse ku bucuruzi no gufunga abantu, kuri zimwe mu ngaruka z'igihe kirekire zizakomeza kubaho mu gihe kiri imbere.
mt0: <pad> "It is some of the leadership changes that have been made from the rapid threat to business and prisoners, to some long-term effects that will continue to be felt in the future."</s>

en: And learning loss among their students, theyre worried it's going to persist for many, many, many years into the future. It's hard to make up for."
kin: Kandi gutakaza imyigire mu banyeshuri babo, bafite impungenge ko bigiye. komeza kuri benshi, benshi, imyaka myinshi mugihe kizaza. Biragoye kubihimbira. "
mt0: <pad> And the loss of education in their students, they are afraid that they will continue for many, many, many years in the future. It's hard to weave.</s>

en: According to the survey, other top concerns for Americas mayors include the financial insecurity of low-income residents (33%), the closing of small businesses (29%) and increased crime and violence (26%).
kin: Nk’uko ubushakashatsi bwabigaragaje, izindi mpungenge z’abayobozi b’Amerika zirimo umutekano muke w’amafaranga ku baturage bafite amikoro make (33%), guhagarika imishinga mito (29%) no kongera ibyaha n’ihohoterwa (26%).
mt0: <pad> As the survey shows, other concerns of American officials include poor financial security for low-income citizens (33%), a halt to small projects (29%), and an increase in crime and violence (26%).</s>

en: Just 7% of mayors are worried about the shift to remote work and the long-term impact that could have on outmigration — people moving away from their cities.
kin: 7% by'abayobozi gusa bafite impungenge zo kwimukira mu kazi ka kure n'ingaruka z'igihe kirekire zishobora kugira ku kwimuka - abantu bava mu migi yabo.
mt0: <pad> Only 7% of managers are worried about moving to a remote job and the long-term effects that could have on relocation - people leaving their homes.</s>

en: The $350 billion in funding from the American Rescue Plan to local and state governments could help mayors address some of their concerns.
kin: Inkunga ingana na miliyari 350 z'amadorali yatanzwe na gahunda yo gutabara y'Abanyamerika kuri guverinoma z'ibanze na leta zishobora gufasha abayobozi gukemura ibibazo byabo.
mt0: <pad> The U.S. emergency aid of $350 billion to local and state governments can help officials solve their problems.</s>

en: The survey found that 78% of mayors believe the money will allow them to make meaningful change.
kin: Ubushakashatsi bwerekanye ko 78% by'abayobozi bemeza ko amafaranga azabafasha guhindura ibintu bifatika.
mt0: <pad> Research showed that 78% of executives believed that money would help them make real change.</s>

en: "What we're seeing is a large majority are using it for things they consider to be transformative and will make major changes to their cities," Glick says, "instead of feeling obligated or feeling the necessity to use it to plug up over-budget gaps to keep the doors open and the lights on."
kin: Glick agira ati: "Ibyo tubona ni benshi babikoresha mu bintu babona ko bihinduka kandi bizahindura imijyi yabo, aho kumva ko ari itegeko cyangwa kumva ko ari ngombwa kubikoresha kugira ngo uzibe icyuho cyingengo yimari kugirango imiryango ikingure kandi itara. "
mt0: <pad> Glick says: "What we see is that many people are using it for things that they see as changing and changing their cities, rather than using it to plug a budget gap to keep doors open and lights on.</s>

en: Renting an apartment can be a challenge for new college graduates who are facing the hottest U.S. rental market in a decade, along with some unexpected competition from millennials — people aged 24 to 40 — and even baby boomers — the over-57 club.
kin: Gukodesha inzu birashobora kuba ingorabahizi kubanyeshuri barangije kaminuza bashya bahura nisoko rishyuha cyane muri Amerika mumyaka icumi, hamwe namarushanwa atunguranye kuva mumyaka igihumbi - abantu bafite imyaka 24 kugeza 40 - ndetse nabana bavuka - club irenga 57.
mt0: <pad> Renting a house can be a challenge for new college graduates who are facing the hottest market in America in the past 10 years, with surprising competition from the age group of the millennials - people aged 24 to 40 - and even children - club over 50 clubs.</s>

en: "You have aging millennials who are creating families who should be moving from rental situations into ownership but, because of the lack of housing supply, that has been stopped in a lot of instances.
kin: "Ufite imyaka igihumbi ishaje irimo gushinga imiryango igomba kuva mu bukode ikajya mu nyungu, ariko, kubera kubura amazu, ibyo bikaba byarahagaritswe ahantu henshi.
mt0: <pad> "You have a thousand-year-old family planning to move from rent to profit, but, because of shortages of homes, this has been stopped in many places."</s>

en: And so, what you see is the aging millennial population continues to rent," says Doug Ressler, manager of business intelligence at Yardi-Matrix, a commercial real estate data and research firm.
kin: Kandi rero, icyo ubona ni uko imyaka igihumbi ishaje ikomeje gukodesha, "ibi bikaba byavuzwe na Doug Ressler, umuyobozi ushinzwe amakuru y’ubucuruzi muri Yardi-Matrix, amakuru y’ubucuruzi n’ikigo cy’ubushakashatsi.
mt0: <pad> So, what you see is that the older ones are still renting," said Doug Ressler, director of business information at Yardi-Matrix, a business information and research company.</s>

en: "It's not just about millennials, it's not just about [Gen] Z [people under 24], we also see that boomers are making a transition, he added. "Their percentage of moving into rental properties is growing in the last five years."
kin: Yongeyeho ati: "Ntabwo ari nko mu myaka igihumbi gusa, ntabwo bireba gusa [Gen] Z [abantu bari munsi y’imyaka 24], turabona kandi ko abaterankunga barimo gukora inzibacyuho."
mt0: <pad> He added: "It's not just the next 100 years, it's not just [Gen] Z [people under 24], we also see that donors are making a bridge."</s>

en: There are a variety of reasons older people are opting for rentals, according to Ressler.
kin: Hariho impamvu zitandukanye abantu bakuze bahitamo gukodesha nkuko Ressler abitangaza.
mt0: <pad> There are a number of reasons why elderly people choose to rent, Ressler said.</s>

en: "They've lived in a home for so long and they want to be able to reduce their expenses on a fixed income," he says.
kin: Agira ati: "Babaye mu rugo igihe kirekire kandi barashaka kugabanya amafaranga bakoresheje ku musaruro uteganijwe."
mt0: <pad> She said: "They've been at home for a long time and they want to cut down on the cost of their anticipated income."</s>

en: "They want to live in a social cohort, like a retirement community, and things like that where it's much more socially amenable to them."
kin: "Bashaka gutura mu mibereho, nk'umuryango w'izabukuru, n'ibindi nk'ibyo aho biborohera cyane kuri bo."
mt0: <pad> "They want to live in a life, like an elderly family, and so on where it is very difficult for them."</s>

en: The asking price of apartment rentals was up 10.7% in September 2021 compared to last year at the same time, according to the National Association of Realtors (NAR).
kin: Nk’uko Ishyirahamwe ry’Abacuruzi (NAR) ribitangaza ngo muri Nzeri 2021, igiciro cy’ubukode bw’amazu cyazamutseho 10.7% muri Nzeri 2021 ugereranije n’umwaka ushize.
mt0: <pad> As per the National Association of Residents (NAR), in September 2021, the cost of house rent rose by 10.7% compared to the previous year.</s>

en: "It's a hot market. We have never seen this market so hot in the last decade," says Gay Cororaton, NARs senior economist and director of housing and commercial research. "The average rent growth, year-over-year, is about 3-to-5%. We're seeing 11% rent growth now, so, clearly, way above trends weve had in the past."
kin: Gay Cororaton, impuguke mu by'ubukungu akaba n'umuyobozi ushinzwe imiturire n'ubushakashatsi mu bucuruzi, agira ati: "Ni isoko rishyushye. Ntabwo twigeze tubona iri soko rishyushye cyane mu myaka icumi ishize."
mt0: <pad> Gay Cororaton, an economist and the director of urbanization and research at the Centre for Economic Studies, said: "This is a hot market. We haven't seen such a hot market in the past 10 years."</s>

en: Renters are feeling the squeeze because the COVID-19 pandemic caused supply chain issues, slowing down home building in the United States.
kin: Abakodesha bumva bahungabanye kuko icyorezo cya COVID-19 cyateje ibibazo byo gutanga amasoko, bidindiza inyubako zamazu muri Amerika.
mt0: <pad> Renters feel weakened as the COVID-19 pandemic has caused market problems, damaging apartment construction in the United States.</s>

en: Instead of the usual 5-to-6 month supply of available single-family homes, supply dropped below two months in January 2021.
kin: Aho kugirango amezi 5 kugeza 6 asanzwe atange amazu yumuryango umwe, itangwa ryagabanutse munsi yamezi abiri muri Mutarama 2021.
mt0: <pad> While they normally provide a family home for 5 to 6 months, they have been cut down to 2 months in January 2021.</s>

en: The lack of housing supply means millennials are having a harder time buying a single-family home, which has been the traditional trajectory in the past.
kin: Kubura amazu yo guturamo bivuze ko imyaka igihumbi igira ikibazo cyo kugura inzu yumuryango umwe, wahoze ari inzira gakondo mugihe cyashize.
mt0: <pad> The shortage of housing means that the millennium has had a problem with buying a single-family home, which was a common practice in the past.</s>

en: "The whole building industry was beset by supply chain issues," Cororaton says.
kin: Cororaton agira ati: "Inganda zose zubaka zari zugarijwe n'ibibazo bitangwa."
mt0: <pad> Cororaton said: "All construction companies were threatened by the questions asked."</s>

en: "Shipments couldn't come in, the price of lumber was rising, manufacturing slowed, workers could not come in [to work], so you have shortages of frames, appliances. So, essentially, just a short supply."
kin: "Kohereza ntibishobora kwinjira, igiciro cy'ibiti cyariyongereye, inganda zidindiza, abakozi ntibashobora kwinjira [ku kazi], bityo ukaba ufite ikibazo cyo kubura amakadiri, ibikoresho. Rero, cyane cyane, ni bike."
mt0: <pad> "The shipping can't come in, the cost of wood has gone up, the factories are delaying, the workers can't get into [work], so you have a problem with lack of materials, supplies. So, mainly, it's very little.</s>

en: The housing supply got even tighter during the pandemic as more investors put their money into housing, according to Cororaton, while existing homeowners looked for second homes.
kin: Itangwa ry'amazu ryarushijeho kwiyongera mu gihe cy'icyorezo kuko abashoramari benshi bashyira amafaranga yabo mu mazu nk'uko Cororaton abitangaza, mu gihe ba nyir'amazu bariho bashakisha amazu ya kabiri.
mt0: <pad> The rental market has increased during the pandemic as more investors invested in houses, according to Cororaton, while owners are looking for second homes.</s>

en: "With the pandemic, there was also a big demand for second homes, for vacation homes. Typically, vacation homes accounted for just about 5% [of the market]," she says.
kin: Agira ati: "Hamwe n'icyo cyorezo, hakenewe kandi amazu ya kabiri, amazu yo kuruhukiramo. Ubusanzwe, amazu y'ibiruhuko yari hafi 5% [ku isoko]".
mt0: <pad> He said: "With this pandemic, there is also a need for second-tier retail, holiday retail. In the past, holiday retail was about 5% [of the market]."</s>

en: "Early this summer they rose to about 8%. So again, strong demand and strong imbalance of demand and supply caused home prices to rise, made them less affordable."
kin: "Mu ntangiriro z'iki cyi cyazamutse kigera kuri 8%. Ubundi rero, icyifuzo gikomeye hamwe n'ubusumbane bukabije bw'ibisabwa n'amasoko byatumye ibiciro by'amazu bizamuka, bituma bihendutse."
mt0: <pad> "In the beginning of this year it rose by 8%. Then, the strong demand and the great disparity in demand and market caused the house prices to rise, making them cheaper."</s>

en: The hottest rental markets right now are in the West and South. More renters are moving to Dallas and Houston in Texas, followed by Atlanta, Georgia; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; and Washington, D.C., according to NAR.
kin: Amasoko akodeshwa ashyushye kurubu ni muburengerazuba no mumajyepfo. Abapangayi benshi bimukira i Dallas na Houston muri Texas, bakurikirwa na Atlanta, Jeworujiya; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; na Washington, D.C., nk'uko NAR ibivuga.
mt0: <pad> The hottest rental markets are now in the west and south. Most renters move to Dallas and Houston in Texas, followed by Atlanta, Georgia; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; and Washington, D.C., according to NAR.</s>

en: Cororaton expects the coming year to be a little better but says the housing shortage is likely to continue for the next few years.
kin: Cororaton yiteze ko umwaka utaha uzaba mwiza ariko akavuga ko ikibazo cyo kubura amazu gishobora gukomeza mu myaka mike iri imbere.
mt0: <pad> Cororaton expects the next year to be good but says the problem of homelessness may continue for several years.</s>

en: "You know, the old adage of moving from rentals into homeownership, that whole polemic may be changing," says Ressler.
kin: Ressler agira ati: "Urabizi, umugani wa kera wo kuva mu bukode ukajya mu nzu, ko icyorezo cyose gishobora guhinduka."
mt0: <pad> Ressler said: "You know, the old proverb of moving from the shack to the house, that any danger can be transformed into a blessing."</s>

en: "The sweet spot was always the millennials, and now the millennials are being replaced by the [Gen] Zs, but the millennials are staying longer and the Zs are coming on board, and now you've got the demographic of the boomers … What it means is a very profitable and dynamic [rental] market that's going to continue to grow."
kin: "Ahantu heza hahoze haribihumbi, none imyaka igihumbi irasimburwa na [Gen] Zs, ariko imyaka igihumbi iragumaho kandi Zs ziraza mubwato, none ufite demografiya yabatezimbere… Niki? bivuze ko ari isoko ryunguka kandi rifite imbaraga [gukodesha] rigiye gukomeza gutera imbere. "
mt0: <pad> "There were a thousand good places, now a thousand years ago they were replaced by [Gen] Zs, but a thousand years ago they still live in boats, now you have a growing demographics of the elderly... What? that means it's a profitable and powerful market [renting] that will continue to grow.</s>

en: Some medical experts have expressed concern that COVID-19 preventative measures, like masking and remote schooling, are potentially weakening childrens immune systems by shielding them from the usual childhood illnesses.
kin: Bamwe mu bahanga mu by'ubuvuzi bagaragaje impungenge z'uko ingamba zo gukumira COVID-19, nko guhisha no kwishuri rya kure, zishobora kugabanya intege nke z'abana babakingira indwara zisanzwe zo mu bwana.
mt0: <pad> Some medical experts have expressed concerns that measures to prevent COVID-19, such as confinement and distance education, may reduce the children's immune systems to fight common childhood diseases.</s>

en: "There are a lot of reasons to believe that kids need to be exposed to things to keep their immunity complex, so that should they encounter something very dangerous, they have aspects of their immunity that might cross over and help protect them against those things," says Sara Sawyer, a professor of molecular, cellular and developmental biology at the University of Colorado Boulder.
kin: Hariho impamvu nyinshi zituma twemera ko abana bakeneye guhura nibintu kugirango bagumane ubudahangarwa bwabo, kuburyo nibaramuka bahuye nikintu kibi cyane, bafite ingingo zubudahangarwa bwabo zishobora kwambuka zikabafasha kubarinda ibyo bintu, ibi bikaba byavuzwe na Sara Sawyer, umwarimu w’ibinyabuzima bya molekuline, selile n’iterambere muri kaminuza ya Colorado Boulder.
mt0: <pad> There are many reasons why we think children need to experience things to build their immunity, so that if they are exposed to something very bad, they have a built-in immune system that can cross over and protect them from that thing, says Sara Sawyer, professor of molecular biology, cell and development at the University of Colorado Boulder.</s>

en: At birth, vulnerable infants get antibodies from their mothers breast milk, which helps protect them until they can build their own immunity.
kin: Mu gihe cyo kuvuka, impinja zitagira kivurira zibona antibodi kuri ba nyina amashereka, abafasha kubarinda kugeza igihe bazubaka ubudahangarwa bwabo.
mt0: <pad> When newborns are born, they receive antibodies from their mother's milk, which helps them to protect until they build their own immunity.</s>

en: Its no accident that babies start putting things in their mouths as soon as they gain enough dexterity to pick things up.
kin: Ntabwo ari impanuka ko abana batangira gushyira ibintu mu munwa bakimara kugira ubuhanga buhagije bwo gutoragura ibintu.
mt0: <pad> It is not a coincidence that children start putting things in their mouths as soon as they are able to pick up things.</s>

en: "They're doing that because they're sampling the environment and building their immunity. That's an evolutionary trait," Sawyer says.
kin: Sawyer agira ati: "Ibyo babikora kubera ko batoranya ibidukikije kandi bakubaka ubudahangarwa bwabo. Iyo ni imwe mu bwihindurize."
mt0: <pad> Sawyer says: "They do this because they select their environment and build their immunity. That's one of the evolutionary changes."</s>

en: "They're exposing their body to germs in a certain, level way to build their immunity.
kin: Bagaragaza umubiri wabo kuri mikorobe mu buryo runaka, bwo kubaka ubudahangarwa bwabo. Abantu bamwe rero bavuga ko indwara zo mu bwana, nk'ubukonje ndetse n'udukoko two mu gifu, byubaka ubudahangarwa bwacu kugira ngo igihe ibintu byinshi biteye akaga, twiteguye kandi ntituzarwara muri ibyo bintu bibi cyane.
mt0: <pad> They expose their body to microorganisms in a way that builds their immunity. Some people therefore say that childhood illnesses, such as malnutrition and diarrhea, build our immunity so that when many dangers come, we are prepared and not sick in the most severe of those bad things.</s>

en: Even before the pandemic, epidemiological evidence suggested that children in more developed countries, where handwashing and the use of sanitizer are more prevalent, might have less-developed immune systems compared to kids in developing nations who are routinely exposed to more bacteria, viruses and allergens.
kin: Ndetse na mbere y’icyorezo, ibimenyetso by’ibyorezo byerekanaga ko abana bo mu bihugu byateye imbere cyane, aho gukaraba intoki no gukoresha isuku byiganje, bashobora kuba bafite sisitemu y’umubiri idateye imbere ugereranije n’abana bo mu bihugu bikiri mu nzira y'amajyambere bakunze guhura na bagiteri nyinshi, virusi na allergene. .
mt0: <pad> Even before the pandemic, evidence showed that children in highly developed countries, where handwashing and hygiene practices are common, may have a less developed immune system than children in developing countries who are more likely to be exposed to bacteries, viruses and allergens.</s>

en: This makes kids in more industrialized countries more vulnerable to developing autoimmune diseases, according to whats known as the "hygiene hypothesis."
kin: Ibi bituma abana bo mu bihugu byinshi byateye imbere bibasirwa n'indwara ziterwa na autoimmune, ukurikije icyo bita "hypothesis yisuku."
mt0: <pad> This causes children in many developed countries to be at risk of autoimmune diseases, according to what is called the "cultural hypothesis."</s>

en: "The hygiene hypothesis is actually quite controversial because it's thought that our exposure to microbes isn't the only factor," says Cody Warren, a virologist and immunologist who is a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Colorado Boulder.
kin: Cody Warren, inzobere mu bijyanye na virusi akaba n'umu immunologue akaba ari umunyeshuri w’iposita muri kaminuza ya Colorado Boulder, agira ati: "Igitekerezo cy’isuku mu byukuri ntikivugwaho rumwe kuko twibwira ko guhura na mikorobe atari byo byonyine."
mt0: <pad> Cody Warren, a virus expert and immunologist at the University of Colorado Boulder, said: "The idea of cleanliness is really not shared because we think that getting in touch with microorganisms is not the only thing that can be spread."</s>

en: "A lot of this could also be dictated by genetics, diet, and the environment that we live in.
kin: Byinshi muri byo bishobora nanone guterwa na genetiki, imirire, n'ibidukikije dutuyemo. Ibyo kandi bigira uruhare runini mumubiri… nikintu gifatika tudashobora kubara byuzuye twambaye masike. Hariho ibindi bintu bijya muri iryo gereranya.
mt0: <pad> Many of them can also be affected by genetics, diet and the environment we live in. They also have a large impact on the body... nothing tangible can be counted fully wearing a mask. There are other things that come into that comparison.</s>

en: Warren, the father of three young children, says spending lots of time outdoors is one way to balance the negatives of isolation.
kin: Warren, se w'abana batatu bato, avuga ko kumara umwanya munini hanze ari bumwe mu buryo bwo guhuza ibibi byo kwigunga.
mt0: <pad> Warren, a father of three young children, says that spending a lot of time outside is one way to combat the dangers of isolation.</s>

en: "Just exploring microbes in the environment also is benefiting [and] training our immune system," Warren says. "Our immune systems get trained through the foods that we eat, which also have microorganisms on them.
kin: Warren agira ati: "Gusa gukora ubushakashatsi kuri mikorobe mu bidukikije nabyo byunguka [no] guhugura umubiri." "Ubudahangarwa bw'umubiri bwacu butozwa binyuze mu biryo turya, bifite na mikorobe kuri byo.
mt0: <pad> Warren said, "Even researching bacterial communities in the environment would be beneficial [to] train the body." "Our immune system is maintained through our food, which has bacterial communities on it."</s>

en: And so, despite the fact that we've kind of been hunkered down a little bit, I do feel that our immune systems will catch up."
kin: Kandi rero, nubwo twaba twarahigishijwe gato, ndumva ko ubudahangarwa bwacu buzafatwa. "
mt0: <pad> So, even though we've been a little threatened, I think our independence will be taken.</s>

en: There are other things parents can do, he says, to boost their childrens immune systems during pandemic times.
kin: Avuga ko hari ibindi bintu ababyeyi bashobora gukora, kugirango bongere abana babo ubudahangarwa bw'umubiri mugihe cyibyorezo.
mt0: <pad> He says there are other things parents can do, to boost their children's immune system during the pandemic.</s>

en: "One of the most important things you can do is just to stay up to date on vaccines.
kin: "Kimwe mu bintu by'ingenzi ushobora gukora ni ugukomeza kugezwaho amakuru ku nkingo.
mt0: <pad> One of the most important things you can do is to keep informing people about the border.</s>

en: That's one of the best ways that we have to train our immune systems," Warren says.
kin: Ubu ni bumwe mu buryo bwiza tugomba kumenyereza umubiri, "Warren.
mt0: <pad> This is one of the best ways to train the body," said Warren.</s>

en: "But also, equally important is making sure our children have a good diet and they regulate stress.
kin: Ariko nanone, icy'ingenzi ni ukureba niba abana bacu bafite indyo yuzuye kandi bagenga imihangayiko. Byanditswe neza ko ibyo byombi - kugira indyo yuzuye, ibidukikije bidahangayikishije - bishobora kugira ingaruka nziza ku mikorere yacu.
mt0: <pad> But also, it is important to see if our children have a balanced diet and manage stress. It has been well documented that both of these - having a balanced diet, a stress-free environment - can have positive effects on our performance.</s>

en: Once public health officials say masks are no longer necessary, Sawyer thinks pointing out the positives of putting our masks away could reassure hesitant parents who worry about their children getting sick.
kin: Abashinzwe ubuzima rusange bamaze kuvuga ko masike atagikenewe, Sawyer atekereza ko kwerekana ibyiza byo gushyira maska ​​yacu bishobora guhumuriza ababyeyi bashidikanya bahangayikishijwe n’abana babo barwara.
mt0: <pad> After public health officials said masks were no longer needed, Sawyer thinks that showing the benefits of wearing our masks might comfort doubtful parents who are worried about their children being infected.</s>

en: "Maybe we should have a public conversation about the possible reasons to take that mask off, if they are in school, and get back to the normal repertoire of relatively safe childhood illnesses," she says.
kin: Agira ati: "Ahari twakagombye kugirana ikiganiro mbwirwaruhame ku mpamvu zishoboka zo gukuramo iyo mask, niba bari ku ishuri, hanyuma tugasubira mu ndirimbo zisanzwe z’indwara zo mu bwana zifite umutekano."
mt0: <pad> He said: "We should probably have a discussion about the possibilities of removing the mask, if they are at school, and then return to the normal childbirth songs that are safe."</s>

en: "The plus side of childhood illnesses is that they can build up that hornet's nest of immunity that could protect kids against new things that then come along."
kin: Icyiza cy’indwara zo mu bwana ni uko zishobora kubaka icyari cya hornet cy’ubudahangarwa gishobora kurinda abana ibintu bishya hanyuma bikaza.
mt0: <pad> The good thing about childhood illnesses is that they can build a healthy immune system that can protect children from new things and then develop.</s>

en: US Quietly Expands Asylum Limits While Preparing to End Them
kin: Amerika Yaguye Bituje Imipaka Yubuhunzi Mugihe Yitegura Kubarangiza
mt0: <pad> America has closed its immigration borders as it prepares to close them</s>

en: The Biden administration has begun expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans to Mexico under pandemic-related powers to deny migrants a chance to seek asylum, expanding use of the rule even as it publicly says it has been trying to unwind it, officials said Wednesday.
kin: Ku wa gatatu, abayobozi bavuze ko ubuyobozi bwa Biden bwatangiye kwirukana Abanyakanani na Nikaragwa muri Mexico kubera ububasha bujyanye n’icyorezo bwo kwima abimukira amahirwe yo gusaba ubuhungiro, kwagura ikoreshwa ry’iryo tegeko nubwo rivuga ku mugaragaro ko ryagerageje kubireka.
mt0: <pad> Wednesday, officials said that Biden's administration began deporting Mexicans and Nicaraguans from Mexico under the power of the pandemic to deny asylum applicants the chance to ask for asylum, expanding the use of the law even though it officially says it has tried to stop it.</s>

en: The U.S. struck agreement with Mexico to expel up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans a day from three locations: San Diego; El Paso, Texas; and Rio Grande Valley, Texas, according to a U.S. official with direct knowledge of the effort.
kin: Amerika yagiranye amasezerano na Mexico yo kwirukana abanya Cuba 100 na Nikaragwa 20 kumunsi ahantu hatatu: San Diego; El Paso, muri Texas; n'ikibaya cya Rio Grande, muri Texas, nk'uko byatangajwe n'umuyobozi wa Amerika ufite ubumenyi butaziguye bw'imbaraga.
mt0: <pad> America has signed an agreement with Mexico to deport 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans per day in three places: San Diego; El Paso, Texas; and the Rio Grande Valley, Texas, according to the United States intelligence official.</s>

en: The expulsions began April 27 and will end May 22, the official told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the agreement has not been made public.
kin: Iyirukanwa ryatangiye ku ya 27 Mata rikazarangira ku ya 22 Gicurasi, nk'uko uyu muyobozi yabitangarije ibiro ntaramakuru by'Abanyamerika kugira ngo atamenyekana kubera ko ayo masezerano atashyizwe ahagaragara.
mt0: <pad> The expulsions began on 27 April and will end on 22 May, the official said to the American Press Corps in order to avoid being identified because the contracts were not publicly released.</s>

en: They are carried out under Title 42 authority, a public health law that has been used to expel migrants on grounds of preventing spread of COVID-19. Title 42 is due to expire May 23, unless a judge intervenes.
