kin: Bikorerwa munsi yumutwe wa 42, itegeko ryubuzima rusange ryakoreshejwe mu kwirukana abimukira ku mpamvu zo gukumira ikwirakwizwa rya COVID-19. Umutwe wa 42 ugomba kurangira ku ya 23 Gicurasi, keretse umucamanza abigizemo uruhare.
mt0: <pad> It is done under Section 42, a general health law used to deport migrants for the purposes of preventing the spread of COVID-19. Section 42 should end on May 23, unless a court intervenes.</s>

en: The U.S. and Mexico agreed April 26 to a very limited number of expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans, according to a high-level Mexican official who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment publicly.
kin: Nk’uko byatangajwe n'umuyobozi wo mu rwego rwo hejuru wo muri Megizike wavuze ko atigeze atangazwa kubera ko batemerewe kugira icyo batangaza ku mugaragaro, Amerika na Mexico byumvikanye ku ya 26 Mata ku mubare muto cyane wo kwirukana Abanyakanani na Nikaragwa.
mt0: <pad> As a senior Mexican official said, which he did not name because they were not allowed to make public statements, the United States and Mexico agreed on 26 April on a small number of deportations of Canadians and Nicaraguans.</s>

en: It was prompted by higher numbers of migrants from those two countries coming to the U.S. border.
kin: Byatewe numubare munini w’abimukira bava muri ibyo bihugu byombi baza kumupaka wa Amerika.
mt0: <pad> It is due to the large number of migrants from both countries coming to the United States border.</s>

en: Mexico also took into account that the U.S. government had started processing visas in Cuba again, the official said. Mexico had also begun processing visas for Cubans.
kin: Uyu muyobozi yavuze ko Mexico kandi yazirikanye ko guverinoma y'Amerika yatangiye gutunganya viza muri Cuba. Mexico nayo yari yatangiye gutunganya viza kubanya Cuba.
mt0: <pad> The official also said that Mexico had recognized the US government's decision to start processing visa applications for Cubans. Mexico had also begun processing visa applications for Cubans.</s>

en: Another Mexican official, also not authorized to comment publicly, confirmed that up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans were being expelled from San Diego under Title 42.
kin: Undi muyobozi wo muri Megizike, na we utemerewe kugira icyo atangaza ku mugaragaro, yemeje ko Abanyakanani bagera kuri 100 na Nikaragwa 20 birukanwa muri San Diego ku mutwe wa 42.
mt0: <pad> Another Mexican official, who is not allowed to speak publicly, confirmed that about 100 Canadians and 20 Nicaraguans were deported from San Diego on charges of illegal immigration.</s>

en: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
kin: Minisiteri ishinzwe umutekano mu gihugu cya Amerika ntabwo yahise isubiza icyifuzo cyo gutanga ibisobanuro.
mt0: <pad> The U.S. Department of Homeland Security did not respond immediately to a request for comment.</s>

en: Until last week, Mexico only agreed to take Guatemalans, Hondurans and El Salvadorans — in addition to Mexicans — under Title 42 authority. Other nationalities are subject to Title 42 but costs, strained diplomatic ties and other considerations often make it difficult to send them back to their home countries.
kin: Kugeza mu cyumweru gishize, Mexico yemeye gufata Guatemala, Hondurans na El Salvadorans - usibye Abanyamegizike - ku butegetsi bwa 42. Abandi benegihugu bagengwa na Umutwe wa 42 ariko ikiguzi, umubano wububanyi n’ububanyi n’ibindi bitekerezo akenshi biragoye kubasubiza mu bihugu byabo.
mt0: <pad> Since last week, Mexico has agreed to take in Guatemala, Hondurans and El Salvadorans - except for Mexicans - under Article 42. Other nationals are subject to Article 42, but the cost, diplomatic relations and other factors often make it difficult to return them to their homeland.</s>

en: It's next to impossible for the U.S. to expel migrants to Cuba or Nicaragua because of poor relations with those governments.
kin: Bikurikira ntibishoboka ko Amerika yirukana abimukira muri Cuba cyangwa Nikaragwa kubera umubano mubi na guverinoma.
mt0: <pad> Next, it is not possible for the United States to deport migrants from Cuba or Nicaragua because of poor relations with the governments.</s>

en: That has posed a challenge for the Biden administration as more people from those countries seek haven in the United States.
kin: Ibyo byateje ikibazo ubuyobozi bwa Biden mugihe abantu benshi baturuka muri ibyo bihugu bashaka ubuhungiro muri Amerika.
mt0: <pad> That put a problem for Biden's administration as many people from those countries sought asylum in the United States.</s>

en: Cubans were stopped by U.S. authorities more than 32,000 times on the Mexican border in March, double the number in February and more than five times October's count, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Nicaragua eased travel restrictions from Cuba in November, making it easier for Cubans to continue by land to the U.S. border. Most enter the U.S. in or near Yuma, Arizona, and Del Rio, Texas.
kin: Nk’uko byatangajwe na gasutamo ya Leta zunze ubumwe za Amerika, ngo abanya Cuba bahagaritswe n'abayobozi b'Abanyamerika inshuro zirenga 32.000 ku mupaka wa Mexico, bakubye kabiri muri Gashyantare ndetse bakubye inshuro zirenga eshanu Ukwakira. Nikaragwa yorohereje imbogamizi z’ingendo ziva muri Cuba mu Gushyingo, byorohereza Abanyakanada gukomeza ku butaka kugera ku mupaka wa Amerika. Benshi binjira muri Amerika cyangwa hafi ya Yuma, Arizona, na Del Rio, Texas.
mt0: <pad> According to the United States Customs Service, Cubans were detained by U.S. officials over 32,000 times at the Mexican border, up two-thirds in February and five-quarters in October. Nicaragua eased entry requirements for Cubans in November, allowing Canadians to continue on land towards the American border. Most of them enter into the United States or near Yuma, Arizona, and Del Rio, Texas.</s>

en: Nicaraguans were stopped more than 16,000 times in March, more than double September's level. The vast majority enter in South Texas.
kin: Muri Werurwe, Nikaragwa yahagaritswe inshuro zirenga 16.000, irenga inshuro ebyiri Nzeri. Umubare munini winjira muri Texas yepfo.
mt0: <pad> In March, Nicaragua was detained over 16.000 times, more than double in September. Most of it came into South Texas.</s>

en: Lifting Title 42 has proved controversial as midterm elections near, even for Biden's Democratic Party, amid concerns that the U.S. is unprepared for an anticipated increase in migrants seeking asylum. Authorities stopped migrants more than 221,000 times in March, the highest mark in 22 years.
kin: Kuzamura Umutwe wa 42 byagaragaye ko bitavugwaho rumwe nk’amatora yo hagati, ndetse no mu ishyaka rya demokarasi rya Biden, mu gihe hari impungenge z’uko Amerika ititeguye kwiyongera kw’abimukira bashaka ubuhungiro. Muri Werurwe, abategetsi bahagaritse abimukira inshuro zirenga 221.000, kikaba aricyo kintu kinini mu myaka 22.
mt0: <pad> The raising of Article 42 has been widely criticized as a midterm election, even within Biden's Democratic Party, as concerns grow about the increasing number of refugees. In March, authorities detained more than 221.000 asylum seekers, the biggest number in years.</s>

en: The White House and Homeland Security Department have publicly stood behind the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's decision to end the measure because it could no longer be justified on grounds of protecting public health.
kin: Ishami ry’umutekano n’umutekano mu gihugu ryashyigikiye ku mugaragaro icyemezo cy’ikigo gishinzwe kurwanya no gukumira indwara cyo guhagarika iki cyemezo kuko kitagishoboye kuba gifite ishingiro kubera kurengera ubuzima rusange.
mt0: <pad> The Department of Health and Safety in the National Security and Security Committee has supported the decision of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to suspend this measure as it cannot be justified for the protection of public health.</s>

en: But the practice of expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans runs counter to the administration's public statements that it was phasing out use of the pandemic powers to prepare for May 23.
kin: Ariko imyitozo yo kwirukana abanya Cuba na Nikaragwa irahabanye n’ubuyobozi bwatangaje ko bwagiye bukuraho imbaraga z’icyorezo kugira ngo bitegure ku ya 23 Gicurasi.
mt0: <pad> But the preparations for deporting Cubans and Nicaraguans are in conflict with the government, which said it had removed emergency forces to prepare for May 23.</s>

en: The U.S. has expelled migrants more than 1.8 million times under Title 42 authority since March 2020, effectively overriding rights to seek asylum under U.S. law and international treaty. In doing so, migrants are not subject to immigration law, which include rights to seek protection from persecution at home.
kin: Kuva muri Werurwe 2020, Amerika yirukanye abimukira inshuro zirenga miliyoni 1.8 ku butegetsi bwa Umutwe wa 42, bivuguruza uburenganzira bwo gusaba ubuhungiro hakurikijwe amategeko ya Amerika n'amasezerano mpuzamahanga. Mu kubikora, abimukira ntibagengwa n'amategeko y’abinjira, akubiyemo uburenganzira bwo kurindwa ibitotezo mu ngo.
mt0: <pad> Since March 2020, the United States has deported more than 1.8 million migrants under Section 42, violating the right to refuge under American law and international treaties. In doing so, migrants are not subject to immigration laws, including the right to be free from domestic harassment.</s>

en: The administration said in court filings that it began processing more Central American adults under immigration laws after the CDC's announcement on April 1. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that it couldn't start unwinding Title 42 while it was still in effect.
kin: Ubuyobozi bwatangaje mu rukiko ko bwatangiye gutunganya abantu benshi bakuze bo muri Amerika yo Hagati bakurikiza amategeko y’abinjira nyuma y’uko CDC ibitangaza ku ya 1 Mata.
mt0: <pad> The agency announced in court that it had begun processing many elderly Central Americans who followed the immigration rules after the CDC announced on April 1.</s>

en: U.S. District Judge Robert Summerhays strongly criticized the CDC's decision, suggesting he would try to keep Title 42 in effect after May 23. A hearing is scheduled May 13 for oral arguments.
kin: Umucamanza w'akarere ka Amerika, Robert Summerhays, yanenze cyane icyemezo cya CDC, avuga ko azagerageza gukomeza Umutwe wa 42 nyuma y'itariki ya 23 Gicurasi.
mt0: <pad> Robert Summerhays, a district judge in the United States, has strongly criticized the CDC's decision, saying that he will try to extend Section 42 after May 23.</s>

en: Marisa Limon, senior director of advocacy and planning at the Hope Border Institute, said advocates began learning about expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans from El Paso on Monday and later confirmed the new practice with U.S. officials.
kin: Umuyobozi mukuru ushinzwe ubuvugizi n’igenamigambi mu kigo cya Hope Border, Marisa Limon, yavuze ko abunganizi batangiye kwiga ibijyanye no kwirukana Abanyakanani na Nikaragwa muri El Paso ku wa mbere nyuma baza kwemeza imikorere mishya hamwe n’abayobozi ba Amerika.
mt0: <pad> The director of lobbying and planning at Hope Border, Marisa Limon, said they began studying the removal of Mexicans and Nicaraguans from El Paso on Monday and will confirm the new procedure with U.S. authorities later.</s>

en: Limon said the administration is "trying to get every last bit out of Title 42" before it expires.
kin: Limon yavuze ko ubuyobozi "bugerageza gukuramo buri kintu cya nyuma mu mutwe wa 42" kitararangira.
mt0: <pad> Limon said the authorities were "trying to remove every last thing from the 42nd head" before the end of the season.</s>

en: She called it "sobering" but consistent with the administration's efforts to have other countries in the Western hemisphere take more responsibility for hosting people fleeing their homes.
kin: Yayise "gutekereza" ariko ahuza n'imbaraga z'ubuyobozi kugira ngo ibindi bihugu byo mu gice cy'iburengerazuba bigire uruhare runini mu kwakira abantu bahunga ingo zabo.
mt0: <pad> He called it "thinking" but he also linked it with political power to get other western countries to play a bigger role in accepting refugees.</s>

en: Mexico Relocates Migrant Camp; Haitians Appear at Border
kin: Mexico yimuye inkambi y'abimukira; Abanyahayitiya bagaragara kumupaka
mt0: <pad> Mexico moved the refugee camp; Ethiopians were seen on the video</s>

en: Mexican authorities said Tuesday they have relocated a migrant camp that sprung up in a park in the border city of Reynosa, moving about 2,000 people from Central America and Haiti to a shelter in the city, across the border from McAllen, Texas.
kin: Ku wa kabiri, abategetsi ba Mexico bavuze ko bimuye inkambi y’abimukira yavukiye muri parike iri mu mujyi wa Reynosa uhana imbibi, yimura abantu bagera ku 2000 bava muri Amerika yo Hagati na Haiti mu buhungiro mu mujyi, hakurya y’umupaka na McAllen, muri Texas.
mt0: <pad> On Tuesday, Mexican authorities said they had relocated the migrant camp that was established in a park in the border town of Reynosa, moving about 2,000 people from Central America and Haiti to a refugee camp in McAllen, Texas.</s>

en: The camp of migrants mainly from Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Haiti sprung up after U.S. officials, citing the pandemic, invoked a health rule that denies migrants a chance to seek asylum.
kin: Inkambi y'abimukira ahanini baturutse muri Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras na Haiti imaze kuvuka nyuma yuko abayobozi ba Amerika, bavuga ko iki cyorezo, basabye itegeko ry’ubuzima ryanga abimukira amahirwe yo gusaba ubuhungiro.
mt0: <pad> The refugee camp, which is mainly from Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Haiti, has been established after U.S. officials, claiming the disease, called for a health law that denied asylum-seekers the chance to ask for asylum.</s>

en: Mexico's National Immigration Institute said the migrants were taken around midnight Monday to the shelter, which it said will have better hygiene and food services.
kin: Ikigo cy'igihugu gishinzwe abinjira n'abasohoka muri Mexico cyatangaje ko abimukira bajyanywe mu gicuku cyo ku wa mbere bakajya mu buhungiro, buvuga ko buzagira isuku na serivisi nziza.
mt0: <pad> The National Immigration and Customs Administration of Mexico announced that the refugees were transported to a camp on Monday night, claiming it will have cleanliness and good services.</s>

en: But on Monday, people in another border city, Nuevo Laredo, said hundreds of migrants, mainly Haitians, have streamed into that city, which is across the border from Laredo, Texas
kin: Ariko ku wa mbere, abantu bo mu wundi mujyi uhana imbibi, Nuevo Laredo, bavuze ko abimukira babarirwa mu magana, cyane cyane Abanyahayiti, binjiye muri uwo mujyi, uhana imbibi na Laredo, muri Texas.
mt0: <pad> But on Monday, people from another border town, Nuevo Laredo, said that about 100 migrants, mostly Haitians, had entered the city, which is bordering Laredo, in Texas.</s>

en: The rush apparently started after the U.S. began processing some asylum-seekers there.
kin: Kwihuta bigaragara ko byatangiye nyuma yuko Amerika itangiye gutunganya bamwe mubasaba ubuhungiro.
mt0: <pad> The increase seems to have begun after the United States began to house some of the asylum-seekers.</s>

en: The Catholic bishop of Nuevo Laredo said Monday that migrant shelters there are overcrowded, with some migrants sleeping outside in tents.
kin: Umwepiskopi gatolika wa Nuevo Laredo yavuze ku wa mbere ko aho abimukira bahurira huzuye, aho abimukira bamwe baryama hanze mu mahema.
mt0: <pad> The Catholic bishop of Nuevo Laredo said Monday that the refugee camp was full, with some refugees sleeping in tents outside.</s>

en: Bishop Enrique Sánchez Martínez said migrants started streaming into Nuevo Laredo in late April, though the city isn't usually popular among migrants, in part because it is dominated by the violent Northeast drug cartel.
kin: Musenyeri Enrique Sánchez Martínez yavuze ko abimukira batangiye kwinjira muri Nuevo Laredo mu mpera za Mata, nubwo uyu mujyi udakunzwe cyane n'abimukira, kubera ko wiganjemo amakarito y’ibiyobyabwenge yo mu majyaruguru y'uburasirazuba.
mt0: <pad> The bishop Enrique Sánchez Martínez said the migrant arrivals began in Nuevo Laredo in late May, even though the city is not popular with migrants, because it is a hub of drug cartels from the northeast.</s>

en: "It is new for us because this is the last place they come, due to the conditions of our border, of our city, which are sometimes adverse for migrants," the bishop said.
kin: Umwepiskopi yagize ati: "Ni shyashya kuri twe kuko aha niho hantu ha nyuma baza, bitewe n'imipaka yacu, umujyi wacu, rimwe na rimwe bikaba bibi ku bimukira."
mt0: <pad> The bishop said: "It's new for us because this is the last place they come, because of our borders, our city, sometimes it's bad for refugees."</s>

en: "But since they opened the door in the United States to asylum requests, a lot of them came in large groups."
kin: "Ariko kuva bafungura umuryango muri Amerika gusaba ubuhunzi, benshi muri bo baza mu matsinda manini."
mt0: <pad> But since the door to asylum in America has been open, most of them have come in large groups.</s>

en: Marvin Ajic, the director of the Casa Nazareth shelter, said that around April 16, Mexican authorities notified the shelters that the United States would resume processing asylum claims for humanitarian reasons.
kin: Umuyobozi w'ikigo cya Casa Nazareth, Marvin Ajic, yavuze ko ahagana ku ya 16 Mata, abategetsi ba Mexico bamenyesheje ubwo buhungiro ko Amerika izakomeza gutunganya ibirego by'ubuhunzi kubera impamvu z’ubutabazi.
mt0: <pad> Marvin Ajic, the director of Casa Nazareth, said that on April 16, Mexican authorities informed the refugee camp that the United States would continue to process asylum applications for humanitarian reasons.</s>

en: The U.S. had begun allowing more people in, especially Central American adults, to prepare for lifting Title 42 — a pandemic-era health rule that denies migrants a chance to enter the U.S. seek asylum — on May 23. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that the government could not unwind the rule before the end date.
kin: Ku ya 23 Gicurasi, Amerika yari yatangiye kwemerera abantu benshi, cyane cyane abakuze bo muri Amerika yo Hagati, kwitegura gukuraho Umutwe wa 42 - itegeko ry’ubuzima bwo mu gihe cy’icyorezo kibuza abimukira amahirwe yo kwinjira muri Amerika gusaba ubuhungiro - ku ya 23 Gicurasi. Ariko umucamanza wa federasiyo muri Louisiana yemeje icyumweru gishize ko guverinoma idashobora gukuraho iryo tegeko mbere yitariki yo kurangiriraho.
mt0: <pad> On May 23, the United States had begun to prepare many people, especially elderly Central Americans, for the removal of Article 42 - the pandemic health law that bars immigrants from entering the United States and applying for asylum - on May 23. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that the government could not remove the law before its end date.</s>

en: "The (Mexican) immigration officials organized things with the shelters, and the plan was to send people who had been waiting a long time, without any checks, basically anyone," Ajic said.
kin: Ajic yagize ati: "Abashinzwe abinjira n'abasohoka (Abanyamegizike) bateguye ibintu hamwe n'ubuhungiro, kandi gahunda yari iyo kohereza abantu bari bategereje igihe kirekire, nta sheki bafite, cyane cyane umuntu uwo ari we wese."
mt0: <pad> Ajic said: "The immigration department and the asylum seekers had arranged things, and the plan was to deport people who had been waiting for a long time, without a check, especially any person."</s>

en: That apparently drew the attention of other migrants, including Haitians.
kin: Ikigaragara ni uko ibyo byashimishije abandi bimukira, harimo n'Abanyahayiti.
mt0: <pad> It is clear that this attracted other migrants, including Haitians.</s>

en: In September, similar rumors sparked a rush by about 15,000 mostly Haitian refugees to the Texas border, where they camped under a bridge. U.S. officials began large scale deportations of Haitians while also allowing thousands to remain in the U.S.
kin: Muri Nzeri, ibihuha nk'ibyo byatumye abantu bagera ku 15.000 bihutira cyane cyane impunzi zo muri Hayiti kugera ku mupaka wa Texas, aho bakambitse munsi y'ikiraro. Abayobozi ba Amerika batangiye kwirukana Abanyahayiti benshi mu gihe banemerera ibihumbi kuguma muri Amerika
mt0: <pad> In September, such rumors prompted about 15,000 people, mostly Haitian refugees, to rush to the Texas border, where they camped under the bridge. U.S. authorities began deporting many Haitians while allowing thousands to stay in the United States.</s>

en: Ajic warned migrants against coming to the border, noting the risks. On Monday, Mexico's National Immigration Institute said that so far this year, it has pulled the bodies of 19 immigrants from the Rio Grande, also known as the Rio Bravo.
kin: Ajic yihanangirije abimukira kwirinda kuza ku mupaka, avuga ingaruka. Ku wa mbere, Ikigo cy’igihugu gishinzwe abinjira n’abasohoka muri Mexico cyavuze ko kugeza uyu mwaka, kimaze gukuramo imirambo y’abimukira 19 bava muri Rio Grande, izwi kandi ku izina rya Rio Bravo.
mt0: <pad> Ajic warned migrants not to cross the border, warning of the consequences.</s>

en: New US Rule Grants Automatic Work Permit Extensions to Noncitizens
kin: Amategeko mashya yo muri Amerika atanga uruhushya rwo gukora rwikora kubaturage
mt0: <pad> New U.S. law gives self-employed licenses to American citizens.</s>

en: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) announced Tuesday that it would automatically extend for 360 days the work permits of immigrants who applied to renew their work authorization amid the current backlog in processing times.
kin: Serivisi ishinzwe abenegihugu n’abinjira n’abasohoka muri Amerika (USCIS) yatangaje ku wa kabiri ko izahita yongerwa iminsi 360 uruhushya rwo gukora rw’abimukira basabye kuvugurura uruhushya rw’akazi mu gihe kiri inyuma mu gihe cyo gutunganya.
mt0: <pad> The USCIS announced Tuesday that it will automatically extend the work permits of immigrants who requested to extend their work permits in the future.</s>

en: The new notice expands on the 180-day extension USCIS announced in November. It is expected to prevent about 260,000 immigrants from losing their work permits in the next 18 months. It will also give the agency extra time to clear applicants waiting in line, the agency said in a statement.
kin: Amatangazo mashya yagutse ku iyongerwa ry'iminsi 180 USCIS yatangaje mu Gushyingo. Biteganijwe ko bizabuza abimukira bagera ku 260.000 gutakaza uruhushya rwo gukora mu mezi 18 ari imbere. Bizatanga kandi ikigo cy’inyongera cyo gukuraho abasaba gutegereza umurongo, nkuko byatangajwe n’ikigo.
mt0: <pad> The new announcements expanded the 180-day USCIS extension announced in November. It is expected to prevent up to 260,000 immigrants from losing their work permits in the next 18 months. It will also provide an additional mechanism to remove applicants from the wait list, the USCIS said.</s>

en: "This temporary rule will provide those noncitizens otherwise eligible for the automatic extension an opportunity to maintain employment and provide critical support for their families while avoiding further disruption for U.S. employers," USCIS Director Ur M. Jaddou said in a statement.
kin: Mu ijambo rye, Umuyobozi wa USCIS, Ur M. Jaddou, yagize ati: "Iri tegeko ry’agateganyo rizaha abo banyagihugu ubundi bemerewe kongererwa mu buryo bwikora amahirwe yo gukomeza akazi no gutanga inkunga ikomeye ku miryango yabo mu gihe birinda ko hajyaho ihungabana ku bakoresha ba Amerika."
mt0: <pad> In his statement, the Director of USCIS, Ur M. Jaddou, said: "This temporary law will give those citizens who were previously granted a work permit the chance to continue their work and provide a strong support to their families while preventing economic disruption to American employers."</s>

en: The extension, which takes effect Wednesday, aims to stabilize operations for U.S. employers and help people with pending employment authorizations who have a job and are working in the U.S.
kin: Iyongerekana ritangira gukurikizwa ku wa gatatu, rigamije guhuza ibikorwa ku bakoresha ba Amerika no gufasha abantu bafite uburenganzira bwo gutegereza bafite akazi kandi bakorera muri Amerika.
mt0: <pad> The amendment, which comes into effect on Wednesday, is intended to streamline procedures for American employers and help people with the right to wait who have a job and work in the United States.</s>

en: USCIS is the agency in charge of handling the nation's immigration paperwork. In recent years, it has struggled with backlogs, an issue made worse by the COVID-19 pandemic and budget shortfalls.
kin: USCIS nicyo kigo gishinzwe gukemura impapuro z’abinjira mu gihugu. Mu myaka yashize, yahanganye n'ibibazo bidasubirwaho, ikibazo cyarushijeho kuba icyorezo cya COVID-19 hamwe no kubura ingengo yimari.
mt0: <pad> USCIS is the agency that handles immigration. In the past years, it has faced unrepeatable problems, a problem that has worsened with the COVID-19 pandemic and lack of funding.</s>

en: In April, Jaddou told U.S. government officials during a congressional hearing that USCIS had 8.5 million pending immigration cases, including those seeking green cards and U.S. naturalization.
kin: Muri Mata, Jaddou yabwiye abayobozi ba leta zunze ubumwe z’Amerika mu gihe cy’iburanisha ry’inteko ishinga amategeko ko USCIS ifite miliyoni 8.5 zitegereje imanza z’abinjira n’abinjira, harimo n’abashaka amakarita y’icyatsi ndetse n’ubwenegihugu bwa Amerika.
mt0: <pad> In May, Jaddou told US officials during a congressional hearing that USCIS had 8.5 million applicants waiting for immigration and citizenship decisions, including applicants for green cards and U.S. citizenship.</s>

en: She said more than half of those pending cases were taking longer than the agency's normal processing times.
kin: Yavuze ko kimwe cya kabiri cy’izo manza zitarangizwa zafashe igihe kirenze igihe cy’ikigo gisanzwe.
mt0: <pad> He said that one-half of those unresolved cases took longer than normal court time.</s>

en: Asylum-seekers, immigrants adjusting their status to permanent residence and other noncitizens going through the U.S. immigration process are among the noncitizens affected by the latest work authorization extension.
kin: Abasaba ubuhungiro, abimukira bahindura status yabo gutura burundu hamwe nabandi banyagihugu banyura muri gahunda y’abinjira n’abanyamerika bari mu baturage badafite ingaruka ku iyongerwa ry’akazi riheruka.
mt0: <pad> Applicants for asylum, permanent residents and other citizens who pass through the Immigration and Naturalization Program are among the citizens who have not been affected by the recent job increase.</s>

en: The agency had reported that processing times for asylum applicants looking to renew work permits increased from seven months in 2017 to 11 months in 2021.
kin: Ikigo cyari cyatangaje ko igihe cyo gutunganya abasaba ubuhunzi bashaka kuvugurura impushya zo gukora cyiyongereye kuva ku mezi arindwi muri 2017 kigera ku mezi 11 muri 2021.
mt0: <pad> The agency had previously announced that the time for processing applications for asylum-seekers who want to extend their work permits had been extended from July 2017 to November 2021.</s>

en: In March, USCIS announced a program to reduce backlogs, including the expansion of premium processing for certain applications where applicants could pay a higher fee to expedite paperwork processing.
kin: Muri Werurwe, USCIS yatangaje gahunda yo kugabanya ibirarane, harimo no kwagura progaramu ya progaramu ya progaramu zimwe aho abasaba bashobora kwishyura amafaranga menshi kugirango byihutishe gutunganya impapuro.
mt0: <pad> In March, USCIS announced plans to reduce backlog, including expanding the program of some priority programs where applicants can pay a large fee to speed up processing documents.</s>

en: According to the USCIS, most of the announced changes simply restore options offered before the Trump administration's slowdown of USCIS processing and before the COVID-19 pandemic further slowed the agency's resources.
kin: Nk’uko USCIS ibigaragaza, impinduka nyinshi zatangajwe gusa zigarura gusa amahitamo yatanzwe mbere y’uko ubuyobozi bwa Trump butinda gutunganya USCIS ndetse na mbere y’icyorezo cya COVID-19 cyadindije umutungo w’ikigo.
mt0: <pad> As USCIS notes, most of the changes announced are only a renewal of decisions made before Trump's administration delayed reforming USCIS and before the COVID-19 pandemic that affected the agency's finances.</s>

en: "For several years, USCIS has been in a precarious financial situation that has impaired the efficient completion of caseloads.
kin: Hashize imyaka itari mike, USCIS ihura n'ikibazo cy'ubukungu cyabujije kurangiza neza amakarito.
mt0: <pad> For many years, USCIS has been struggling with an economic problem that has prevented them from finishing the applications on time.</s>

en: The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated these challenges in 2020, in addition to a hiring freeze and furlough threat leading to workforce attrition and severely reduced capacity.
kin: Icyorezo cya COVID-19 cyakajije umurego muri 2020, hiyongereyeho gukonjesha akazi no gukangisha abantu bigatuma abakozi binjira kandi bikagabanya cyane ubushobozi.
mt0: <pad> The COVID-19 pandemic intensified in 2020, with a rise in job shortages and staff reassignments that forced employees to enter and severely limit their capabilities.</s>

en: In 2021, before USCIS could recover from these fiscal and operational impacts, there was a sudden and dramatic increase in EAD (Employment Authorization Document) initial and renewal filings," according to the USCIS statement.
kin: Mu 2021, mbere yuko USCIS isubirana izo ngaruka z’imari n’ibikorwa, habaye ubwiyongere butunguranye kandi butangaje muri EAD (Impapuro zemeza akazi) inyandiko zambere kandi zivugururwa , nk'uko byatangajwe na USCIS.
mt0: <pad> In 2021, before USCIS reviewed those financial and operational impacts, there was a sudden and unexpected increase in the number of EAD (Employment Authorization Documents) applications for both initial and renewed applications, as announced by USCIS.</s>

en: The USCIS historically has been underfunded because most of the agency's funding comes from application fees that have stalled at $5 billion a year since 2019.
kin: Amateka ya USCIS yatewe inkunga kubera ko inkunga nyinshi z’ikigo zituruka ku mafaranga yo gusaba yahagaze kuri miliyari 5 z'amadolari ku mwaka kuva 2019.
mt0: <pad> The USCIS' history has been supported because the majority of its funding comes from application fees and the agency's budget has been reduced to $5 billion per year since 2009.</s>

en: What Is the US-Launched 'Uniting for Ukraine' Program?
kin: Niki Gahunda yatangijwe na Amerika 'Guhuriza hamwe muri Ukraine'?
mt0: <pad> What is the American-led 'Operation in Ukraine'?</s>

en: U.S. President Joe Biden recently announced the Uniting for Ukraine program, which aims to streamline the process for Ukrainians who have fled their country and are seeking safety in the United States.
kin: Perezida wa Leta zunze ubumwe za Amerika, Joe Biden, aherutse gutangaza gahunda y’ubumwe bwa Ukraine, igamije koroshya inzira ku Banya Ukraine bahunze igihugu cyabo kandi bashaka umutekano muri Amerika.
mt0: <pad> President of the United States, Joe Biden, has recently announced the U.S.-Ukraine unity plan, which is intended to ease the path for refugees from Ukraine who fled their country and seek security in the United States.</s>

en: The new program, which took effect Monday, will complement existing legal pathways available to those fleeing Russian aggression due to the ongoing Russia-Ukraine crisis, Biden administration officials said.
kin: Abayobozi b'ubuyobozi bwa Biden bavuze ko iyi gahunda nshya yatangiye gukurikizwa ku wa mbere, izuzuza inzira zemewe n'amategeko zihari ku bahunga igitero cy'Uburusiya kubera ikibazo cy'Uburusiya na Ukraine gikomeje.
mt0: <pad> The new program, which began on Monday, will fill in the legal paths available to refugees fleeing Russian aggression because of the continuing conflict between Russia and Ukraine.</s>

en: "The U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) will continue to provide relief to the Ukrainian people, while supporting our European allies who have shouldered so much as the result of Russia's brutal invasion of Ukraine," Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas said in a statement to reporters on April 21.
kin: Umunyamabanga wa Leta ushinzwe umutekano mu gihugu, Alejandro Mayorkas, yagize ati: "Minisiteri ishinzwe umutekano mu gihugu cya Amerika (DHS) izakomeza gutanga ubutabazi ku baturage ba Ukraine, mu gihe ishyigikiye ibihugu byacu by’i Burayi bitwaje intwaro nyinshi bitewe n’uko Uburusiya bwateye muri Ukraine bunyamaswa." itangazo ku banyamakuru ku ya 21 Mata.
mt0: <pad> The Secretary of State for National Security, Alejandro Mayorkas, said: "The U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) will continue to provide aid to the people of Ukraine, while it supports our European allies with heavy weapons because Russia has invaded Ukraine indiscriminately."</s>

en: What is Uniting for Ukraine?
kin: Guhuza Ukraine ni iki?
mt0: <pad> What is Ukraine?</s>

en: The program allows U.S. citizens and residents to sponsor Ukrainian refugees under different immigration statuses. The online portal, open to potential sponsors or organizations, is accepting applications and has received more than 4,000 requests so far, CNN reported.
kin: Porogaramu yemerera abanyamerika n’abaturage gutera inkunga impunzi zo muri Ukraine mu bihe bitandukanye by’abinjira. CNN yatangaje ko umuyoboro wa interineti ufunguye abaterankunga cyangwa imiryango, ushobora kwakira ibyifuzo kandi umaze kwakira ibyifuzo birenga 4000 kugeza ubu.
mt0: <pad> The program allows Americans and citizens to support refugees from Ukraine in different immigration phases. CNN reported that an open web site for donors or families, can accept request and has received over 4000 request so far.</s>

en: Who qualifies under the program? Ukrainians, or an immediate family member of a Ukrainian citizen. They must have a U.S. sponsor and have been a resident of Ukraine as of February 11.
kin: Ninde wujuje ibisabwa muri gahunda? Abanya Ukraine, cyangwa umuryango wa hafi wumuturage wa Ukraine. Bagomba kugira umuterankunga w’Amerika kandi bakaba batuye muri Ukraine guhera ku ya 11 Gashyantare.
mt0: <pad> Who meets the requirements of the program? Ukrainians, or relatives of a Ukrainian citizen. They must have an American sponsor and live in Ukraine since February 11.</s>

en: What are the requirements? They must pass security checks — including a fingerprint and an FBI name check and biographic and biometric screening — and meet public health requirements, such as having the proper vaccinations, before entering the U.S.
kin: Ni ibihe bisabwa? Bagomba gutsinda igenzura ry'umutekano - harimo igikumwe no kugenzura izina rya FBI no gusuzuma biografiya na biometrike - kandi bujuje ibyangombwa byubuzima rusange, nko kugira inkingo zikwiye, mbere yo kwinjira muri Amerika
mt0: <pad> What are the requirements? They must pass security checks - including fingerprinting and FBI name checks and biometrics and biography - and meet general health requirements, such as having a valid immunization, before entering the program.</s>

en: Those approved will be allowed to travel to the U.S., be considered for humanitarian parole on a case-by-case basis, stay in the country for two years, and apply for work permits.
kin: Abemerewe bazemererwa kujya muri Amerika, bafatwe nk'agateganyo ku buntu, bagume mu gihugu imyaka ibiri, kandi basabe uruhushya rwo gukora.
mt0: <pad> The applicants will be allowed to come to the United States, be taken in for a short period of time at no cost, stay in the country for two years, and ask for a work permit.</s>

en: "The United States strongly encourages Ukrainians seeking refuge in the United States who do not have and are not eligible for a visa to seek entry via Uniting for Ukraine from Europe.
kin: Amerika irashishikariza cyane Abanya Ukraine bashaka ubuhungiro muri Amerika badafite kandi batemerewe kubona viza yo kwinjira binyuze muri Uniting for Ukraine bava i Burayi.
mt0: <pad> The United States encourages Ukraine refugees who do not have or are denied a visa to enter the United States through the United for Ukraine from Europe to apply for asylum in the United States.</s>

en: This will be the safest and most efficient way to pursue temporary refuge in the United States," a DHS statement said.
kin: Ubu ni bwo buryo bwizewe kandi bunoze bwo guhungira by'agateganyo muri Amerika. Ibihugu , nk'uko byatangajwe na DHS.
mt0: <pad> This is the safest and most secure way to temporarily enter the United States of America, as announced by the DHS.</s>

en: Who qualifies as a sponsor?
kin: Ninde wujuje ibisabwa nk'umuterankunga?
mt0: <pad> Who meets the requirements for a sponsor?</s>

en: U.S. citizens and other residents who hold lawful status in the United States or who are beneficiaries of Deferred Enforced Departure, Temporary Protected Status, or Deferred Action, among others.
kin: Abanyamerika hamwe nabandi baturage bafite ubuzima gatozi muri Reta zunzubumwe zamerika cyangwa abagenerwabikorwa bagenda batinze, Imiterere irinzwe byigihe gito, cyangwa ibikorwa byadindijwe, nibindi.
mt0: <pad> Americans and other permanent residents in the United States or their employers who are delayed, unexpected situations, or delayed projects, etc.</s>

en: Sponsors will be required to prove they can financially support the refugee while they are in the U.S. They also need to pass security and background vetting "to protect against exploitation and abuse." The Ukrainian applicant will receive authorization only after everything is verified, including that the sponsor has the means to support them while they are in the U.S.
kin: Abaterankunga bazasabwa kwerekana ko bashobora gutera inkunga impunzi mu gihe bari muri Amerika Bakeneye kandi kunyura mu mutekano no kugenzura "kurinda ihohoterwa no guhohoterwa." Usaba ukomoka muri Ukraine azahabwa uruhushya nyuma yuko byose bigenzuwe, harimo ko umuterankunga afite uburyo bwo kubatera inkunga mugihe bari muri Amerika
mt0: <pad> Sponsors will be asked to show they can support refugees while they are in the United States. They will also need to pass security and checks "to prevent harassment and harassment." The applicants from Ukraine will be granted a permit after all of the requirements are met, including that the sponsor has funds to support them while they are in the United States.</s>

en: Who is not eligible for parole under the program?
kin: Ninde utemerewe kurekurwa muri gahunda?
mt0: <pad> Who is not allowed to be released from the program?</s>

en: Ukrainian citizens already in the U.S. are not eligible for parole under Uniting for Ukraine.
kin: Abenegihugu ba Ukraine basanzwe muri Amerika ntibemerewe kurekurwa muri Uniting for Ukraine.
mt0: <pad> Ukraine citizens living in the United States were not allowed to be freed from Uniting for Ukraine.</s>

en: However, they can apply for Temporary Protected Status, which is another form of humanitarian relief that allows people to legally stay and work in the U.S.
kin: Ariko, barashobora gusaba Imiterere irinzwe byigihe gito, nubundi buryo bwo gutabara imbabare butuma abantu bagumaho kandi bakorera muri Amerika.
mt0: <pad> But they can request temporary employment, and other forms of relief that allow people to stay and work in America.</s>

en: What about those arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border?
kin: Tuvuge iki ku bashitse ku mupaka wa Amerika na Mexico?
mt0: <pad> What can we say about the migrants who have arrived at the US-Mexico border?</s>

en: Citing safety issues, U.S. officials have urged Ukrainians not to travel to Mexico in hopes of entering the United States. In addition, U.S. Customs and Border Protection has no place to hold them while they go through the Uniting for Ukraine vetting process.
kin: Abayobozi ba Leta zunze ubumwe za Amerika basabye ibibazo by’umutekano, basabye abanya Ukraine kutajya muri Mexico bizeye kwinjira muri Amerika. Byongeye kandi, gasutamo yo muri Amerika no kurinda imipaka nta hantu na hamwe yabifata mu gihe banyuze muri gahunda yo gusuzuma Ukraine.
mt0: <pad> US officials raised security concerns, and urged Ukrainians not to go to Mexico hoping to enter the United States. In addition, U.S. customs and border guards did not take any steps to check them while they passed through the inspection process in Ukraine.</s>

en: Since Uniting for Ukraine's launch on Monday, Ukrainians who arrive at U.S. ports of entry without a valid visa or without preauthorization to travel to the United States through the Uniting for Ukraine program will be denied entry and told to apply to the program.
kin: Kuva Guhuriza hamwe kwa Ukraine ku wa mbere, Abanya-Ukraine bageze ku byambu by’Amerika binjira nta viza yemewe cyangwa batabiherewe uburenganzira bwo kujya muri Amerika binyuze muri gahunda y’ubumwe bwa Ukraine bazangirwa kwinjira kandi babwirwa gusaba iyo gahunda.
mt0: <pad> Since the integration of Ukraine on Monday, Ukrainians arriving at US ports without a valid visa or without being granted entry through the United States through the Ukraine Integration Program will be refused entry and told to request the program.</s>

en: Biden officials hope this will curb the number of Ukrainian migrants seeking humanitarian parole along the border.
kin: Abayobozi ba Biden bizeye ko ibyo bizagabanya umubare w’abimukira bo muri Ukraine bashaka gufungurwa by’umupaka.
mt0: <pad> Biden officials hope that this will reduce the number of Ukrainian refugees who want to cross the border.</s>

en: Those at the border must apply under the rules of Uniting for Ukraine, meaning they must have a qualifying sponsor or a non-government agency willing to sponsor them in the U.S. for up to two years. And they need to have all required vaccinations and pass background checks.
kin: Abari ku mipaka bagomba gusaba hakurikijwe amategeko agenga ubumwe bwa Ukraine, bivuze ko bagomba kugira umuterankunga wujuje ibyangombwa cyangwa ikigo kitegamiye kuri leta cyifuza kubatera inkunga muri Amerika mugihe cyimyaka ibiri. Kandi bakeneye kugira inkingo zose zisabwa no gutsinda igenzura.
mt0: <pad> Border migrants must apply under the Ukraine reunification law, meaning they must have a qualified sponsor or non-governmental organization that wants to support them in the United States for two years. They also need to have all insurance and pass the checks.</s>

en: The Biden administration announced the private sponsorship initiative as another way the U.S. hopes to achieve President Biden's commitment to welcome up to 100,000 Ukrainians displaced by the Russian military invasion.
kin: Ubuyobozi bwa Biden bwatangaje gahunda yo gutera inkunga abikorera ku giti cyabo nk'ubundi buryo Amerika yizeye kuzagera ku cyemezo cya Perezida Biden cyo kwakira abanya Ukraine bagera ku 100.000 bavanywe mu byabo n’igitero cy’ingabo z’Uburusiya.
mt0: <pad> The Biden administration announced plans to support private sector companies as another way the United States hopes to achieve President Biden's decision to accept nearly 100, 000 Ukrainians displaced by the Russian invasion.</s>

en: As of Thursday, almost 5.4 million refugees have since left Ukraine, according to U.N. data.
kin: Nk’uko amakuru ya Amerika abitangaza, kugeza ku wa kane, impunzi zigera kuri miliyoni 5.4 zimaze kuva muri Ukraine.
mt0: <pad> As the U.S. reports, as of Thursday, 5.4 million refugees have fled Ukraine.</s>

en: Report: Rwanda Should Ease Restrictions On 2003 National Elections - 2001-10-15
kin: Raporo: U Rwanda rukwiye koroshya imbogamizi ku matora y’igihugu 2003 - 2001-10-15
mt0: <pad> Report: Rwanda should ease obstacles to the 2003 national election</s>

en: In 2003 Rwanda will hold its first national elections since the 1994 genocide. A new report says the government of Rwanda needs to relax its control over public life if the polls are to have any credibility.
kin: Mu 2003 u Rwanda ruzakora amatora yambere y’igihugu kuva jenoside yo mu 1994. Raporo nshya ivuga ko guverinoma y'u Rwanda ikeneye koroshya ubuzima bw’abaturage niba amatora agomba kwizerwa.
mt0: <pad> In 2003 Rwanda will hold its first national election since the 1994 Genocide. A new report says that the government of Rwanda needs to ease the lives of the people if it is to be credible.</s>

en: There was relief when the Rwandan Patriotic Front seized power in Rwanda in 1994, ending the genocide in which about 800,000 minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus were killed.
kin: Habayeho ihumure igihe urugamba rwo gukunda igihugu rw’u Rwanda rwafataga ubutegetsi mu Rwanda mu 1994, rukarangiza itsembabwoko ryahitanye Abatutsi bagera ku 800.000 n'Abahutu bashyira mu gaciro.
mt0: <pad> There was peace when the Rwandan National Salvation War took power in 1994, ending the atrocities that killed about 800,000 Tutsis and Hutus who valued the values of the genocide.</s>

en: The new military government promised to restore democracy to Rwanda via elections in 2003.
kin: Guverinoma nshya y’ingabo yasezeranije kugarura demokarasi mu Rwanda binyuze mu matora yo mu 2003.
mt0: <pad> The new military government promised to bring back democracy in Rwanda through the 2003 elections.</s>

en: That process began in March this year, with district elections.
kin: Iyo nzira yatangiye muri Werurwe uyu mwaka, hamwe n’amatora y’akarere.
mt0: <pad> The process started in March this year, with the local election.</s>

en: Senior analyst Francois Grignon, of the International Crisis Group, a Brussels-based policy research organization, says he was disappointed with the district poll. Mr. Grignon says the process was so tightly controlled that he maintains no genuine opposition candidates were allowed to stand.
kin: Umusesenguzi mukuru Francois Grignon, wo mu itsinda mpuzamahanga rishinzwe ibibazo bya politiki iherereye i Buruseli, avuga ko yatengushye amatora y'akarere. Bwana Grignon avuga ko inzira yagenzuwe cyane ku buryo akomeza avuga ko nta bakandida nyabo batavuga rumwe n’ubutegetsi bari bemerewe guhagarara.
mt0: <pad> The chief analyst Francois Grignon, of the International Institute for Political Studies in Brussels, said that the election process was so heavily controlled that no real opposition candidates were allowed to stand.</s>

en: "There was a screening and there was a preparation of the elections, which did not allow other candidates than those who had been rubber-stamped by the government to actually contest, especially for the executive positions within the local authorities," he says. "If consensual democracy means that the political debate is actually handled before the electoral contest in such a way that it does not lead to a real competition then there is no democracy at all."
kin: Agira ati: "Habayeho isuzuma kandi hategurwa amatora, atemerera abandi bakandida uretse abashyizweho kashe na guverinoma guhatanira koko, cyane cyane ku myanya y'ubuyobozi mu nzego z'ibanze". "Niba demokarasi yumvikanyweho bivuze ko impaka za politiki zikemurwa mbere y'amarushanwa y'amatora ku buryo bitatuma habaho amarushanwa nyayo, nta demokarasi ihari."
mt0: <pad> He said: "There was a scrutiny and preparation of the election, which did not allow other applicants except those approved by the government to compete really, especially for the local authority posts." "If consensus democracy means that political disputes are resolved before the election so that there is no real competition, there is no true democracy."</s>

en: In a new report, titled Consensual Democracy in Post Genocide Rwanda, the International Crisis Group urges the international community to pressure Rwanda's government to liberalize political activity.
kin: Muri raporo nshya yiswe Demokarasi ihuriweho na Jenoside nyuma y’itsembabwoko mu Rwanda, Itsinda mpuzamahanga rishinzwe ibibazo rirasaba amahanga guhatira leta y’u Rwanda kwishyira ukizana mu bikorwa bya politiki.
mt0: <pad> In its new report titled Shared Democracy and Genocide after the Genocide in Rwanda, the International Crisis Group urges international pressure on the Rwandan government to pursue self-rule in political activities.</s>

en: The report notes that the military dominates public life and there is little open criticism of the government, either in the media or by opposition figures. The Rwanda government argues that allowing a range of opinions would be dangerous in a country struggling to come to terms with its bloody past.
kin: Raporo ivuga ko igisirikare cyiganje mu buzima rusange kandi ko nta kunegura guverinoma, haba mu bitangazamakuru cyangwa ku bantu batavuga rumwe n’ubutegetsi. Guverinoma y'u Rwanda ivuga ko kwemerera ibitekerezo bitandukanye byaba ari akaga mu gihugu kirwanira kumvikana na kahise kayo k'amaraso.
mt0: <pad> The report says that the military is overly powerful in public life and that there is no criticism of the government, either in the media or by people who disagree with the government. The Rwandan government says allowing different views would be dangerous in a country which is trying to understand its bloody past.</s>

en: But Mr. Grignon says dissent is simply being driven underground or outside Rwanda's borders.
kin: Ariko Bwana Grignon avuga ko abatavuga rumwe na leta bayoborwa mu nsi cyangwa hanze y’umupaka w’u Rwanda.
mt0: <pad> But Mr Grignon says that dissidents are being held either within or outside the Rwandan border.</s>

en: "Opponents to the regime have to flee the country or to join in rebel movements outside the country or in the Congo and no chance to express a different view," he says. "All the good policies that the government has been implementing - including the organization of the elections, national elections, presidential and parliamentary, in 2003 - will lack the credibility because they were not implemented in an environment that actually allowed a fair contest to take place," he says.
kin: Agira ati: "Abatavuga rumwe n'ubutegetsi bagomba guhunga igihugu cyangwa kujya mu myigaragambyo y'inyeshyamba hanze y'igihugu cyangwa muri Kongo kandi nta mahirwe yo kuvuga ukundi." "Politiki nziza zose guverinoma yashyize mu bikorwa - harimo gutegura amatora, amatora y’igihugu, perezida ndetse n’inteko ishinga amategeko, mu 2003 - ntizizigirirwa icyizere kuko zitashyizwe mu bikorwa byemerera amarushanwa akwiye. , ".
mt0: <pad> He said: "Opponents of the government must flee the country or join rebel demonstrations outside the country or in the Republic of the Congo and there is no chance for them to speak again." "All good policies that the government has implemented - including election preparation, national elections, president and parliamentary elections, 2003 - will not be trusted because they have not been put into practice to allow fair competition.</s>

en: Mr. Grignon says greater freedom of expression would strengthen Rwanda's reconciliation process and enhance its chances of a peaceful future.
kin: Bwana Grignon avuga ko ubwisanzure mu gutanga ibitekerezo bwashimangira inzira y'ubwiyunge y'u Rwanda kandi bikongerera amahirwe y'ejo hazaza.
mt0: <pad> Mr Grignon said that the freedom of expression strengthened the path of reconciliation in Rwanda and boosted the prospects for the future.</s>

en: He says the international community's involvement in reconstruction projects gives it the leverage to make this plain to the Rwandan government.
kin: Avuga ko uruhare mpuzamahanga mu mishinga yo kwiyubaka rutanga imbaraga zo kugeza iki kibazo kuri guverinoma y'u Rwanda.
mt0: <pad> He says that the international role in the reconstruction projects gives him the strength to bring this issue to the Rwandan government.</s>

en: Economists Predict Bumpy Road for Malawi's Economy in 2015
kin: Abahanga mu bukungu bavuze ku muhanda wa Bumpy mu bukungu bwa Malawi muri 2015
mt0: <pad> Economic experts have commented on the impact of Bumpy Road on the economy of Malawi in 2015.</s>

en: Economists in Malawi say the country is likely to continue facing financial challenges in 2015 unless the government can regain the confidence of donors, who are still withholding 40 percent of budgetary support due to the corruption scandal known as Cashgate. More than $30 million were looted from government coffers in the scandal, and several people, including government officials, were arrested.
kin: Abashinzwe ubukungu muri Malawi bavuga ko iki gihugu gishobora gukomeza guhura n’ibibazo by’amafaranga mu mwaka wa 2015 keretse guverinoma ishobora kugarura ikizere cy’abaterankunga, bakaba bakomeje guhagarika 40% by’ingengo y’imari kubera ikibazo cya ruswa kizwi ku izina rya Cashgate. Amadolari arenga miliyoni 30 yasahuwe mu isanduku ya leta muri ayo mahano, maze abantu benshi barimo n'abayobozi ba leta barafatwa.
mt0: <pad> Malawi's financial experts say the country may continue to face financial difficulties in 2015 unless the government can regain the trust of its international donors, who have been holding 40% of its budget due to the Cashgate scandal.</s>

en: The withholding of donor aid has forced Malawi's government to pass what is known as the Zero Aid national budget for the 2014-2015 fiscal year. Analysts, such as Abel Mwanyungwe, an economics lecturer at the Polytechnic College of the University of Malawi, say the drop in spending has hurt the economy.
kin: Guhagarika imfashanyo z'abaterankunga byatumye leta ya Malawi itora icyitwa ingengo y’imari ya Zero Aid mu mwaka w'ingengo y'imari wa 2014-2015. Abasesenguzi nka Abel Mwanyungwe, umwarimu w’ubukungu muri kaminuza ya Polytechnic ya kaminuza ya Malawi, bavuga ko igabanuka ry’amafaranga ryangije ubukungu.
mt0: <pad> The cuts in aid from the international community led to the government of Malawi adopting a zero aid budget in the fiscal year 2014-2015. Analysts like Abel Mwanyungwe, an economics professor at the Polytechnic University of Malawi, say the reduction in aid has damaged the economy.</s>

en: "This has been a bumpy year as we are coming from the Cashgate effects that have quite a major dent on the economys performance. We have seen that in most cases the very delicate and crucial departments and service providers have been affected, in the sense that we dont have enough drugs in the hospitals. In schools, in terms of teachers payments is not in time," said Mwanyungwe.
kin: Uyu ni umwaka utoroshye kuko tuvuye mu ngaruka za Cashgate zifite uruhare runini mu mikorere y'ubukungu. Twabonye ko akenshi usanga amashami yoroheje kandi akomeye ndetse n'abatanga serivisi byagize ingaruka, mu buryo bw'uko ntabwo dufite ibiyobyabwenge bihagije mu bitaro. Mu mashuri, mu bijyanye no kwishyura abarimu ntabwo ari igihe , Mwanyungwe.
mt0: <pad> This year is not easy as we have come out of the effects of Cashgate which has a large impact on the economic functioning. We have seen that often small and medium-sized firms and service providers have been affected, in such a way that we don't have enough drugs in our hospitals. In the schools, regarding paying teachers, it's not time.</s>

en: Mwanyungwe also links Cashgate to the recent depreciation of Malawis currency, the kwacha, which has resulted in strikes by various government workers demanding higher pay.
kin: Mwanyungwe ahuza kandi Cashgate no guta agaciro kw'ifaranga rya Malawis, kwacha, bikaba byaratumye imyigaragambyo y'abakozi ba leta basaba umushahara munini.
mt0: <pad> Mwanyungwe also links Cashgate to the devaluation of Malawi's currency, kwacha, which has led to government workers protesting for higher pay.</s>

en: For example, support staff for the judiciary have been on strike for six weeks, seeking a 45 percent pay increase which the government says it cannot afford because it has no money.
kin: Kurugero, abakozi bunganira ubucamanza bamaze ibyumweru bitandatu bigaragambyaga, basaba kongererwa umushahara 45% leta ivuga ko idashobora kwishyura kuko idafite amafaranga.
mt0: <pad> The lawyers of the judiciary have been protesting for six weeks, demanding a 45% pay hike that the government says it can't pay because it doesn't have money.</s>

en: Workers at Malawi's Anti-Corruption Bureau went on strike demanding a 70 percent pay raise until the government threatened to forfeit their December salaries if they did not return.
kin: Abakozi bo mu biro bishinzwe kurwanya ruswa muri Malawi bagiye mu myigaragambyo basaba kongererwa umushahara 70% kugeza igihe leta ibangamiye ko bazabura umushahara wabo mu Kuboza nibataha.
mt0: <pad> Malawian anti-corruption workers have staged a protest demanding a 70% pay hike until the government threatened to cut their pay in December if they did not agree to a deal.</s>

en: Mwanyungwe said the government can only avoid further strikes in 2015 if it makes efforts to restore donor confidence in the management of its public finances.
kin: Mwanyungwe yavuze ko guverinoma ishobora kwirinda gusa imyigaragambyo mu 2015 mu gihe ishyira ingufu mu kugarura icyizere cy'abaterankunga mu micungire y’imari ya Leta.
mt0: <pad> The government can only avoid protests in 2015 if it concentrates on regaining the trust of international donors in the management of the state finances, Mr Mwanyungwe said.</s>

en: "My fear is that if we dont have this donor confidence and donor support coming back to the economy, we may force the government to go into serious local borrowing that would lead to serious repercussions in terms of inflation, in terms of interest rates and this may have a sort of catch-catch lose situation," said Mwanyungwe.
kin: Ubwoba bwanjye ni uko niba tudafite iki cyizere cy'abaterankunga ndetse n'inkunga y'abaterankunga igaruka mu bukungu, dushobora guhatira guverinoma kujya mu nguzanyo zikomeye zaho byavamo ingaruka zikomeye ku bijyanye n'ifaranga, ku bijyanye n'inyungu n'ibi hashobora kugira uburyo bwo gufata-gutakaza ibintu , Mwanyungwe.
mt0: <pad> My fear is that if we don't have this donor trust and the donor support back into the economy, we may have to force the government into very difficult borrowing which will have very serious consequences in terms of money, in terms of profits and this could have a take-and-lose mechanism.</s>

en: The donors are, among other things, demanding that the government prosecute all those involved in the scandal and strengthen its financial management system.
kin: Abaterankunga, mu bindi, basaba ko leta yakurikirana abantu bose bagize uruhare muri ayo mahano no gushimangira gahunda y’imicungire y’imari.
mt0: <pad> The donors, among other things, urge the government to prosecute all those involved in the accident and strengthen the system of financial management.</s>

en: Newton Kambala, the president of the Malawi Confederation of Chambers of Commerce and Industry, said the scandal rendered 2014 as "a very bad year for the business sector, because of huge debts that the government owes the private sector."
kin: Newton Kambala, perezida w’ishyirahamwe ry’ubucuruzi n’inganda muri Malawi, yavuze ko aya mahano yatumye umwaka wa 2014 uba "umwaka mubi cyane ku bucuruzi, kubera imyenda nini leta ibereyemo abikorera."
mt0: <pad> Newton Kambala, president of the Malawi Chamber of Business and Industry, said that 2014 was "the worst year for business, due to the large debts the government has owed the private sector."</s>

en: He warned that if the situation persists, "2015 will be worse."
kin: Yagabishije ko nibikomeza, "2015 bizaba bibi."
mt0: <pad> He warned that if this continues, "2015 will be bad."</s>

en: In his state of the nation address last Saturday, Malawi president Peter Mutharika said his government is doing everything possible to address the problems caused by the Cashgate scandal.
kin: Ku wa gatandatu ushize, muri leta y’igihugu cye, Peter Mutharika, yavuze ko guverinoma ye ikora ibishoboka byose kugira ngo ikemure ibibazo byatewe n’urukozasoni rwa Cashgate.
mt0: <pad> Last Friday, during his national assembly, Peter Mutharika said his government was doing all it can to solve the problems caused by the Cashgate scandal.</s>

en: "My government has strengthened the financial system to make sure that Cashgate never occurs again in Malawi. We have resourced fairly well the law enforcement institutions, including the Anti-Corruption Bureau, so that they do a thorough independent job, prosecute all suspects, and recover the stolen resources where possible," said Mutharika.
kin: Guverinoma yanjye yashimangiye gahunda y’imari kugira ngo Cashgate itazongera kubaho muri Malawi. Twakiriye neza inzego zishinzwe kubahiriza amategeko, harimo na Biro ishinzwe kurwanya ruswa, kugira ngo bakore akazi kigenga, bakurikirane abakekwaho icyaha bose, kandi kugarura umutungo wibwe aho bishoboka, Mutharika.
mt0: <pad> My government has strengthened the financial system to prevent Cashgate from happening again in Malawi. We have welcomed the law enforcement agencies, including the Office on Anti-Corruption, to do an independent job, prosecute all of the accused, and recover the stolen assets as much as possible, President.</s>

en: Mutharika also said his government is implementing newly-adopted fiscal reforms that seek to grow the countrys economy by 5.5 percent in 2014, up from an estimated 5.0 percent in 2013.
kin: Mutharika yavuze kandi ko guverinoma ye ishyira mu bikorwa ivugurura ry’imari ryashyizweho hagamijwe kuzamura ubukungu bw’igihugu ku gipimo cya 5.5 ku ijana muri 2014, kikaba kivuye ku kigereranyo cya 5.0% muri 2013.
mt0: <pad> Mutharika also said that his government is implementing a fiscal reform to boost the country's economic growth at a rate of 5.5 percent in 2014, up from a 5.0% in 2013.</s>

en: Malawi to Conduct Door-to-Door HIV Testing
kin: Malawi gukora Ikizamini cya virusi itera sida ku muryango
mt0: <pad> Malawi to conduct HIV test at the entrance</s>

en: Malawians have mixed reactions to government plans to introduce door-to door HIV testing early next year. Supporters say the step is urgently needed because 100 Malawians get infected each day, and an average of 138 die from AIDS daily. Minister of Health Jean Kalirani announced the plans during the recent commemoration of World AIDS Day in the northern district of Karonga.
kin: Abanya Malawiya batanze ibitekerezo kuri gahunda za leta zo kwipimisha ku nzu n'inzu mu ntangiriro z'umwaka utaha. Abashyigikiye bavuga ko iyi ntambwe ikenewe byihutirwa kubera ko Abanya Malawi 100 bandura buri munsi, kandi impuzandengo ya 138 bapfa bazize sida buri munsi. Minisitiri w’ubuzima Jean Kalirani yatangaje gahunda mu gihe cyo kwibuka umunsi mpuzamahanga wahariwe kurwanya SIDA mu karere ka Karonga gaherereye mu majyaruguru.
mt0: <pad> Malawians have expressed support for government plans to test every house in the country in the early years of next year.</s>

en: "We will go in the villages asking for blood samples to check whether that person is HIV positive or not. And those that will be found HIV positive will definitely be given the care they need. And those who are found negative will also be counseled so that they remain negative," said Kalirani.
kin: Tuzajya mu midugudu dusaba amaraso kugira ngo tumenye niba uwo muntu afite virusi itera SIDA cyangwa niba atari bo. Kandi abazagaragara ko banduye virusi itera SIDA bazahabwa ubwitonzi bakeneye. Kandi abagaragaye ko ari babi na bo bazabigirwa inama. ko bakomeza kuba babi , Kalirani.
mt0: <pad> We will go to the villages and ask for blood to see if the person has HIV or not. And those who are found to have HIV will be given the care they need. And those who are found to be bad will be advised.</s>

en: Kalirani said the campaign will start in mid-March and will aim to reach everyone in the country, including people who are far from health facilities that provide HIV testing and counseling services. She said the campaign is in line with the goal of ending HIV infection by 2030. Malawi's HIV infection rate is currently at 10 percent, a slight drop from three years ago.
kin: Kalirani yavuze ko ubukangurambaga buzatangira hagati muri Werurwe kandi bugamije kugera kuri buri wese mu gihugu, harimo n'abantu bari kure y'ibigo nderabuzima bitanga serivisi zipimisha virusi itera SIDA. Yavuze ko ubukangurambaga bujyanye n'intego yo guhagarika ubwandu bwa virusi itera SIDA mu 2030. Muri iki gihe umubare w'ababana na virusi itera SIDA uri muri Malawi uri ku gipimo cya 10 ku ijana, ukaba wagabanutseho gato mu myaka itatu ishize.
mt0: <pad> Kalirani said the campaign will target everyone in Malawi, including people who are far from health facilities that offer HIV tests.</s>

en: The announcement has raised fears in some Malawians, such as Steven Jailosi, a primary school teacher in rural Blantyre, who feel the campaign will likely infringe upon peoples privacy.
kin: Iri tangazo ryateje ubwoba bamwe mu Banya Malawi, nka Steven Jailosi, umwarimu w’ishuri ryibanze mu cyaro cya Blantyre, bumva ko ubukangurambaga bushobora guhungabanya ubuzima bwite bw’abaturage.
mt0: <pad> The announcement scared some Malawians, like Steven Jailosi, a teacher at a primary school in Blantyre, who feared that the campaign could affect their private lives.</s>

en: "I think it is not okay because they will be invading our privacy. HIV testing is supposed to be private. No one is supposed to know that I went for an HIV testing unless I make a choice to tell them," said Jailosi.
kin: Jailosi ati: "Ntekereza ko atari byiza kuko bazinjira mu buzima bwacu. Kwipimisha virusi itera sida bigomba kuba byihariye. Nta muntu ugomba kumenya ko nagiye kwipimisha virusi itera sida keretse mpisemo kubabwira".
mt0: <pad> Jailosi said: "I think it's not good because they get into our lives. The HIV test should be private. No one should know I've been tested for HIV unless I decide to tell them."</s>

en: Ester Makonokaya, a secretary in Blantyre, said that although she has been tested already, she feels the door-to-door HIV testing will violate people's privacy.
kin: Ester Makonokaya, umunyamabanga muri Blantyre, yavuze ko nubwo yamaze kwipimisha, yumva ko kwipimisha virusi itera sida ku nzu n'inzu bizahungabanya ubuzima bwite bw'abantu.
mt0: <pad> Ester Makonokaya, a secretary in Blantyre, said that although she has been tested for HIV, she thinks it will interfere with people's privacy.</s>

en: "Government should instead take the mobile clinics to the villages where people will be able to access them on their own rather than taking testing in their homes, because that might mean that some of the people who are not supposed to know other peoples status will know because, you know, when someone has been tested you show some reactions," said Makonokaya.
kin: Guverinoma igomba ahubwo kujyana amavuriro agendanwa mu midugudu aho abantu bazashobora kuyageraho bonyine aho kwipimisha mu ngo zabo, kuko ibyo bivuze ko bamwe mu bantu batagomba kumenya uko abandi baturage bazabimenya. kuberako, urabizi, iyo umuntu yapimwe uba ugaragaje reaction zimwe , Makonokaya.
mt0: <pad> The government should rather bring mobile clinics to the communities where people can go alone instead of testing at home, because that means that some people don't have to know how others will know.</s>

en: Macpherson Maulana, a journalist in Blantyre and a producer of radio programs on health, told VOA that government would do better to educate Malawians on the need for HIV testing so that people will go for tests on their own "without being pushed."
kin: Macpherson Maulana, umunyamakuru muri Blantyre akaba na progaramu ya radiyo ku buzima, yabwiye Ijwi rya Amerika ko guverinoma izakora ibishoboka byose kugira ngo yigishe Abanya Malawi ko bakeneye kwipimisha virusi itera SIDA kugira ngo abantu bajye kwipimisha bonyine "badasunitswe."
mt0: <pad> Macpherson Maulana, a journalist in Blantyre and a radio program on health, told the Voice of America that the government will do everything it can to educate Malawians about the need for HIV testing so that people go to get tested "unshaken."</s>

en: "I fear it could end up into fights. You see it happened in Liberia recently where people who were coming to help people suspected to have contracted Ebola were even killed. So, civic education is the most important element for people to be encouraged to come out for testing voluntarily," said Maulana.
kin: Ndatinya ko bishobora kurangira mu mirwano. Urabona ko byabereye muri Liberiya vuba aha aho abantu bari baje gufasha abantu bakekwaho kuba baranduye Ebola ndetse bakicwa. Rero, uburere mboneragihugu ni cyo kintu cy'ingenzi abantu bashishikarizwa kuza hanze yo kwipimisha ku bushake, Maulana.
mt0: <pad> I'm afraid it could end in conflict. You see what happened in Liberia recently where people came to help Ebola patients and were killed. So, civic education is the key thing that people are encouraged to come out and get tested voluntarily, Maulana.</s>

en: However, HIV/AIDS counselor David Odali, whose NGO Umunthu Foundation runs HIV-related projects, insisted privacy will be protected.
kin: Icyakora, umujyanama wa virusi itera SIDA, David Odali, umuryango utegamiye kuri Leta Umunthu Foundation ukora imishinga ijyanye na virusi itera SIDA, yashimangiye ko ubuzima bwite buzarindwa.
mt0: <pad> But, AIDS expert David Odali of the non-profit Human Foundation, which works on HIV projects, confirmed that privacy will be protected.</s>

en: "Confidentiality will be upheld. Lets consider the household setup. I think the first thing would be to provide group counseling to members of that family. [Of course] people can be tested while others are watching, but when it comes to disclosing the results, a counselor is supposed to disclose that results to each and every individual separately," said Odali.
kin: Amabanga azubahirizwa. Reka dusuzume uko urugo rumeze. Ntekereza ko ikintu cya mbere cyaba ari ugutanga inama mu matsinda ku bagize uwo muryango. [Birumvikana ko] abantu bashobora kwipimisha mu gihe abandi bareba, ariko mu gihe cyo gutangaza ibisubizo. , umujyanama agomba guhishura ibisubizo kuri buri muntu ku giti cye , Odali.
mt0: <pad> The privacy will be respected. Let's assess the family. I think the first thing would be to provide group counseling for the members of the family. [Of course] people can test themselves while others are watching, but when they release the results, the counselor should reveal the results to each individual, Odell.</s>

en: Odali said it will be up to the person who has been tested to disclose his or her status.
kin: Odali yavuze ko umuntu uzapimwa azagaragaza uko ahagaze.
mt0: <pad> Odali said that the testing will show how well the patient is doing.</s>

en: In 2006, the charity Development Aid from People to People conducted door-to-door HIV testing in the district of Thyolo and Blantyre, reaching 400,000 people. The organization says it worked well.
kin: Mu mwaka wa 2006, imfashanyo ishinzwe iterambere ry’abantu kuva ku bantu kugeza ku bantu bakoze isuzuma ku nzu n'inzu mu karere ka Thyolo na Blantyre, bagera ku 400.000. Uyu muryango uvuga ko wakoze neza.
mt0: <pad> In 2006, the Population Development Fund (PDP) conducted house-to-house surveys in the Thyolo and Blantyre areas of the country, reaching 400,000 people. The organisation says it has done well.</s>

en: Water Crisis Raises Fears of Waterborne Disease in Malawi
kin: Ikibazo cy’amazi gitera ubwoba bwindwara ziterwa n’amazi muri Malawi
mt0: <pad> Water problems in Malawi are causing fears of water-related diseases.</s>

en: Malawians in the country's commercial capital, Blantyre, usually rely on tap water. But for the past five months, the taps have often run dry, forcing residents to draw water from unprotected sources like rivers and wells, while work is being done at the city main pumping station.The risk of contracting water-borne diseases is rising.
kin: Abanya Malawi mu murwa mukuru w’ubucuruzi w’igihugu, Blantyre, bashingira ku mazi meza. Ariko mu mezi atanu ashize, robine yakunze gukama, bigatuma abaturage bavoma amazi mu masoko adakingiwe nk'inzuzi n'amariba, mu gihe imirimo ikorerwa kuri sitasiyo nkuru yo mu mujyi. Ibyago byo kwandura indwara ziterwa n'amazi biriyongera.
mt0: <pad> Malawians in the commercial capital Blantyre depend on clean water. But in the past five months, the taps have often broken down, forcing people to drink unfiltered water from sources like rivers and streams, while work is underway on the main station in the city. The risk of contracting waterborne diseases is rising.</s>

en: In Blantyre and surrounding areas, residents have spent five days without tap water.
kin: Muri Blantyre no mu turere tuyikikije, abaturage bamaranye iminsi itanu nta mazi meza.
mt0: <pad> In Blantyre and the surrounding areas, residents have been without clean water for five days.</s>

en: Women, who by Malawi tradition are responsible for household tasks, complain of the risks they face when fetching water from rivers far from residential areas.
kin: Abagore, bakurikije imigenzo ya Malawi bashinzwe imirimo yo murugo, binubira ingaruka bahura nazo mugihe bavoma amazi mumigezi kure yabatuye.
mt0: <pad> Women, according to the tradition of Malawian women, complain about the effects they experience when they drink water from rivers far from their homes.</s>

en: Rhoda Milanzi, a housewife and mother of three, tells VOA the journeys through bushy footpaths are risky. "We wake up every day 2 a.m., sometimes 1 a.m., to go and collect water. There are so many risks. You see, sometimes we would meet witches, snakes on the way," she says, "even hyenas have been chasing us."
kin: Rhoda Milanzi, umugore wo murugo akaba na nyina wabana batatu, abwira IJWI ingendo zinyura mumihanda y'ibihuru ishobora guteza akaga. Agira ati: "Turabyuka buri munsi saa mbiri za mu gitondo, rimwe na rimwe mu gitondo, kugira ngo tujye gukusanya amazi. Hariho ingaruka nyinshi. Urabona, rimwe na rimwe twahuraga n'abapfumu, inzoka mu nzira", ndetse n'impyisi zagiye zidukurikirana. . "
mt0: <pad> Rhoda Milanzi, a married mother of three children, told the IJWI that traveling through the forest can be dangerous. She said: "We wake up every day at 2 o'clock, sometimes in the morning, to collect water. There are many effects. You see, sometimes we met wizards, snakes in the path", and even monkeys have followed us... "There are many dangers.
