en: Milanzi says to ease the burden of carrying water home for bathing, women prefer to bathe in the river. But she says they have been disturbed by youths who hide in the nearby bush.
kin: Milanzi avuga ko koroshya umutwaro wo gutwara amazi murugo rwo kwiyuhagira, abagore bahitamo kwiyuhagira muruzi. Ariko avuga ko bahungabanijwe n’urubyiruko rwihishe mu gihuru kiri hafi.
mt0: <pad> Milanzi says that to ease the burden of carrying water to the bathroom, women choose to bathe in the river. But she says they are being hindered by young men hiding in the nearby bushes.</s>

en: "These youths of today would come there and hide somewhere to see us naked. This has been a major embarrassment. In fact we complained to the chiefs about it.
kin: Uru rubyiruko rwo muri iki gihe rwazaga hariya rwihisha kugira ngo rutubone twambaye ubusa. Ibi byabaye isoni zikomeye. Mubyukuri twaritotombeye abatware. Bahannye bamwe muri bo, ariko uzi ko rimwe na rimwe bazamuka ibiti kugira ngo barebe abagore bakuze nkatwe.
mt0: <pad> The modern young people would come there to study to see us naked. This was very shameful. We actually played the kings. Some of them were bad, but you know that sometimes they climbed up the trees to look at older women like us.</s>

en: The water problem also has affected the delivery of health services.
kin: Ikibazo cy’amazi nacyo cyagize ingaruka ku itangwa rya serivisi z'ubuzima.
mt0: <pad> The water problem also affected the provision of health services.</s>

en: Three weeks ago, authorities at Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital in Blantyre confirmed that they had suspended surgical operations due to water scarcity.
kin: Ibyumweru bitatu bishize, abayobozi mu bitaro bikuru by’umwamikazi Elizabeth i Blantyre bemeje ko bahagaritse ibikorwa byo kubaga kubera kubura amazi.
mt0: <pad> Three weeks ago, the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Blantyre announced that they had suspended operations because of water shortages.</s>

en: Health rights campaigners warn of the possible outbreak of waterborne diseases, especially in densely populated areas, if the situation is left unresolved.
kin: Abaharanira uburenganzira bw’ubuzima baraburira ko hashobora kubaho indwara ziterwa n’amazi, cyane cyane mu turere dutuwe cyane, niba ikibazo kidakemutse.
mt0: <pad> Health activists warn that water-related diseases can be caused, particularly in heavily-populated areas, if the problem is not resolved.</s>

en: Officials at the Blantyre Water Board attribute the problem largely to an ongoing European Union-funded project that seeks to install new pumping machines at Walkers Ferry, the main pumping station. Priscilla Mateyu, the spokesperson for the Blantyre Water Board, says the project is expected to increase water production capacity to 105,000 cubic meters per day from the current daily production of 78,000 cubic meters.
kin: Abayobozi mu kigo cy’amazi cya Blantyre bavuga ko iki kibazo ahanini cyatewe n’umushinga uterwa inkunga n’umuryango w’ubumwe bw’ibihugu by’Uburayi ushaka gushyira imashini nshya zo kuvoma kuri Walkers Ferry, sitasiyo nkuru yo kuvoma. Priscilla Mateyu, umuvugizi w’ikigo cy’amazi cya Blantyre, avuga ko umushinga uteganijwe kongera ingufu z’amazi kugera kuri metero kibe 105.000 ku munsi uhereye ku musaruro wa buri munsi wa metero 78.000.
mt0: <pad> The lack of water in Blantyre has been blamed in part on a European Union project to install new pumps at the main pump station.</s>

en: "January is when the project is finishing. But for the new machines and everything else to start working properly, we have to wait until March [2015]. That's when we expect the levels would increase and also production capacity improving to least what we expect it to be," Mateyu said.
kin: Mutarama ni bwo umushinga urangiye. Ariko kugira ngo imashini nshya n'ibindi byose bitangire gukora neza, tugomba gutegereza kugeza muri Werurwe [2015]. Nibwo twizeye ko urwego rwiyongera kandi n'ubushobozi bwo kongera umusaruro bugera ku byo dutegereje bigomba kuba, Mateyu ati.
mt0: <pad> The project was finished in January. But to get the new machine and everything else to start working properly, we have to wait till March [2015]. That's when we hope the level will be higher and the capacity to increase production will be enough to meet our expectations, Matthew said.</s>

en: The local consumer rights watchdog, the Consumers Association of Malawi, had been planning to hold vigils at the water board until the water supply was normalized, but the board asked protesters to hold off, promising to distribute water to residents through mobile water tanks. The consumer rights group has given the water board two weeks to fulfill its commitment before proceeding with the protests.
kin: Ishyirahamwe ry’uburenganzira bw’umuguzi ryaho, Ishyirahamwe ry’abaguzi muri Malawi, ryateganyaga gukomeza kuba maso ku kibaho cy’amazi kugeza igihe amazi azaba asanzwe, ariko inama y'ubutegetsi yasabye abigaragambyaga guhagarika, basezeranya guha abaturage amazi binyuze mu bigega by’amazi. Ihuriro ry’uburenganzira bw’umuguzi ryahaye akanama k’amazi ibyumweru bibiri kugirango ryuzuze ibyo ryiyemeje mbere yo gukomeza imyigaragambyo.
mt0: <pad> The local consumer group, Consumers Union of Malawi, planned to continue protesting the water crisis until water was restored, but the government asked the protesters to stop, promising to provide water to the people through water tanks. The Consumers Union gave the water commission two weeks to fulfill its commitment before continuing the protests.</s>

en: Malawi President Under Fire for Giving Money to Journalists
kin: Perezida wa Malawi uri mu muriro kubera guha amafaranga abanyamakuru
mt0: <pad> President of Malawi is under fire for giving money to journalists</s>

en: Malawi President Peter Mutharika is under fire for giving envelopes containing $125 to more than 80 media people at a dinner he hosted last month in Blantyre. The editor of the privately owned Times Television said reporters were told the envelopes contained the presidents plans for the media - which has been critical of the governments economic performance.
kin: Perezida wa Malawi, Peter Mutharika, arashinjwa gutanga amabahasha arimo amadolari 125 ku banyamakuru barenga 80 mu birori yakiriye i Blantyre. Umuyobozi w'ikinyamakuru Times Televiziyo yigenga yavuze ko abanyamakuru babwiwe ko mu ibahasha irimo gahunda za ba perezida ku itangazamakuru - ryanenze imikorere ya guverinoma.
mt0: <pad> President Peter Mutharika of Malawi is accused of handing out envelopes with 125 US dollars to over 80 journalists at a ceremony he attended in Blantyre.</s>

en: In his column published in Malawis Sunday Times newspaper, editor Grecian Tukula said he was not sure why the money was given to journalists at the state dinner.
kin: Mu nkingi ye yasohotse mu kinyamakuru Malawis Sunday Times, umwanditsi Grecian Tukula yavuze ko atazi neza impamvu ayo mafaranga yahawe abanyamakuru mu ifunguro rya Leta.
mt0: <pad> In his column in the Sunday Times of Malawi, writer Grecian Tukula said he did not know why the money was given to journalists in government food.</s>

en: Tukula said he initially decided to return the money but reversed the decision to avoid "creating a scene."
kin: Tukula yavuze ko yabanje gufata icyemezo cyo gusubiza amafaranga ariko ahindura icyemezo cyo kwirinda "gukora ibintu."
mt0: <pad> Tukula said he initially decided to return the money but changed his mind to avoid "doing things."</s>

en: But the editor for the Weekend Nation newspaper, George Kasakula, told VOA that he returned the money right away.
kin: Ariko umwanditsi w'ikinyamakuru Weekend Nation, George Kasakula, yabwiye VOA ko yahise asubiza amafaranga.
mt0: <pad> But the editor of the Weekend Nation, George Kasakula, told VOA he had returned the money.</s>

en: "I just felt it was not right for me to receive the money, so I returned it. My understanding is that if someone invites me to a workshop, its their duty to ensure that they feed me, they accommodate me and they transport me. But in this case, I didnt see why I should get that allowance because I didnt spend anything to go to Sanjika [Palace]," said Kasakula.
kin: Gusa numvaga bidakwiriye ko nakira ayo mafaranga, nuko ndayasubiza. Ndumva ko niba umuntu antumiye mu mahugurwa, inshingano zabo zo kureba ko bampa, baranyakira kandi barantwara. Ariko muri uru rubanza, sinigeze mbona impamvu nkwiye kubona ayo mafaranga kubera ko ntacyo nakoresheje ngo njya i Sanjika [Ingoro] , Kasakula.
mt0: <pad> Just felt it wasn't right to take the money, so I returned it. I think if someone invites me to a training, it's their responsibility to provide me with food, accommodation and transport. But in this case, I didn't see any reason to take the money because I didn't use it to go to Sanjika [the lodge] or Kasakula.</s>

en: The issue has attracted more public attention after privately owned Capital Radio aired a story questioning the meaning of the cash handouts from the president.
kin: Iki kibazo cyashimishije abantu benshi nyuma y’uko abikorera ku giti cyabo Radio Radio yerekanaga inkuru ibaza icyo amafaranga yatanzwe na perezida.
mt0: <pad> The question drew the attention of many people after private radio showed a report on how much money the president had given.</s>

en: "As Capital FM we serve the interest of the public. This issue has been all over the social media, and even we as a media are implicated [we believe] it is paramount that we follow up and get to the bottom of the matter," said Steven Dakalira, the head of news and current affairs at Capital Radio.
kin: Nka Capital FM dukorera inyungu za rubanda. Iki kibazo cyabaye ku mbuga nkoranyambaga, ndetse natwe nk'itangazamakuru tubigiramo uruhare [twizera ko ari ngombwa ko dukurikirana kandi tukagera ku kibazo, "ibi bikaba byavuzwe na Steven Dakalira, ukuriye amakuru n'ibikorwa muri iki gihe kuri Radiyo Nkuru.
mt0: <pad> As Capital FM, we serve the interests of the public. This issue happened on social media, and we as a journalist [believe it is our responsibility to follow and address the issue], " said Steven Dakalira, current news and programming director at Capital FM.</s>

en: In his column in the Nyasa Times, Malawi professor of law Danwood Mzikenge Chirwa said what President Mutharika did by giving money handouts to journalists at a news event was tantamount to bribery. He has called on Mutharika to resign or face impeachment proceedings.
kin: Mu nkingi ye mu kinyamakuru Nyasa Times, umwarimu w’amategeko muri Malawi, Danwood Mzikenge Chirwa, yavuze ko ibyo Perezida Mutharika yakoze mu gutanga amafaranga ku banyamakuru mu birori by’amakuru byari bihwanye na ruswa. Yahamagariye Mutharika kwegura cyangwa gukurikiranwa mu nkiko.
mt0: <pad> In his column in the Nyasa Times, a professor of law in Malawi, Danwood Mzikenge Chirwa, said that President Mutharika's payment to journalists at news conferences was equivalent to bribery. He urged Mutharika to resign or face legal action.</s>

en: Local civil society groups said that "by attempting to bribe the journalists" Mutharika subjected his leadership style to disrepute.
kin: Imiryango itegamiye kuri leta yavuze ko "mu gushaka guha ruswa abanyamakuru" Mutharika yakoresheje uburyo bwe bwo kuyobora.
mt0: <pad> NGOs said that the President used his powers "in an attempt to bribe journalists."</s>

en: Meanwhile, some journalists are donating the money to charity.
kin: Hagati aho, bamwe mu banyamakuru batanga amafaranga mu gufasha.
mt0: <pad> While some journalists offered money to help.</s>

en: Brian Ligomeka, the Managing Editor for the Times Group, told Times Television that all four employees there have donated the money to an orphanage.
kin: Umuyobozi mukuru w'ikinyamakuru Times Group, Brian Ligomeka, yatangarije Televiziyo ya Times ko abakozi bose uko ari bane batanze amafaranga mu kigo cy'imfubyi.
mt0: <pad> Brian Ligomeka, the chief executive of The Times Group, told the Times on television that all four employees donated money to a shelter.</s>

en: "At first we decided to return the money to the president but we later thought it wise to buy assorted items like sugar, salt, notebooks and donate it to needy children," said Ligomeka.
kin: Ligomeka ati: "Twabanje gufata icyemezo cyo gusubiza amafaranga perezida ariko nyuma twatekereje ko ari byiza kugura ibintu bitandukanye nk'isukari, umunyu, amakaye maze tukabiha abana batishoboye".
mt0: <pad> Ligomeka said: "We initially decided to return the president's money but later we thought it would be better to buy different things like sugar, salt, and coffee and give them to the poor children."</s>

en: In his latest Sunday Times column, Raphael Tenthani, who also writes for BBC, apologized on behalf of other journalists "for letting down the public that trust journalists unreservedly."
kin: Mu kinyamakuru Sunday Times aheruka gusohora, Raphael Tenthani, nawe wandika kuri BBC, yasabye imbabazi mu izina ry'abandi banyamakuru "kubera ko yaretse rubanda yizera abanyamakuru bidasubirwaho."
mt0: <pad> In a recent Sunday Times article, Raphael Tenthani, a BBC journalist, apologised for "breaking the trust of the public in journalists."</s>

en: Tenthani has since donated the money for charity work and said that although the journalists could have done better if they returned the money right away, doing so would have been perceived as disrespect to the head of state.
kin: Kuva icyo gihe Tenthani yatanze amafaranga mu bikorwa by'urukundo avuga ko nubwo abanyamakuru bashoboraga gukora neza baramutse basubije amafaranga ako kanya, kubikora byari gufatwa nko gusuzugura umukuru w'igihugu.
mt0: <pad> Since then Tenthani has donated money to charity, saying that although the journalists could have done a better job if they had returned the money immediately, it would be seen as insulting the president.</s>

en: Maclan Kanyangwa, who heads the Department of Journalism and Media Studies at the Polytechnic College of the University of Malawi, said a media code of ethics bars journalists from accepting payment on a story.
kin: Maclan Kanyangwa uyobora ishami ry’itangazamakuru n’ubushakashatsi mu itangazamakuru muri kaminuza ya Polytechnic ya kaminuza ya Malawi, yavuze ko amategeko agenga imyitwarire ibuza abanyamakuru kwakira ubwishyu ku nkuru.
mt0: <pad> Malawian journalists are not allowed to accept payment for their stories, according to the head of the department of media and research at the Polytechnic University of Malawi.</s>

en: "Obviously the meeting at the palace was the newsworthy event. There was a possibility that something was going to be published. And in the event that this payment would have influenced journalist decision [on news judgment], then that becomes a problem," said Kanyangwa.
kin: Ati: "Biragaragara ko inama yabereye ibwami yari igikorwa cyo gutangaza amakuru. Byashobokaga ko hari ikintu kigiye gutangazwa. Kandi mu gihe aya mafaranga yari kugira uruhare mu cyemezo cy'abanyamakuru [ku rubanza rw'amakuru], noneho biba ikibazo." Kanyangwa.
mt0: <pad> He said: "It is clear that the royal meeting was a press conference. It could be that something was going to be announced. And if this money was to have an impact on the journalists' decision [on the press trial], then it becomes a problem."</s>

en: Kanyangwa said he feels many journalists failed to return the money immediately because they might have been out of their ethical senses when they got the money.
kin: Kanyangwa yavuze ko yumva abanyamakuru benshi bananiwe gusubiza amafaranga ako kanya kuko bashobora kuba baravuye mu myitwarire yabo igihe babonye amafaranga.
mt0: <pad> Kanyangwa said he believes many journalists failed to return the money immediately because they may have lost their behavior after receiving the money.</s>

en: Efforts to talk to Presidential Press Officer Fredrick Ndala were not successful. But some government authorities say the payment was not a bribe but meant for a fuel refund to those who attended the night event.
kin: Imbaraga zo kuvugana n’umuyobozi ushinzwe itangazamakuru rya Perezida Fredrick Ndala ntizagenze neza. Ariko bamwe mu bayobozi ba leta bavuga ko kwishyura atari ruswa ahubwo ko byari bigamije gusubizwa lisansi abitabiriye ibirori bya nijoro.
mt0: <pad> Efforts to speak to the president's press secretary did not go well. But some government officials say the payment was not a bribe but was intended to repay gas to those who attended the night event.</s>

en: Report: Manufacturing Could Free Poorest Nations From Poverty
kin: Raporo: Inganda zishobora kuvana ibihugu bikennye mubukene
mt0: <pad> Report: Industries can help poor countries out of poverty</s>

en: A new United Nations report urges the poorest countries in the world to shift from low- to high-productivity activities to improve their economies.
kin: Raporo nshya y’umuryango w’abibumbye irasaba ibihugu bikennye cyane ku isi kuva mu bikorwa bito bikagera ku musaruro mwinshi kugira ngo ubukungu bwiyongere.
mt0: <pad> A new UN report urges the world's poorest countries to move from small-scale production to higher-yield production to boost economic growth.</s>

en: In its annual Least Developed Countries Report, UNCTAD — the U.N. Conference on Trade and Development — says these countries must structurally transform their economies to free themselves from the "poverty trap," which is stunting economic growth and development.
kin: Muri raporo y’ibihugu byateye imbere cyane cyane, UNCTAD - Inama y’umuryango w’abibumbye ishinzwe ubucuruzi n’iterambere - ivuga ko ibyo bihugu bigomba guhindura imiterere y’ubukungu kugira ngo bikure mu "mutego w’ubukene," bidindiza iterambere ry’ubukungu n’iterambere.
mt0: <pad> In its report on developing countries, the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) says that those countries must change their economic structure to escape the "trap of poverty," which impedes economic development and development.</s>

en: Of the 48 nations the U.N. considers "Least Developed Countries" (LDCs), only one, Laos, is on track to achieve all seven of the Millennium Development Goals (MDG's) by 2015.
kin: Mu bihugu 48 Umuryango w'abibumbye ufata "Ibihugu byateye imbere cyane" (LDCs), kimwe gusa, Laos, kiri mu nzira zo kugera ku ntego zirindwi z'ikinyagihumbi (MDG) muri 2015.
mt0: <pad> From the 48 UN-defined "Low-Development Countries" (LDCs), only one, Laos, is on track to achieve the seven Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) in 2015.</s>

en: Only four African countries — Ethiopia, Malawi, Rwanda and Uganda — are likely to meet a majority of these targets.
kin: Ibihugu bine bya Afurika gusa - Etiyopiya, Malawi, u Rwanda na Uganda - birashoboka ko byujuje ibyinshi muri byo.
mt0: <pad> Four African countries - Ethiopia, Malawi, Rwanda and Uganda - are likely to have met most of these requirements.</s>

en: This assessment is particularly grim in light of the even greater challenges awaiting these countries in the coming years. The MDGs set a goal for nations to halve their poverty levels by 2015. The so-called Sustainable Development Goals, which carry on from where the MDGs leave off, call for eradication of poverty by 2030.
kin: Iri suzuma rirakaze cyane bitewe n’ibibazo bikomeye bitegereje ibi bihugu mu myaka iri imbere. MDGs yihaye intego ibihugu kugabanya ubukene bw’ubukene bitarenze 2015. Icyiswe intego z’iterambere rirambye, kiva aho MDGs ziva, zirahamagarira guca ubukene mu 2030.
mt0: <pad> This review is very important because of the difficult problems that are ahead for these countries. The MDGs set a target for countries to reduce poverty by 2015. The Sustainable Development Goals, which derived from the MDGs, call for eliminating poverty by 2030.</s>

en: According to Taffere Tesfachew, an UNCTAD official who works with African nations, it would be nothing short of a miracle for the LDCs to pull this off.
kin: Nk’uko byatangajwe na Taffere Tesfachew, umuyobozi wa UNCTAD ukorana n'ibihugu by'Afurika, nta kintu na kimwe cyaba ari igitangaza kuri LDCs kubikuramo.
mt0: <pad> As announced by Taffere Tesfachew, the director of UNCTAD's African affairs office, there is nothing surprising for LDCs to pull out of the group.</s>

en: In order for the least developed countries to achieve this miraculous performance, he says they will need to structurally change their economies.
kin: Kugirango ibihugu bidateye imbere bigere kuri iyi mikorere yigitangaza, avuga ko bizakenera guhindura imiterere yubukungu.
mt0: <pad> To achieve this remarkable performance, he said that they needed to change their economic structure.</s>

en: He tells VOA this means shifting labor from activities with low productivity, such as small-scale agriculture and services to more dynamic activities with higher productivity, such as manufacturing and high-value services.
kin: Abwira IJWI ibi bivuze guhindura imirimo mu bikorwa bifite umusaruro muke, nk'ubuhinzi buciriritse na serivisi ku bikorwa byinshi bifite umusaruro mwinshi, nko gukora na serivisi zifite agaciro kanini.
mt0: <pad> He says this means moving jobs from low-yielding activities, like small farming and services, to high-yielding activities, like work and high value services.</s>

en: "Countries that have moved up are the ones that are creating opportunities for those that are leaving agriculture to engage in things where they add value, where they get training and as it happens, manufacturing tends to have that sort of feature, that is why this call for manufacturing," he said. "Countries that are using policies to shift and influence capital and labor to move into this activity sector tend to do better."
kin: Ibihugu byazamutse ni byo bitanga amahirwe ku bava mu buhinzi kwishora mu bintu bongerera agaciro, aho bakura amahugurwa kandi uko bigenda, inganda zikunda kugira ibintu nk'ibyo, niyo mpamvu ibi guhamagarira gukora . "Ibihugu bikoresha politiki mu guhindura no guhindura igishoro n'umurimo kugira ngo byinjire muri uru rwego rw'ibikorwa usanga bikora neza."
mt0: <pad> Emerging countries provide the opportunity for farmers to enter value-added industries, where they get training and as a result, companies like to have things like that, so this is why it's important to do. "Countries that use policy to change and transform taxes and labor to enter this sector of activity are usually doing well.</s>

en: Tesfachew says these high-productivity sectors tend to pay higher wages and create a demand for goods. This, he says, encourages investment.
kin: Tesfachew avuga ko izo nzego zitanga umusaruro mwinshi zikunda kwishyura umushahara munini kandi bigatuma ibicuruzwa bikenerwa. Avuga ko ibi bitera inkunga ishoramari.
mt0: <pad> Tesfachew says that those highly productive sectors often pay high wages and make goods unnecessary. He says that this encourages the business to buy.</s>

en: On the surface, it appears that the LDCs are not doing badly. UNCTAD economic data show growth in these poor countries between 2002 and 2008 exceeded the seven percent target set by the international community. And, even after the 2008 financial crisis, UNCTAD notes the LDCs grew faster than other developing countries, at an average of 5.7 percent per year.
kin: Ku isura, bigaragara ko LDC idakora nabi. Amakuru y’ubukungu ya UNCTAD yerekana iterambere muri ibi bihugu bikennye hagati ya 2002 na 2008 yarenze intego irindwi ku ijana yashyizweho n’umuryango mpuzamahanga. Kandi, na nyuma y’ibibazo by’amafaranga yo mu 2008, UNCTAD ivuga ko LDC yazamutse vuba kurusha ibindi bihugu bikiri mu nzira y'amajyambere, ku kigereranyo cya 5.7 ku ijana ku mwaka.
mt0: <pad> On the surface, it seems that LDC is not doing badly. UNCTAD economic data shows that development in poor countries between 2002 and 2008 exceeded the seven percent target set by the international community. And, even after the 2008 financial crisis, UNCTAD says that LDC has grown faster than other developing countries, at a rate of 5.7 percent per year.</s>

en: But U.N. economists say the outlook for the least developed countries in the short and medium term remains uncertain. They say increasing peoples productivity is the best way to break the patter of human and economic underdevelopment that continues to entrap them in poverty.
kin: Ariko abahanga mu bukungu bo muri Leta zunze ubumwe za Amerika bavuga ko icyerekezo cy’ibihugu bitaratera imbere mu gihe gito kandi giciriritse bikomeje kutamenyekana. Bavuga ko kongera umusaruro w’abaturage aribwo buryo bwiza bwo guca intege iterambere ry’abantu n’ubukungu bikomeje kubashora mu bukene.
mt0: <pad> But American economists say that the future of low- and medium-income countries is still unclear. They say that increasing the output of the population is the best way to curb the growth and economic development that keeps them in poverty.</s>

en: UN: Most African Nations to Miss 2015 MDG Goals
kin: Loni: Ibihugu byinshi bya Afrika ntibizagera  ku ntego za MDG 2015
mt0: <pad> Today: Most African countries will not meet the MDG goals.</s>

en: Most African countries will not reach the Millennium Development Goals set for 2015 because of the gap between economic and human development. That is one of the conclusions in this years annual U.N. report on the Least Developed Countries, presented Thursday.
kin: Ibihugu byinshi bya Afrika ntibizagera ku ntego z'ikinyagihumbi zashyizweho muri 2015 kubera itandukaniro riri hagati y’ubukungu n’iterambere ry’abantu. Uyu ni umwe mu myanzuro muri iyi myaka ya buri mwaka raporo y’umuryango w’abibumbye ku bihugu byateye imbere cyane, byatanzwe ku wa kane.
mt0: <pad> Many African countries will not achieve the Millennium Development Goals set in 2015 due to the gap between economic and human development. This is one of the main conclusions of this year's UN Highly Developed Country Report, released on Thursday.</s>

en: Junior Davis, U.N. economic affairs officer for Africa, said African countries have not been able to translate their economic growth into structural transformation.
kin: Junior Davis, ushinzwe ibibazo by’ubukungu muri Amerika muri Afurika, yavuze ko ibihugu bya Afurika bitashoboye guhindura ubukungu bwabyo mu guhindura imiterere.
mt0: <pad> Junior Davis, the United States' economist in Africa, said that African countries could not change their economies by changing their structure.</s>

en: "We think that is the case because these countries have not focused efficiently on building what we call their productive capacities," Davis said. "These are the basic human and economic development capacities that are needed to promote sustainable economic development. And the MDG, as they were constructed, largely ignored the need to develop the productive capacities."
kin: Davis yagize ati: "Turatekereza ko aribyo kuko ibyo bihugu bitibanze cyane ku kubaka icyo twita ubushobozi bwabo bwo gutanga umusaruro". "Ubu ni bwo bushobozi bw’ibanze bw’iterambere ry’abantu n’ubukungu bukenewe kugira ngo iterambere ry’ubukungu rirambye. Kandi MDG, uko yubatswe, yirengagije ko ari ngombwa guteza imbere ubushobozi butanga umusaruro."
mt0: <pad> Davis said: "We think so because those countries haven't focused enough on building what we call their output capabilities. "This is the fundamental capability of human and economic development that is needed for sustainable economic development. And the MDG, as it was built, neglected the need to develop output capabilities."</s>

en: Slow progress
kin: Buhoro buhoro
mt0: <pad> Please don't know.</s>

en: African countries also are not on course to halve poverty by 2015, and their overall progress on reducing hunger is relatively slow. Poverty limits human development and undermines productivity. And economic development is needed to make gains in human development.
kin: Ibihugu bya Afurika nabyo ntabwo biri mu nzira yo kugabanya ubukene bitarenze 2015, kandi iterambere ryabo muri rusange mu kugabanya inzara biratinda. Ubukene bugabanya iterambere ryabantu kandi bigabanya umusaruro. Kandi iterambere ryubukungu rirakenewe kugirango umuntu yunguke iterambere ryabantu.
mt0: <pad> Africa's countries are not on the path to eliminating poverty by 2015, and their general development in reducing poverty is slow. Poverty decreases human development and reduces output. And economic development is needed to benefit from human development.</s>

en: Ethiopia, Rwanda, Uganda and Malawi are the only African countries on track to reach the majority of the development goals. They are making progress because they heavily invested in areas that create sustainable development such as infrastructure, health and education.
kin: Etiyopiya, u Rwanda, Uganda na Malawi nicyo gihugu cyonyine cya Afurika kiri mu nzira yo kugera ku ntego nyinshi z’iterambere. Barimo gutera imbere kuko bashora imari mubice bitera iterambere rirambye nkibikorwa remezo, ubuzima nuburezi.
mt0: <pad> Etiopia, Rwanda, Uganda and Malawi is the only African country in the process of achieving multiple development goals. They are growing because they invest in areas that lead to long-term development like infrastructure, health and education.</s>

en: The post-2015 development agenda for fragile countries where governance remains an issue — such as South Sudan and the Democratic Republic of Congo — will still largely depend on support from the international community to achieve social and economic development, Davis said.
kin: Davis yavuze ko gahunda y’iterambere ry’inyuma ya 2015 ku bihugu byoroshye aho imiyoborere ikomeje kuba ikibazo - nka Sudani y'Amajyepfo na Repubulika Iharanira Demokarasi ya Kongo - bizaterwa ahanini n’inkunga n’umuryango mpuzamahanga kugira ngo iterambere ry’imibereho n’ubukungu ryiyongere.
mt0: <pad> Davis said that the post-2015 development plan for easily managed countries where governance continues to be a problem - such as South Sudan and the Democratic Republic of Congo - will be largely funded by international aid to boost human and economic development.</s>

en: Improvements in rural development, industrial productivity, agriculture and the services sectors in these countries will require "ways in which we can have a pattern of growth which is not just sustainable but jobs-rich," Davis said. "Because we see the growth in jobs and employment is central to any development strategy that aims to reduce poverty in a sustainable way."
kin: Davis yagize ati: "Gutezimbere mu cyaro, umusaruro w’inganda, ubuhinzi n’inzego za serivisi muri ibi bihugu bizakenera" inzira dushobora kugira uburyo bwo kuzamuka butarambye gusa ahubwo bukungahaye ku mirimo. " "Kubera ko tubona iterambere ry'imirimo n'akazi ari ingenzi mu ngamba zose z'iterambere zigamije kugabanya ubukene mu buryo burambye."
mt0: <pad> Davis said: "Rural development, industrial output, agriculture and services in these countries will need to be the path we can have a sustainable but rich growth." "Because we see the development of jobs and employment as an important component of all development strategies that aim to reduce poverty in a long-term way," he said.</s>

en: A country is placed on the Least Developed Countries list based on its per capita income, economic vulnerability, and human development indicators such as health and nutrition.
kin: Igihugu gishyizwe ku rutonde rw’ibihugu byateye imbere cyane hashingiwe ku musaruro w’umuturage, ubukungu bwifashe nabi, hamwe n’ibipimo by’iterambere ry’abantu nk’ubuzima n’imirire.
mt0: <pad> The country is listed as one of the poorest countries in the world based on its per-capita output, economic inequality, and human development indicators such as health and nutrition.</s>

en: Of the 48 least developed countries in the world, 34 are in Africa. Three countries have graduated from their least developed status: Botswana, Cape Verde and Samoa.
kin: Mu bihugu 48 bidateye imbere ku isi, 34 biri muri Afurika. Ibihugu bigaragara ko byateye imbere cyane: Botswana, Cape Verde na Samoa.
mt0: <pad> From the 48 developing countries in the world, 34 are in Africa. The most developed countries: Botswana, Cape Verde and Samoa.</s>

en: Strike Paralyzes Malawi's Judicial Services
kin: Strike Paralyzes ishinzwe Serivisi z'ubutabera za Malawi
mt0: <pad> Strike Paralyzes Malawi's Judicial Services</s>

en: A week-long strike by the support staff of Malawi's judiciary system has paralyzed the courts, causing overcrowding in police cells and the indefinite suspension of major cases - including government corruption trials. Court marshals, clerks and messengers are demanding the 30 percent salary increases promised by the government two years ago.
kin: Hashize icyumweru cyose abakozi bunganira inzego z'ubutabera za Malawi cyahagaritse inkiko, bituma ubucucike bw’abapolisi bwiyongera ndetse n’ihagarikwa ry’agateganyo mu manza zikomeye - harimo n’imanza za ruswa. Abashinzwe inkiko, abanditsi n’intumwa barasaba kongererwa umushahara 30% byasezeranijwe na guverinoma mu myaka ibiri ishize.
mt0: <pad> The Malawian judiciary union has been on strike for a week, causing a police overcrowding and the temporary suspension of important criminal trials - including graft. Malawian judiciary officers, lawyers and judges are demanding a 30% pay hike promised by the government two years ago.</s>

en: Chanting and singing around the court premises has become a pastime activity for the striking court workers since the onset of a sit-in last week. Linley Hebert, a spokesperson for the striking workers, told VOA the strike is a result of the governments failure to honor a 2012 agreement.
kin: kuririmba hirya no hino mu rukiko byahindutse igikorwa cyo kwidagadura ku bakozi bigaragambyaga kuva icyumweru cyatangira. Linley Hebert, umuvugizi w’abakozi bigaragambyaga, yabwiye Ijwi rya Amerika ko iyi myigaragambyo ari ukubera ko guverinoma itubahirije amasezerano ya 2012.
mt0: <pad> Singing around the courthouse has become a form of entertainment for protesters since the week began. Linley Hebert, a spokesman for the protesters, told the Voice of America that the protests are because the government did not comply with their 2012 contract.</s>

en: "In October [this year], the government reviewed the salaries of the civil servants, but we were not included in that revision," Hebert said.
kin: Hebert yagize ati: "Mu Kwakira [uyu mwaka], guverinoma yasuzumye imishahara y'abakozi ba Leta, ariko ntitwashyizwe muri iryo vugurura."
mt0: <pad> Hebert said: "In October [this year], the government examined the pay of state workers, but we were not included in that review."</s>

en: "Yet in 2012, we had an agreement that each time they are revising the salaries of the civil servants, [they will be increasing our salaries as well].
kin: Nyamara muri 2012, twagiranye amasezerano ko igihe cyose barimo kuvugurura imishahara y'abakozi ba Leta, [bazongera umushahara]. Rero, [nyuma yo kubahiriza ayo masezerano mu 2013], twatunguwe no kubona ko iki gihe dusigaye. Abayobozi ba leta bavuga ko kutongera umushahara w'abakozi bo mu bucamanza muri uyu mwaka ahanini biterwa n'ubukungu buke, nyuma yo guhagarika inkunga y'abaterankunga. kurwanya leta ya Malawi.
mt0: <pad> But in 2012, we signed a deal that whenever they are going to raise the state workers' pay, [we will be given a rise]. So, [after keeping that deal in 2013], we were surprised to see that this time we are still. The government officials say the lack of a rise in the judiciary salary this year is mainly due to the economic difficulties, after the international community withdrew its aid.</s>

en: The freeze is a result of a government financial scandal in which more than $30 million was looted from government coffers. Ministry of Finance spokesperson Nations Msowoya told a local radio station it is hard for the government to meet the workers' demand.
kin: Ihagarikwa ni igisubizo cy’amafaranga ya leta aho yasahuye miliyoni zisaga 30 z’amadolari mu isanduku ya leta. Umuvugizi wa Minisiteri y’Imari, Msowoya, yatangarije radiyo yaho ko bigoye guverinoma isaba abakozi.
mt0: <pad> The arrest is a response to the state money scandal where he stole over 30 million dollars from the state treasury.</s>

en: "It is difficult to promise what the treasury will do. But suffice to say that the prevailing economic circumstances and budgetary constraints will make a little bit difficult for the treasury to bow down to the demands," "Msowoya said.
kin: Msowoya ati: "Biragoye gusezeranya icyo ikigega kizakora. Ariko birahagije kuvuga ko ubukungu bwiganje ndetse n'imbogamizi z’ingengo y’imari bizagora gato ko ikigega cyunama ku byifuzo."
mt0: <pad> Msowoya said: "It is difficult to promise what the fund will do. But it is enough to say that the current economic and fiscal challenges will make it more difficult for the fund to meet the needs."</s>

en: But according to Hebert, the strikers will not resume work until their demands are met. "Since I was born [there has been] no time the government said it had some money.
kin: Ariko nk'uko Hebert abitangaza ngo ba rutahizamu ntibazongera imirimo kugeza igihe ibyo basabye bituzuye. "Kuva navuka [nta gihe] guverinoma yavuze ko ifite amafaranga.
mt0: <pad> But according to Hebert, the nurses will not return to work until their demands are met. "Since I was born [no] government has said it has money.</s>

en: It has its own means [of finding the money] and it will find the same means to give us the money," Hebert insisted. The ongoing strike is hampering progress of trials, as court operations remain suspended.
kin: Ifite uburyo bwayo [bwo gushaka amafaranga] kandi izabona uburyo bumwe bwo kuduha ayo mafaranga ", Hebert yashimangiye.
mt0: <pad> It has its own way of seeking money and it will find some way to pay for it," Hebert added.</s>

en: Several trials, including that of former justice minister Ralph Kasambara, who is answering charges in connection with the financial scandal, were indefinitely suspended last week.
kin: Mu cyumweru gishize, imanza nyinshi, harimo n'uwahoze ari minisitiri w’ubutabera, Ralph Kasambara, usubiza ibirego bijyanye n’ikibazo cy’amafaranga, yahagaritswe burundu mu cyumweru gishize.
mt0: <pad> Last week, many cases, including the former minister of justice, Ralph Kasambara, which re-examined charges related to money, were suspended indefinitely last week.</s>

en: Police are complaining of congestion in jail cells, as no suspects are being taken to court.
kin: Polisi yinubira ubwinshi bw’imfungwa za gereza, kubera ko nta bakekwa bajyanwa mu rukiko.
mt0: <pad> Police complain about the prisoners' numbers, as no suspects have been brought before the court.</s>

en: Malawi police spokesperson Rhoda Manjolo told VOA the only option they have is "giving police bail to those with minor offenses." Human rights campaigners and legal experts say the strike is contributing to human rights violations.
kin: Umuvugizi wa polisi muri Malawi, Rhoda Manjolo, yatangarije Ijwi rya Amerika ko inzira imwe bafite ari "guha ingwate abapolisi bafite ibyaha byoroheje." Abaharanira uburenganzira bwa muntu n'inzobere mu by'amategeko bavuga ko iyi myigaragambyo igira uruhare mu ihohoterwa ry'uburenganzira bwa muntu.
mt0: <pad> The Malawian police spokesman, Rhoda Manjolo, told the American Voice that the only way to end the protests is to "give bail to officers with minor offenses."</s>

en: "There are those people who have to be taken to court within 48 hours," noted Lawyer George Kadzipatike who works in a private practice in the northern city of Mzuzu. "We cannot make application for them to be granted bail.
kin: Umunyamategeko George Kadzipatike ukora mu mwiherero mu mujyi wa Mzuzu uherereye mu majyaruguru yagize ati: "Hariho abo bantu bagomba kujyanwa mu rukiko mu masaha 48". "Ntidushobora gusaba ko bahabwa ingwate.
mt0: <pad> The lawyer George Kadzipatike, who works in the refugee camp in Mzuzu in north, said: "There are some of those people that have to be brought to court within 48 hours. "We can't ask for bail."</s>

en: There are those people who do not want to live with their partners, they would like the court to decree that they be divorced, we cannot file any petition through the courts."
kin: Hariho abo bantu badashaka kubana na bagenzi babo, bifuza ko urukiko rwemeza ko batana, ntidushobora gutanga ikirego binyuze mu nkiko. "
mt0: <pad> Some people don't want to live with their friends, they want to have a court declare them as separate, we can't file a lawsuit through the court.</s>

en: Government authorities say closed door negotiations to resolve the matter continue in the capital, Lilongwe. But the striking workers told VOA whatever the case, they will accept nothing short of a 30 percent increase in their salaries.
kin: Abayobozi ba leta bavuga ko imishyikirano ihagaze kugira ngo iki kibazo ikemuke mu murwa mukuru, Lilongwe. Ariko abakozi bigaragambyaga babwiye VOA uko byagenda kose, nta kintu na kimwe bazemera ko umushahara wabo wiyongera 30%.
mt0: <pad> Officials say talks are ongoing to resolve the issue in the capital, Lilongwe. But protesters told VOA that no matter what happens, they will not accept a 30% pay rise.</s>

en: A similar strike lasted three months in 2012 after the magistrates and judges joined the labor action.
kin: Imyigaragambyo nk'iyi yamaze amezi atatu muri 2012 nyuma yuko abacamanza bitabiriye umurimo.
mt0: <pad> Similar protests lasted for three months in 2012 after the new judges began their work.</s>

en: Famine in Southern Africa Worse Than Predicted - 2002-07-24
kin: Inzara muri Afrika yepfo Ikibi Kurenza Ibyahanuwe - 2002-07-24
mt0: <pad> The Hunger in South Africa Is Worse than Predicted - 2002</s>

en: The United Nations World Food Program says the famine in southern Africa is even worse than predicted. WFP officials are warning that 13 million people in six countries: Malawi, Zambia, Lesotho, Zimbabwe, Swaziland and Mozambique are in danger of starvation if they do not get food aid.
kin: Ishami ry'Umuryango w'Abibumbye ryita ku biribwa rivuga ko inzara muri Afurika y'Epfo ikabije kuruta uko byari byavuzwe. Abayobozi ba WFP baraburira ko abantu miliyoni 13 mu bihugu bitandatu: Malawi, Zambiya, Lesotho, Zimbabwe, Swaziland na Mozambique bafite ibyago byo kwicwa n'inzara nibatabona ubufasha bw'ibiribwa.
mt0: <pad> The World Food Program (WFP) says the famine in South Africa is worse than previously thought.</s>

en: World Food Program officials say they need one million tons of food to alleviate hunger in southern Africa, but they are not confident they will get it. In an appeal to the international community at the beginning of July, WFP officials asked for more than $0.5 billion to buy food. So far they have received only 20 percent of that. WFP's director for the southern Africa region, Judith Lewis, says the situation is getting desperate. "The window of opportunity to avert what could be a major humanitarian crisis is closing," she said. "We need more assistance now. We need food on the high seas now, or we need cash to buy commodities that are still available in southern Africa, so we can avert this major, major crisis."
kin: Abayobozi ba gahunda y’ibiribwa ku isi bavuga ko bakeneye toni miliyoni y’ibiribwa kugira ngo bagabanye inzara muri Afurika yepfo, ariko ntibizeye ko bazayibona. Mu cyifuzo cy’umuryango mpuzamahanga mu ntangiriro za Nyakanga, abayobozi ba WFP basabye amadolari arenga 0.5 yo kugura ibiryo. Kugeza ubu bakiriye 20 ku ijana gusa. Umuyobozi wa WFP mu karere ka Afurika y'Epfo, Judith Lewis, avuga ko ibintu bimeze nabi. Ati: "Idirishya ry'amahirwe yo gukumira icyaba ikibazo gikomeye cy’ubutabazi kirarangiye". "Ubu dukeneye ubufasha bwinshi. Dukeneye ibiryo ku nyanja ndende ubu, cyangwa dukeneye amafaranga yo kugura ibicuruzwa bikiboneka muri Afurika y'Epfo, bityo dushobora gukumira iki kibazo gikomeye kandi gikomeye."
mt0: <pad> The World Food Program (WFP) says it needs to buy one million tonnes of food to help ease the severe famine in South Africa, but is unsure if they will get the money.</s>

en: Currently, the WFP is assisting six million of the most vulnerable people in the six most severely affected countries. About half of these people are in Zimbabwe. The agency says it is sure the number of people needing its help will rise.
kin: Kugeza ubu, WFP ifasha miliyoni esheshatu z’abatishoboye kurusha abandi mu bihugu bitandatu byibasiwe cyane. Hafi ya kimwe cya kabiri cyaba bantu bari muri Zimbabwe. Ikigo kivuga ko cyizeye neza ko umubare w'abantu bakeneye ubufasha bwacyo uziyongera.
mt0: <pad> At present, the World Food Program (WFP) serves six million of the most needy people in six affected countries. Almost half of those are in Zimbabwe. The organization says it is confident that the number of people who need its help will increase.</s>

en: The World Health Organization notes southern Africa, in addition to having the highest prevalence of HIV/AIDS in the world, also has the world's highest chronic malnutrition rates. It predicts about 300,000 people could die over the next six months from diseases related to malnutrition.
kin: Ishami ry'Umuryango w'Abibumbye ryita ku Buzima rivuga ko Afurika y'Epfo, usibye kuba yanduye virusi itera SIDA ku isi, ifite kandi imirire mibi idakira ku isi. Ivuga ko abantu bagera ku 300.000 bashobora gupfa mu mezi atandatu ari imbere bazize indwara ziterwa n'imirire mibi.
mt0: <pad> UN Health says South Africa, in addition to being the world's most infected with HIV, has the worst undernutrition in the world. It says that up to 300.000 people can die in the next six months because of malnutrition.</s>

en: Ms. Lewis says the dying has already begun. "We are seeing people moving from their villages," she said. "If they know there is going to be a food distribution, they immediately go there. The problem is we do not even have enough food to feed the people who are on the rolls, let alone add food for other people in the areas. Is there a potential to become chaotic? Yes. "
kin: Madamu Lewis avuga ko gupfa byatangiye. Ati: "Turimo kubona abantu bimuka mu midugudu yabo." "Niba bazi ko hazabaho kugabura ibiryo, bahita bajyayo. Ikibazo nuko tutagira n'ibiryo bihagije byo kugaburira abantu bari kuri lisiti, tutibagiwe no kongeramo ibiryo kubandi bantu bo muri utwo turere. hari amahirwe yo kuba akajagari? Yego.
mt0: <pad> "If they know that there will be food distribution, they go there. The problem is that we don't have enough food to feed the people on the list, not to mention the other people in those areas."</s>

en: WFP'S Judith Lewis says at this time of year the agency is usually planning how to get food supplies into the region before the rainy season hits in October. But she says since the WFP is already having difficulty meeting its present targets, it can't even begin to plan for future food deliveries.
kin: WFP'S Judith Lewis avuga ko muri iki gihe cy'umwaka ubusanzwe iki kigo giteganya uburyo bwo kwinjiza ibiribwa mu karere mbere yuko ibihe by'imvura bitangira mu Kwakira. Ariko avuga ko kubera ko WFP isanzwe ifite ikibazo cyo kugera ku ntego zayo ubu, ntishobora no gutangira gutegura ibiribwa bizaza.
mt0: <pad> WFP's Judith Lewis says that this time of year the organization usually plans to provide food in the region before the rain season starts in October. But she says that since WFP is already having difficulty achieving its goals now, it can't even begin preparing for the future.</s>

en: Canadian PM Impressed With African Development Plan - 2002-04-05
kin: Minisitiri w’intebe wa Kanada Yashimishijwe na gahunda y’iterambere rya Afurika - 2002-04-05
mt0: <pad> Canada's Prime Minister praised for the African Development Program - 2002</s>

en: Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien says he is impressed with the progress being made towards implementing an African development plan.
kin: Minisitiri w’intebe wa Kanada, Jean Chretien, avuga ko ashimishijwe n’intambwe imaze guterwa mu gushyira mu bikorwa gahunda y’iterambere ry’Afurika.
mt0: <pad> The Canadian Prime Minister, Jean Chretien, said he was pleased with the progress made in implementing the African Development Plan.</s>

en: Mr. Chretien made the remarks Sunday after meeting with South African President Thabo Mbeki and other regional leaders in Pretoria.
kin: Ku cyumweru, Bwana Chretien yabivuze nyuma yo kubonana na Perezida wa Afurika y'Epfo Thabo Mbeki n'abandi bayobozi b'akarere muri Pretoria.
mt0: <pad> Mr Chretien said this on Sunday after meeting South African President Thabo Mbeki and other regional officials in Pretoria.</s>

en: Mr. Chretien, the current chairman of the group of the seven most industrialized nations plus Russia, is visiting Africa to discuss the New Partnership for Africa's Development, known as NEPAD.
kin: Bwana Chretien, usanzwe ayoboye itsinda ry’ibihugu birindwi byateye imbere mu nganda hiyongereyeho Uburusiya, asuye Afurika kugira ngo baganire ku bufatanye bushya bwo guteza imbere Afurika, buzwi ku izina rya NEPAD.
mt0: <pad> Mr. Chretien, former head of the G7 industrial group plus Russia, is in Africa to discuss the new North East African Development Partnership (NEPAD).</s>

en: He said NEPAD will be one of the top agendas at the June G-8 summit in Kananaskis, Canada.
kin: Yavuze ko NEPAD izaba imwe muri gahunda ziza mu nama ya G-8 Kamena izabera i Kananaskis, muri Kanada.
mt0: <pad> He said NEPAD would be one of the agendas at the G-8 meeting in June in Kananaskis, Canada.</s>

en: The G-8 nations are Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United States and Russia.
kin: Ibihugu G-8 ni Ubwongereza, Kanada, Ubufaransa, Ubudage, Ubutaliyani, Ubuyapani, Amerika n'Uburusiya.
mt0: <pad> The G-8 countries are the UK, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, America and Russia.</s>

en: Mr. Chretien says topics such as human rights, democracy the rule of law, transparency and good governance will be discussed at the G8 summit.
kin: Bwana Chretien avuga ko mu nama ya G8 hazaganirwaho ingingo nk’uburenganzira bwa muntu, demokarasi kugendera ku mategeko, gukorera mu mucyo n’imiyoborere myiza.
mt0: <pad> Mr. Chretien said that the G8 meeting will discuss human rights, rule of law, transparency and good governance.</s>

en: NEPAD outlines objectives of promoting democracy and good governance in Africa in return for Western economic assistance. It seeks to achieve an annual growth rate of seven-percent on the African continent by 2015.
kin: NEPAD igaragaza intego zo guteza imbere demokarasi n’imiyoborere myiza muri Afurika hagamijwe ubufasha bw’ubukungu bw’iburengerazuba. Irashaka kugera ku iterambere ry’umwaka wa karindwi ku ijana ku mugabane wa Afurika muri 2015.
mt0: <pad> NEPAD aims to promote democracy and good governance in Africa through western economic support. It wants to achieve a seven percent development rate for the continent by 2015.</s>

en: South African President Mbeki said he is convinced that Africa is ready for NEPAD saying there has been definite progress toward democracy in the continent.
kin: Perezida wa Afurika y'Epfo, Mbeki, yatangaje ko yizeye ko Afurika yiteguye NEPAD avuga ko hari intambwe igaragara kuri demokarasi ku mugabane wa Afurika.
mt0: <pad> South African President, Mbeki, said he believed that Africa was prepared for NEPAD and said there had been a clear step in the development of democracy in the continent.</s>

en: Later, Mr. Chretien and Mr. Mbeki were joined by presidents Festus Mogae of Botswana, Bakili Muluzu of Malawi, Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique, Sam Nujoma of Namibia, Benjamin Makapa of Tanzania and Vice President Enoch Kavindele of Zambia.
kin: Nyuma, Bwana Chretien na Bwana Mbeki bari kumwe na ba perezida Festus Mogae wa Botswana, Bakili Muluzu wa Malawi, Joaquim Chissano wo muri Mozambike, Sam Nujoma wo muri Namibiya, Benjamin Makapa wo muri Tanzaniya na Visi Perezida Enoki Kavindele wa Zambiya.
mt0: <pad> The following day, Mr. Chretien and Mbeki were joined by the presidents of Botswana, Bakili Muluzu of Malawi, Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique, Sam Nujoma of Namibia, Benjamin Makapa of Tanzania and Vice President Enoki Kavindele of Zambia.</s>

en: Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe, who won re-election in disputed voting last month, was not invited.
kin: Perezida wa Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, watsinze amatora yongeye gutorwa mu kwezi gushize, ntabwo yatumiwe.
mt0: <pad> The president of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, who won re-election last month, was not invited.</s>

en: Reuters news agency reports the Canadian prime minister who has already visited Morocco, Algeria and Nigeria on his six-nation tour will visit Ethiopia and Senegal after South Africa.
kin: Ibiro ntaramakuru Reuters bivuga ko minisitiri w’intebe wa Kanada umaze gusura Maroc, Alijeriya na Nijeriya mu ruzinduko rwe mu bihugu bitandatu azasura Etiyopiya na Senegali nyuma ya Afurika yepfo.
mt0: <pad> The Canadian Prime Minister, who has already visited Morocco, Algeria and Nigeria in his six-nation tour, will visit Ethiopia and Senegal after South Africa.</s>

en: Some information for this report provided by Reuters and AFP.
kin: Amakuru amwe kuriyi raporo yatanzwe na Reuters na AFP.
mt0: <pad> Some of the information about this report was provided by Reuters and AFP.</s>

en: Child Labor in Malawi - 2002-02-28
kin: Imirimo ikoreshwa abana muri Malawi - 2002-02-28
mt0: <pad> Child labour in Malawi - 2002-02-28</s>

en: The organization, Eye of the Child, is expressing concern about what is says is a large number of children who are being forced to work due to poverty.
kin: Uyu muryango, Ijisho ry'umwana, urimo kwerekana ko uhangayikishijwe n'ibivugwa ko ari umubare munini w'abana bahatirwa gukora kubera ubukene.
mt0: <pad> The organization, Child's Eye, is showing concern over what it says is the large number of children forced to work because of poverty.</s>

en: It says these children risk being abused.
kin: Ivuga ko aba bana bashobora guhohoterwa.
mt0: <pad> It says that these children may be abused.</s>

en: Some under aged children work as mini – bus call boys in the busy business district of Limbe in the commercial capital, Blantyre. They are some of the many children who have been forced into employment because of poverty.
kin: Bamwe bari munsi yabana bakuze bakora nka mini - bisi ihamagarira abahungu mukarere gafite ubucuruzi bwa Limbe mumurwa mukuru wubucuruzi, Blantyre. Ni bamwe mu bana benshi bahatiwe akazi kubera ubukene.
mt0: <pad> Some are under the age of adult children who work as mini-bus drivers for men in the business district of Limbe in the main town of Blantyre. They are some of many children forced to work because of poverty.</s>

en: Maxwell Matewere is the executive director of Eye of the Child. He says many of the children come from rural areas. He says, "Currently we havent done a data analysis but the Ministry of Labor intends to do that as soon as possible with financial resources from the International Labor Organization.
kin: Maxwell Matewere ni umuyobozi mukuru w'ijisho ry'umwana. Avuga ko benshi mu bana baturuka mu cyaro. Agira ati: "Kugeza ubu ntabwo twakoze isesengura ry'amakuru ariko Minisiteri y'umurimo irateganya kubikora vuba bishoboka hamwe n'amafaranga aturuka mu Muryango mpuzamahanga.
mt0: <pad> Maxwell Matewere is the director of Child Watch. He says that most of the children are from rural areas. He says: "For now we haven't done any analysis of the data but the ministry of labor plans to do it soon with international money."</s>

en: But basing on our own assessment and through our works, we feel child labor is a serious problem particularly in the rural areas and you can tell that from trafficking of children from rural areas to urban areas where most of the young people are working in peoples houses.

mt0: <pad> But based on our own assessment and through our work, we think child labour is a problem especially in rural areas and you can tell us that from the trafficking of children from the rural to the urban areas where many young people are working in private homes.</s>

en: " Mr. Matewere says poor children often find work on large farm estates.

mt0: <pad> Mr Matewere says that children from poor families often find jobs in small farms.</s>

en: He said, "We have noticed that there are some indications that there are children who are working in tea estates and tobacco estates.

en: He says this violates the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.

en: "If you look at the Convention of the Rights of a Child," he said, "you will see that it provides for the protection for children from any kind of exploitation from any kind of harmful activities or act which threatens their health, their development which is a threat to education.
kin: Ati: "Iyo urebye Amasezerano y’uburenganzira bw’umwana, uzabona ko ateganya kurinda abana ibikorwa ibyo ari byo byose byangiza ibikorwa cyangwa ibikorwa bibangamira ubuzima bwabo, iterambere ryabo. bikaba bibangamiye uburezi.
mt0: <pad> He said: "If you look at the Convention on Childhood, you will find that it provides protection for children from any harmful or destructive behaviors or behaviors that interfere with their life, development and education.</s>

en: So children who are found working in tea estates, who are found in brick making, obvious, their rights as it is provided for in the Convention for the Rights of the Children as well as in the constitution are violated. "
kin: Abana rero usanga bakorera mu cyayi usanga mu kubumba amatafari, bigaragara, uburenganzira bwabo nk'uko biteganywa n’amasezerano y’uburenganzira bw’abana kimwe n’itegeko nshinga. "
mt0: <pad> So children who work in the stone mining industry have clearly, as it is clear, their rights as stipulated by the convention on the rights of children and the constitution.</s>

mt0: <pad> To achieve this, the group has launched many programs. "We have just launched a new program and what we're trying to do is inform the public in general about the interests of children and their rights," he said.</s>

en: Zimbabwe Official Defends Crackdown on Protests, Urges Patience with Economy
kin: Umukozi wa Zimbabwe arengera guhashya imyigaragambyo, arasaba kwihangana mu bukungu
mt0: <pad> The Zimbabwean government has again refused to quell the protests, calling for patience in economic reforms.</s>

en: Zimbabwe's minister of foreign affairs and international trade on Monday defended crackdowns on anti-government demonstrations and urged patience in turning around the country's foundering economy.
kin: Kuri uyu wa mbere, minisitiri w’ububanyi n’amahanga w’ubucuruzi n’ubucuruzi mpuzamahanga wa Zimbabwe, yamaganye ihohoterwa ry’imyigaragambyo irwanya guverinoma anasaba kwihangana mu guhindura ubukungu bw’igihugu.
mt0: <pad> On Monday, the Zimbabwean minister of trade and international trade condemned the brutality of anti-government protests and urged patience in transforming the country's economic growth.</s>

en: Though "everybody's got the right to demonstrate," there have "been a lot of insinuations and campaigns of violence," Sibusiso B. Moyo told VOA in an interview. Citing public safety, he endorsed a Zimbabwe court's ruling hours earlier to uphold a police ban on a protest organized by the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) alliance.
kin: Mu kiganiro "Sibusiso B. Moyo" yabwiye VOA mu kiganiro na Sibusiso B. Moyo ati: "N'ubwo" abantu bose bafite uburenganzira bwo kwerekana, "habaye" insinations nyinshi n’ubukangurambaga bw’ihohoterwa. " Avuga ku mutekano rusange, yemeje icyemezo cyafashwe n’urukiko rwa Zimbabwe mbere y’uko icyemezo cy’abapolisi kibuza imyigaragambyo yateguwe n’umuryango utavuga rumwe n’ubutegetsi uharanira demokarasi (MDC).
mt0: <pad> "Even though everyone has the right to demonstrate, there have been many insinations and incitement to violence," he said in an interview with VOA's Sibusiso B. Moyo.</s>

en: Alliance leaders are pressing President Emmerson Mnangagwa and the ruling ZANU-PF party for a role in a transitional government. They had organized a demonstration Monday in Bulawayo, the country's second-largest city, but police authorities banned it hours before its intended start. Two other opposition demonstrations still are planned this week: for the central city of Gweru on Tuesday and the southeastern city of Masvingo on Wednesday.
kin: Abayobozi b’ubumwe barimo guhatira Perezida Emmerson Mnangagwa n’ishyaka riri ku butegetsi rya ZANU-PF kugira uruhare muri guverinoma y’inzibacyuho. Ku wa mbere, bari barateguye imyigaragambyo i Bulawayo, umujyi wa kabiri mu gihugu, ariko abayobozi ba polisi barabuhagaritse amasaha make mbere yuko gitangira. Muri iki cyumweru harateganijwe indi myigaragambyo ibiri itavuga rumwe n’ubutegetsi: ku mujyi wa Gweru rwagati ku wa kabiri n’umujyi wa Masvingo uherereye mu majyepfo y’iburasirazuba.
mt0: <pad> The opposition is demanding President Emmerson Mnangagwa and the ruling party ZANU-PF to participate in an interim government.</s>

en: Police also had pre-emptively banned a demonstration in Harare last Friday, a decision upheld by a Zimbabwe court. Hundreds of MDC supporters ignored the ban, leading to clashes between civilians and police. Video and photographs showed police hitting and kicking some demonstrators among actions that drew complaints of excessive force from civil and human rights groups, including the United Nations human rights office.
kin: Ku wa gatanu ushize, abapolisi bari barabujije mbere na mbere imyigaragambyo yabereye i Harare, icyemezo cyemejwe n'urukiko rwa Zimbabwe. Amajana y'abashyigikiye MDC birengagije iryo tegeko, bituma habaho imirwano hagati y'abasivili n'abapolisi. Amashusho n'amafoto byerekanaga abapolisi gukubita no gukubita bamwe mu bigaragambyaga mu bikorwa byagaragazaga ibirego by’ingufu zikabije z’imiryango iharanira uburenganzira bwa muntu n’uburenganzira bwa muntu, harimo n’ibiro by’umuryango w’abibumbye bishinzwe uburenganzira bwa muntu.
mt0: <pad> Last Friday, police had already banned protests in Harare, a decision that was approved by the Zimbabwean court. Hundreds of supporters of the MDC overturned the ban, causing clashes between civilians and police. Pictures and videos showed policemen beating and beating some protesters in actions that were described as excessive force by human rights groups and human rights organizations, including the UN Human Rights Office.</s>

en: Police, not demonstrators, showed up in force on Bulawayo streets Monday, with foot patrols wielding shields, batons and, in some cases, pistols. The Associated Press reported police trucks and water cannons positioned in the downtown area.
kin: Ku wa mbere, abapolisi, ntabwo ari abigaragambyaga, berekanye imbaraga mu mihanda ya Bulawayo, bafite amarondo y'ibirenge akoresheje ingabo, inkoni ndetse rimwe na rimwe, pistolet. Ibiro ntaramakuru by'Abanyamerika Associated Press byatangaje ko amakamyo ya polisi hamwe n’ibisasu by’amazi biri mu mujyi rwagati.
mt0: <pad> Monday, police, not protesters, showed their force in the streets of Bulawayo, with rubber bullets, sticks and sometimes pistols. The American news agency Associated Press reported that police trucks and water cannons were in the center of the city.</s>

en: A young man in Bulawayo, identifying himself only as James, told VOA that negotiations between the government and opposition leaders were even more important than demonstrations.
kin: Umusore wo muri Bulawayo, wiyita James gusa, yabwiye Ijwi rya Amerika ko imishyikirano hagati ya guverinoma n’abayobozi batavuga rumwe n’ubutegetsi ari ngombwa kuruta imyigaragambyo.
mt0: <pad> James, a Bulawayo boy who only calls himself James, told the Voice of America that talks between the government and the opposition are more important than protests.</s>

en: "Honestly, to demonstrate, we can end up being hurt by being beaten, being chased around. There's really nothing that we see coming out of it," James said. "But these men should sit down and see what they can do for us, especially us, the youth. … We have been affected a lot, and we are getting old just running."
kin: James yagize ati: "Mvugishije ukuri, kwerekana, dushobora kurangiza kubabazwa no gukubitwa, kwirukanwa hirya no hino. Mubyukuri ntakintu tubona kivamo." "Ariko aba bagabo bagomba kwicara bakareba icyo badukorera, cyane cyane twe, urubyiruko.… Twagize ingaruka nyinshi, kandi turasaza twiruka."
mt0: <pad> James said: "To tell the truth, protesting can end the pain and suffering and beatings, expulsion everywhere. In reality, there isn't anything we see coming out of it." "But these men have to sit down and look at what they're doing to us, especially us, young people.... We've been affected so much, and as we get older, we're running away."</s>

en: Moyo, the foreign minister, told VOA the administration is "undertaking economic reforms [that] are fundamental and they are key to ensuring that even the youth would finally have jobs created for them, so that we can create an environment where investors and the capital will find it easy to come into this country, where jobs will be created, and the youth will be part and parcel of economic activity."

en: Few people have turned up for an opposition protest in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second city, on Monday as armed police maintained heavy presence on the streets and at a courthouse where the opposition is pressing to be allowed to hold the demonstration.
kin: Ku wa mbere, abantu bake bitabiriye imyigaragambyo y’abatavuga rumwe n’ubutegetsi i Bulawayo, umujyi wa kabiri wa Zimbabwe, mu gihe abapolisi bitwaje intwaro bakomeje kuba benshi mu mihanda no mu rukiko aho abatavuga rumwe n’ubutegetsi basaba ko bemererwa gukora iyo myigaragambyo.
mt0: <pad> On Monday, a small number of people attended protests in Bulawayo, the second city of Zimbabwe, while armed police remained busy on the streets and at the court where the protesters were asking for permission to hold the protests.</s>

en: The opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, had called the protest as part of a planned series of demonstrations to push President Emmerson Mnangagwa to agree to a transitional government amid a rapidly deteriorating economy and rising political tensions.

en: "Government calls on all progressive Zimbabweans to desist from being used by negative forces to destabilize their own country, as this will only prolong the hardships which the government is tirelessly trying to address in a more sustainable manner," she said. mt0: <pad> "The government urges all citizens of Zimbabwe to refrain from being used by unwanted forces to destabilise their country, as this will only add to the problems the government is trying to solve in a long-term way."</s>
